Ipswich boss Mick McCarthy praised Varney’s performance and the team’s resilience after recent poor form, while Holloway criticized his side’s mental fragility, defending Smithies and blaming defensive errors for the collapse. QPR rarely threatened, with Ipswich creating multiple saved or missed opportunities, including efforts from David McGoldrick, Freddie Sears, and Jonathan Douglas.

Tom Wells, aged 23, delivered a strong performance in last season’s T20 Blast, amassing **373 runs at an average of 28.69** and a **strike rate of 138.66**, highlighting his impact as a key player. He praised the club’s **positive trajectory**, emphasizing the **elite performance culture fostered by the coaches**, which he noted motivates players to engage and excel within the team.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12, with standout performances from Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, whose defensive efforts—including over 70 tackles from the front row and front five—proved pivotal. Coach Churcher highlighted the team’s emotionally resilient but incomplete display, emphasizing the need to build on this performance to avoid wasting progress. Looking ahead, the Reds face seven of their next eight matches against lower-ranked teams, along with a clash against league leaders Old Elthamians, while Churcher insists there remains significant room for improvement.

The police accuse 28-year-old Nazrul (also known as Nazu), a Bangladeshi citizen, of raping a 74-year-old nun during a violent attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on **14 March**, where money was stolen and the building ransacked. Nazrul was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after fleeing to Bangladesh following his identification via **CCTV footage**, acting on a tip-off about his return by train. The crime sparked nationwide outrage and protests in India, with this being the **sixth arrest** in the case—police have identified **eight suspects**, two of whom remain at large. Earlier arrests include **Milon Sarkar**, alleged gang leader, though his exact role is unclear, while all five previously arrested suspects implicated Nazrul as the rapist, according to police statements to the **BBC** and **AFP**.

The passage describes an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of London’s *Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising*, which examines key factors influencing changes in UK consumer purchasing habits, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands, with interactive elements for deeper engagement, though it may not function on older browsers. A non-interactive version and supplementary links—covering topics like Chinese brand ownership, food freezing tips, and the UK’s top 20 consumer brands—are provided as alternatives. The video is optimized for full-screen viewing.

Two elderly women in Scotland—one in Sandyhills (71 years old) and another in Stranraer—were scammed by callers posing as BT technical support, with the incidents occurring on 15 September and 22 September, respectively. The fraudsters claimed to fix internet issues, gained remote access to the victims’ computers, and stole money. PC Siobhan Pellett warned about the alarming ease of such scams and the significant financial losses, urging the public to never share banking details over the phone, as legitimate businesses never request this information. The police emphasized extreme caution with unsolicited calls seeking remote computer access.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship team Featherstone Rovers after departing Swinton Lions, where he was succeeded by his ex-assistant Stuart Littler. He will make his debut as Featherstone’s head coach in their final league match against Toulouse before leading them into the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s coaching ability and resilience, highlighting his strong performance under challenging conditions at Swinton. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with clubs like Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, brings experience both as a player and coach to his new role.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at **Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday**, where an injured rider was found. According to crewman **Chris Page**, the individual had **head injuries and was severely cold** after lying unconscious on wet sand. After receiving on-site treatment, the rider was **airlifted to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales** for further care.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate a dedicated radio frequency for a global satellite-based flight tracking system, addressing gaps in the current ground radar-dependent system after the 2014 disappearance of **MH370** with 239 passengers. Over 160 countries at the **World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC)**, led by the **ITU**, agreed to enable satellites to receive **ADS-B transmissions**—currently limited to aircraft-to-aircraft or ground stations—allowing **"real-time tracking anywhere in the world"** (per ITU’s Francois Rancy). The move follows **MH370’s vanishing**, which exposed flaws in global air navigation, leaving **70% of airspace uncovered**; Malaysia had earlier urged the ITU to improve real-time data transmission. The plane, en route from **Kuala Lumpur to Beijing**, is presumed crashed in the **southern Indian Ocean**, with debris confirmed on **Réunion Island** in July 2015. The **ICAO** set a **November 2016 deadline** for new tracking rules, including **position updates every 15 minutes** (or more in emergencies), while ITU Secretary-General **Houlin Zhao** hailed the decision as a swift response to global demands for enhanced flight tracking.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, was found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, 53, in Cleveland after the FBI received a tip on 30 October following issues with the teen’s college application. Authorities, including Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed his identity and notified his mother. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012, held at Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail. Investigators had long suspected him in Julian’s disappearance after he claimed to be taking the boy to pre-school in August 2002 but instead fled.

A fire on **2 March** at a site on **Duncan Street**, operated by **Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited** (run by **Asset and Land Group**), disrupted train services and caused travel delays, prompting a multi-day response from firefighters. The **Environment Agency (EA)** subsequently **suspended the company’s waste acceptance** and **revoked its environmental permit**, effective **7 August** unless appealed, also requiring all waste to be removed. While **Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS)** stated the site was **"broadly compliant"** with fire safety laws—having conducted **nine inspections in the past year**—they had **warned the EA in February** about potential risks to residents, transport, and the environment. Joint visits with the EA led to enforcement action, though the **fire’s cause remains undetermined**, and the company has not commented.

The pro-Kremlin party **A Just Russia** proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, particularly targeting Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong. The first bill would allow Russia to annex foreign territories—without a treaty—if local leaders request it or a referendum is held, justifying this as necessary when a neighboring state is "disintegrating." The second bill accelerates Russian citizenship for Ukrainians, waiving fees, residency requirements, financial proofs, and dual citizenship restrictions, framing it as protection against a "brown threat" (a reference to fascism). Applicants could gain citizenship in two months via Russian diplomatic missions before August 1. The moves echo Russia’s 2008 annexation of **Abkhazia and South Ossetia** from Georgia, with MPs and celebrities like **Irina Rodnina** and **Nikolai Valuev** visiting Crimea to promote the measures. Many Crimeans, especially in **Sevastopol** (home to Russia’s Black Sea Fleet), already hold Russian passports.

McLaren, once a dominant force in Formula 1 with 182 grand prix wins, a 23.18% win rate, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, now struggles to secure even fourth place in the grid, despite fielding two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 due to poor chassis design, and while the car has improved, the current issue lies with the underperforming Honda power unit—a stark contrast to their past glory, particularly the 1988 season where they won 15 of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. After periods of dominance (1984–1999) and scandals (2007’s "Spygate" and 2009’s "Lie-gate"), the team’s last constructors' title came in 1998. Founded by Bruce McLaren, the team cycled through eras of success and decline, with Ron Dennis playing a pivotal role in revivals, though his 2013 return has yet to yield results. Dennis remains optimistic, claiming McLaren will end Mercedes’ dominance, but for now, their hopes rest on Honda’s engine improvements and Alonso’s gamble on the partnership to secure a third title. The team’s future hinges on reversing their current slump to uphold their legendary status.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest on 27 January at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool’s Old Swan area and later died in hospital. Police believe the attackers had waited outside Phoenix Gym—where Baker had just been—for about an hour before shooting him as he entered his car. Three Liverpool men (aged 29, 29, and 32) remain in custody, while detectives continue searching for a silver VW Polo seen speeding away via Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Authorities urge witnesses captured on CCTV near the market to come forward, as their information could be critical to the investigation.

The passage highlights modern, digital ways to engage with Christmas spiritually while embracing technology. **Everyday Church Online** offers virtual services, including a *Star Wars*-themed Christmas sermon ("The Hope Awakens"), attracting a global congregation from 61 countries. **Guardians of Ancora**, a free fantasy game for ages 8–11, uses Bible-based quests—including Christmas-themed missions about Jesus’ birth—to teach scripture through gameplay. Viral Christmas videos, like *The Digital Story of Nativity* (6M views), retell the nativity via social media parodies, while *Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle* (250K views) blends modern and biblical scenes but faced cinema rejection for being "too religious." **Next Manga** distributes Bible stories in *Manga Messiah*, including a nativity version in 33 languages, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to refugees. Churches also leverage social media (Facebook, Twitter) to share spiritual reflections, emphasizing brief, thought-provoking content over direct evangelism, with pastors noting Jesus’ adaptability as a communicator.

A public inquiry in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to develop a circuit on **250 hectares (600 acres) of common land**, with supporters—including **Blaenau Gwent council**—offering **320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land** as compensation. Experts presented **conflicting views** on environmental impacts: **Natural Resources Wales** found it hard to confirm the replacement land’s equal value but did not fully oppose the project, while the **developers’ ecology report** claimed a **"net gain" in biodiversity** due to nearby habitat enhancements—a claim disputed by the **Gwent Wildlife Trust**. The **Planning Inspectorate for Wales** will issue a recommendation after the eight-day hearing, with the **final decision resting with Welsh government ministers**.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a *Novaya Gazeta* report on 3 April as an insult to their faith and dignity, issuing a resolution warning of "retribution" against those responsible—interpreted by the paper as a threat to journalists. The 1 April report alleged over 100 gay men were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed, and described torture, including electric shocks, at a prison near Argun; the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the claims and accused authorities of inaction. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov, a Putin ally, denied the allegations, with his spokesman claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya, while Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev reiterated the call for divine punishment against the paper. *Novaya Gazeta* defended its reporting, noting past murders of its journalists (Anna Politkovskaya, Natalia Estemirova) and opposition figure Boris Nemtsov—all linked to Chechen investigations—and vowed to continue exposing abuses. The LGBT Network is aiding victims in fleeing and threatens to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has profited significantly over the past two years by housing single homeless men—primarily those over 35—through housing benefit payments, often charging higher total benefits than the rent passed to landlords. The charity **Fresh Start Housing**, founded in 2010 by **Samir Patel** (who also established Investing Solutions in 2002), refers clients from London homeless charities to both the agency and private landlords, though critics argue the arrangement exploits vulnerable tenants. Both organizations operate from the same south London building, with Investing Solutions becoming one of the UK’s largest housing benefit recipients by placing unrelated individuals in shared properties, maximizing payouts—e.g., claiming **£2,114/month** for two tenants while paying the landlord **£1,150**, netting **£11,568/year** profit per property. Tenants like **Nigel McCann** report substandard conditions (rats, damp, no heating), while **Wandsworth Council**—which paid the agency over **£2.1m** in two years—claims it monitors housing standards. Homeless charity **Crisis** condemned the model as exploitative, though Patel defended the arrangement, stating most rents go to private landlords and that Fresh Start Housing has rehoused **788 people** since its founding. The **Department for Communities** emphasized local authorities’ role in safeguarding taxpayer funds.

Great Britain’s men’s basketball team, coached by Joe Prunty, led for most of their final warm-up game against the Netherlands—with London 2012 Olympian **Andrew Lawrence** scoring 14 points and NBA player **Ben Gordon** adding 13—but were overtaken in the last 10 minutes, losing 71-60 after the Dutch opened the fourth quarter with a 10-0 run. GB had built a 35-24 lead in the second quarter, but the Netherlands, led by **Worthy De Jong’s 18 points**, rallied to take control despite a late GB comeback. Prunty emphasized the need for **consistent intensity** ahead of their **EuroBasket qualifiers**, starting with a midweek game in Hungary, and praised Gordon’s performance, particularly his third-quarter three-pointers, noting his adaptation to the team after missing the 2012 Olympics. The match served as Prunty’s final roster evaluation before trimming the squad for the six-game qualifying campaign.

Conor McGregor submitted a required waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) ahead of his 154lb bout with Floyd Mayweather, which mandates 10oz gloves under standard rules, though Mayweather had previously expressed a preference for 8oz gloves—lighter gloves that increase punch impact but reduce hand protection. The NAC will debate the glove issue on 16 August, prioritizing fighter safety, as deviations from regulations require commission approval. McGregor, a UFC veteran accustomed to 4oz gloves, welcomed the idea, while the NAC’s Bob Bennett cited McGregor’s knockout power, durability, youth, and physical advantages over Mayweather—who hasn’t scored a knockout in a decade—as key factors in approving the fight. Bennett also noted McGregor’s progress in boxing training, including sparring sessions with Paulie Malignaggi (who later left the camp), and the hiring of referee Joe Cortez to familiarize McGregor with boxing rules. Despite criticism from boxing figures like Oscar De La Hoya, the NAC deemed the fight justified based on McGregor’s performance data and comparative advantages.

Fleet Street, once the epicenter of British journalism, is closing its final chapter as the *Sunday Post* shuts its London office, marking the departure of its last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked there for decades. Historically, Fleet Street was the heart of the UK’s newspaper industry, home to nearly every national and many provincial papers, where iconic titles like the *Daily Courant*—Britain’s first daily newspaper in 1702—were published. In its heyday, the street thrived with bustling newsrooms, smoke-filled offices, clattering typewriters, and legendary pubs like El Vino (which once barred women), where journalists socialized and chased stories. Veterans like Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson recall an era when newspapers dominated public information, fueled by heavy drinking, male-dominated newsrooms, and a culture of camaraderie, though women faced significant barriers. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch relocated his papers to Wapping, sparking union conflicts and accelerating the shift to digital technology, leading most newspapers to abandon Fleet Street by 1988. Today, its former newspaper buildings house businesses like Sainsbury’s and Pizza Express, while the street’s journalistic legacy fades—though Smith and Sherriff reflect on its historical significance as they transition to freelance work and memoir-writing, respectively.

J.K. Rowling reflected on the mix of abuse and support she receives on Twitter, noting that despite harsh criticism—including being called a "traitor" for her £1m donation against Scottish independence and her Labour Party contribution—she believes most people are decent and stands against online bullies. She blocked abusive users, some allegedly SNP supporters, but also engaged positively with others, highlighting shared political views. After the SNP’s landslide victory in the UK election (winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats), Rowling humorously deflected a call to burn her books by offering to "bring marshmallows," while asserting she won’t stay silent about abuse to spare any party’s reputation.

A University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as better-off peers and were five times more likely to be placed under statutory supervision, with poverty strongly linked to higher risks of offending and victimization—even after accounting for other risk factors. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, while poorer girls were twice as likely to commit violent crimes compared to affluent peers. The study, tracking 4,300 Edinburgh youth since 1998, also revealed that prior police trouble was the strongest predictor of being NEET (not in education, employment, or training) by 18, suggesting juvenile justice contact exacerbates poverty-related risks. A separate report in *Scottish Justice Matters* showed crime remains concentrated in the poorest areas, with half of high-crime communities also ranking in the top 20% for chronic health issues and a third in the top 20% for unemployment, despite Scotland’s overall crime rates hitting a 41-year low. Researchers criticized insufficient progress on inequality, while the Scottish government highlighted investments to mitigate poverty and welfare cuts.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway at the Marian estate in Kilkee early Sunday after a fight involving multiple individuals, including Robbie Walsh, who was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August. Police allege Walsh and two other men entered the estate around 01:00, searching for Haugh, before encountering him and another man, leading to a violent altercation where weapons—including knives and golf clubs—were used. Haugh was stabbed in the back, taken to Limerick University Hospital, and pronounced dead at 06:00. A bloodstained knife blade and handle were recovered at the scene, while the two other arrested men were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. The court noted heightened local tensions following the incident.

In May 2014, Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a false claim about Tom Elliott, alleging he had harassed and shot people while serving in the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) from 1982–1992, despite Elliott having a clear Ministry of Defence record. The tweet, posted after Elliott appeared on a BBC radio program, was deleted within an hour and prompted legal action, with Elliott—now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone—being alerted by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP’s Arlene Foster. Flanagan later apologized, admitting the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation," and must post the apology on Twitter by a court-ordered deadline, while compensation is still under consideration by Mr. Justice Stevens. The insurance firm covering Stormont MLAs refused to indemnify Flanagan for costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he felt "totally vindicated" but criticized the prolonged legal process, expressing relief at the outcome after 19 months.

Hawick Knitwear, a historic company founded in 1874 and acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, has expanded production to 9,500 sweaters weekly—up from 7,500—due to strong demand, driven by better-than-expected sales of its newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range (introduced in January) and growth in its long-standing private-label business. Employing over 230 staff, the firm supplies markets across Europe (including Sweden, Germany, and France) and internationally in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the production surge to increased orders from domestic and global private-label clients, as well as the new brand, praising the workforce’s dedication and expressing confidence in sustained future success despite ongoing challenges.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years of service, suffered severe head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright’s VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December, leaving her now in residential care. Wright, 55, admitted hitting her but denies dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun—just 10 minutes from sunset—and couldn’t recall the traffic light color. The incident occurred as Blackburn, wearing proper gear, stepped into the road to escort a woman and child during a red light, while other traffic had stopped. Wright expressed deep remorse, stating he had devastated Blackburn’s life and family, and described being in shock after hearing a "bump." The trial at Luton Crown Court is ongoing, with prosecutors arguing Wright failed to stop for the red light.

A NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, codenamed *Dynamic Mongoose*, simulates a response to rising Russian submarine activity near European waters, exposing gaps in Britain’s defenses. The drill involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS *Vicksburg* and HMS *Portland*, hunting a German U-boat (*U33*) acting as the "enemy," while helicopters and underwater drones assist in tracking. Russian submarines—now numbering around 60, including advanced, ultra-quiet models—pose a significant threat, capable of evading detection for months and monitoring NATO movements. Britain’s lack of maritime patrol aircraft, once provided by the retired Nimrod fleet, leaves it reliant on allies like France for surveillance, creating a critical vulnerability, particularly in protecting its nuclear deterrent. Experts warn Russia is exploiting these weaknesses, with submarines and bombers probing UK defenses, underscoring the urgency for Britain to address its defense gaps in the upcoming security review.

UN officials warn that South Sudan—already the world’s youngest country—could face **genocide or ethnic cleansing** amid escalating violence that erupted in July, displacing **340,000 people into Uganda** (more than any other country this year, surpassing Syria’s 200,000 refugees). Refugees, including children, report **targeted killings, rape, and ethnic violence**, primarily between **Dinka (President Salva Kiir’s group), Nuer (former VP Riek Machar’s faction), and Equatorians**, who were recently drawn into the conflict after rebel forces fled the capital. Survivors describe brutal attacks—**men hacked to death, women raped, and children beaten**—forcing families to flee on foot through the bush. Uganda, initially coping well by allocating land and aid, now struggles under the strain of **nearly 1 million refugees**, with shortages of water and resources. The UN urges global intervention to stop the **"massacre of civilians"** as refugee settlements like **Bidi Bidi (now home to 250,000+ people)** swell, while traumatized children, like 16-year-old Patricia Mercy, express their losses through poetry, revealing the war’s devastating human toll.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former Norwich and Peterborough footballer turned professional boxer in 2013 after leaving football in 2011, will face Jahmaine Smyle on **12 November at York Hall** for the **English super-middleweight title**. With a record of **eight wins and one draw** from nine fights, he is the son of ex-**British and European champion Clinton McKenzie** and is trained by his uncle, **three-time world champion Duke McKenzie**.

Bridgwater Community Hospital will receive £33m as part of a £330m national NHS investment to replace its outdated 1813 facility, which is now cramped, poorly insulated, and costly to maintain. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners, with funding split between the coalition and NHS Somerset/Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Staff, including Matron Sue Taylor, highlight the current building’s negative impact on patient recovery and the need for a modern, uplifting environment. The project, aimed for completion by autumn 2014, is part of broader upgrades in Somerset, where three of 13 community hospitals have been replaced in five years, alongside the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital. Dr. Donal Hynes, a local GP, emphasizes the benefits for patient care, noting the hospital’s "one-stop shop" approach. Construction depends on planning permission for the proposed Bowers Lane site.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on **Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe**, near Sheffield’s city centre, after being attacked either inside or near a **black Mercedes** he was driving. Emergency services arrived at **13:35 GMT** and found him with a **chest gunshot wound**; he later died at **Northern General Hospital**. Locals reported the victim was part of a nearby family gathered for a **celebration** when the shooting occurred, with relatives rushing to aid him after hearing the gunfire. The incident follows a recent spike in Sheffield shootings—though prior cases were concentrated in **northern areas** like **Shiregreen** (a 25-year-old seriously injured on Monday), **Southey Green** (shots fired at an elderly couple’s home, believed to be mistaken identity), and **High Green** (two separate house shootings in January). **Upperthorpe had not been affected** by previous incidents. Armed police **sealed off the scene** after the attack.

The passage details the activities of three prominent hacktivist groups involved in the Ukraine-Russia conflict: the pro-Ukrainian **Ukrainian Cyber Troops** (led by Yevhen Dokukin), the pro-Russian **Cyber Berkut**, and the Russian-focused **Anonymous International (Shaltay Boltay)**. The **Ukrainian Cyber Troops** target Russian government servers, separatist websites (via DDoS attacks), funding platforms like PayPal, and CCTV systems in rebel-held areas, while also hijacking printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages; they claim to share hacked data—including evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine—with Ukrainian security services, though officials deny using such intelligence for military operations. **Cyber Berkut**, aligned with Russian state rhetoric, disrupts Ukrainian government sites (e.g., during Joe Biden’s visit), leaks alleged U.S. military aid documents, manipulates electronic billboards to label Ukrainian leaders as "war criminals," and claims to have hacked communications suggesting Ukrainian responsibility for MH17 (unverified). **Anonymous International** primarily exposes Kremlin-related leaks, including emails from rebel commander Igor Girkin and reports of weak local support for separatists, though its methods (hacking vs. insider leaks) remain unclear, and its site is blocked in Russia. All groups operate as ostensibly independent activists, though their actions often align with broader geopolitical narratives.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewell speeches ahead of the 5 May election, marking their departure from the Scottish Parliament. Salmond, who led Scotland from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his long-held view that Scotland is "diverse, not divided," emphasizing broad consensus on strengthening Holyrood’s governance while criticizing the Scotland Bill for falling short of referendum pledges. He blended humor—joking about competing with the UK budget and Cheltenham races—with a heartfelt tribute to public service, calling membership in parliament the "greatest honour." McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must improve scrutiny and accountability, urging lessons from Westminster’s committee system to avoid consequences. Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also stepped down, playfully noting her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick praised Salmond’s distinguished service and was visibly moved by McNeil’s speech, highlighting the end of an era for several long-serving politicians.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review to gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and carers about residential care in Wales, aiming to assess quality of life—including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care environments—to develop recommendations for providers and public bodies. While she acknowledges examples of high-quality care, she highlights concerns over unacceptable variations and rising complaints about standards across Wales. The review seeks to ensure accountability and drive improvements by amplifying the voices of older people and their support networks. However, Care Forum Wales, led by Mario Kreft, criticizes the exclusion of care home providers, managers, or residents from the main advisory panel, arguing it undermines partnership opportunities and sector engagement in the process.

Aberdeenshire’s **Harbro Group** reported a **pre-tax profit rise of £800,000 to £3.5 million** for the year ending June 2016, despite a **£1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million**, driven by **growth in international sales across Europe and newer markets**. The **Turriff-based company** specializes in manufacturing and supplying **animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors**, while also operating **19 Country Store retail outlets** across Scotland, offering products like **farming supplies, country clothing, and fireside goods** to rural communities. While acknowledging **ongoing challenges in agriculture and uncertainty around Brexit**, the company expressed confidence in its **resilience and preparedness** to navigate future business risks.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, with police treating the death as murder, while a man in his 80s was hospitalized. Detectives are urgently seeking **Ian John McLoughlin (55)**, also known as **Ian John Baker**, warning the public not to approach him. Described as **white, 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair, average build**, he was last seen wearing **sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter trousers, and a dark/light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt**. The investigation remains in its early stages, and police have increased patrols in the area while appealing for witnesses to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the IMF’s deputy chief, warned in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics that the global economy is weakening, calling it a "delicate juncture," following China’s sharp 25% drop in year-over-year exports, which underscored slower-than-expected trade. The IMF is expected to lower its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its April update, signaling persistent challenges for businesses and industries reliant on China’s economic expansion.

A scrutiny meeting addressed ongoing issues with a new Cowes chain ferry, which has faced multiple problems since its 14 May launch, including breakdowns, groundings, a suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over "training issues," and damage to vehicles during boarding. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July as acknowledgment of the failures and to gather feedback, while confirming an auditor’s review of the project, calling its start "frustrating and disappointing." Local businesses, like shopkeeper Angie Booth, reported severe financial strain from lost trade, questioning whether compensation—similar to that for damaged cars—would be provided. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the problems as "teething issues" for a prototype, noting resolved electrical faults, planned ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping, and improved seamanship to address groundings, while stating compensation discussions were underway.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around **07:30 GMT on Thursday**, resulting in the death of a **32-year-old man** at the scene. A **33-year-old man from Waterlooville** was arrested on suspicion of **causing death by driving without due care and attention**, and the road between **Thursley and Liphook** remained closed until early evening for police investigations.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency for "beautiful and talented people," faced backlash for job adverts specifying physical attributes, such as a personal assistant with "brown long hair with a b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" for a high-paying role. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned the ads as "unlawful and demeaning," demanding clarification on hiring practices, while women’s rights groups called them outdated and discriminatory. The agency’s founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the criteria, citing client demands—like a "Jackie O" look for a Dior outfit or an Indian businessman hiring blonde, blue-eyed women—arguing appearance matters for brand representation. Employment lawyers warned the ads likely violate the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on age, gender, or other protected characteristics unless justified by job requirements, and noted rejected applicants could sue for unlimited compensation. Despite claims of catering to high-profile clients like MTV and Louis Vuitton, critics, including EHRC’s Rebecca Hilsenrath, urged the agency to abandon such practices, labeling them sexist and incompatible with modern workplace standards.

A shooting took place at a hostel linked to Bangalore’s private **Pragati Residential School**, where **Mahesh**, an office assistant at the school, allegedly entered the room of **18-year-old Gautami** and fatally shot her in the head on **Tuesday evening**, then injured another student, **Sirisha**, who survived. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and **remanded until 12 April**, though his motive remains unclear. While **gun crime in Indian schools is rare**, the incident echoes a 2007 case where a 14-year-old was killed by classmates near Delhi. Despite **strict gun control laws**, firearms are often used in personal disputes.

Glaad’s 2016–2017 *Where We Are on TV* report analyzed scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series, identifying **278 regular and recurring LGBT characters**, with **transgender representation doubling from seven to 16**. However, the study criticized the **deaths of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters**, including notable examples like *Orange Is the New Black*’s Poussey Washington and *Wentworth*’s Bea Smith. Additionally, the report highlighted a **record-high percentage of Black characters**, driven by shows such as *Empire*, *Luke Cage*, and *How to Get Away with Murder*. While Glaad’s president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged **progress in diversity**, she emphasized that **quantitative gains alone don’t reflect deeper representational challenges**. The findings were based on confirmed or airing series during the specified period.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, resigned ahead of a local party meeting where he faced likely deselection over a controversial £10.25m public loan to Northampton Town FC—approved when he was borough council leader—of which the funds are now missing. The loan, intended for Sixfields stadium redevelopment and land projects, is under police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities," with the stadium stand left unfinished. Mackintosh denies wrongdoing but stepped down after most of his local party’s executive council indicated they would vote to remove him, stating it was time for his constituents to have a new representative despite his initial plan to seek re-election.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in April after firing a rifle into a car driving away from a house party in Balch Springs, Texas, where police had responded to reports of underage drinking. Initially, police claimed the vehicle reversed aggressively toward Oliver, but bodycam footage later disproved this, showing the car moving forward. Oliver was fired days later for policy violations and charged with murder—facing 5 to 99 years in prison—along with four counts of aggravated assault for endangering the other teenagers in the car, including Edwards’ brothers. If convicted, he would be the first Dallas County officer found guilty of murder since 1973. The victim was remembered as exemplary by his coach, while the district attorney emphasized the pursuit of justice. Oliver remains free on bail, and no trial date has been set, with the Edwards family’s lawyer expressing cautious optimism given Texas’ rare history of convicting officers.

Melania and Barron Trump will delay moving into the White House until after Barron, 10, finishes the school year, sparking mixed reactions—critics calling it unprecedented or symbolic of marital issues, while supporters praise her prioritization of parenting. Historically, only two first ladies (Martha Washington and Anna Harrison) never lived in the White House, though others, like Frances Cleveland, spent limited time there. Many presidential families, including the Obamas and Clintons, managed school-age children by either moving early or adapting routines, with first ladies often balancing ceremonial duties with childcare. Melania’s focus on Barron suggests she may not adopt a traditional, full-time first lady role, hinting at a potential interest in cyber-bullying initiatives. Past first ladies, from Lou Hoover to Nancy Reagan, varied in public engagement, while daughters like Chelsea Clinton occasionally filled ceremonial gaps. The White House has historically accommodated family norms, from homework in the Oval Office to strict dinner schedules, blending public life with private routines.

A 72-year-old man died on **27 October** in a sheltered housing complex in **Inverness** after police responded to a call from him. The **Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc)**, led by **Kate Frame**, is investigating the **initial police response** to the call following instructions from the **Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS)**. **Police Scotland** states it is cooperating fully with the probe, while Pirc will submit a report on its findings to the COPFS at a later date.

A yellow wind warning was issued for parts of Wales, with local gusts reaching up to **75mph (120kmph)**, particularly west of the mountains, worsened by an unusual **easterly wind direction**. Forecasters warned of likely **travel disruptions on roads and at sea**, affecting **Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys**. Overnight gusts **toppled a tree in Menai Bridge (Anglesey)**, blocking **Telford Road**—a key route into the town—with the closure expected to last **most of Monday** for cleanup.

The Giants, led by player-coach Derrick Walser, started strongly but were tied by Jeff Dimmen of the Panthers, with the score finishing 1-1 in the first period. In the second, Mike Forney’s powerplay breakaway put the Giants ahead 2-1, but Andy Bohmback equalized for Nottingham. Mike Radja and James Desmarais extended the Giants' lead to 4-2 before David Ling pulled one back for the Panthers. The teams will face off again the following night in the second game of their double-header, with Nottingham topping the league on 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers (27) and Belfast (25).

Lewis Hamilton started last in the Chinese Grand Prix, suffered early damage from a first-lap collision with Felipe Nasr, and made five pit stops, finishing outside the podium after battling car issues, including suspected suspension and aerodynamic damage. His teammate Nico Rosberg won comfortably, extending his championship lead to 36 points over Hamilton, who now faces an uphill struggle to close the gap in the remaining 18 races—historically, no driver winning the first three races has failed to claim the title. Ferrari’s Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Räikkönen on lap one, damaging both cars; Räikkönen recovered to fifth, aided by a late soft-tyre advantage over Hamilton. Red Bull’s Daniil Kvyat (third) and Daniel Ricciardo (fourth) capitalized on the chaos, with Ricciardo losing the lead early due to a puncture after contact with Rosberg. The race was marred by a chaotic first lap, forcing a safety car, while post-race tensions flared as Vettel criticized Kvyat’s aggressive maneuver, calling him a "torpedo," though Kvyat defended his risky but successful podium bid. Hamilton remained optimistic about reversing his misfortune but acknowledged the significant performance deficit caused by his car’s damage.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent former German footballer, publicly came out as homosexual in an interview with *Die Zeit* to challenge the silence around LGBTQ+ issues in German football, becoming the first high-profile player to do so. His announcement was widely praised by teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as football officials such as Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball, who called it a "courageous step" in combating homophobia. International figures like Gary Lineker and John Amaechi also commended his bravery, while Bayern Munich and German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman Steffen Seibert emphasized the importance of tolerance and openness. The move contrasts with past controversies, including Philipp Lahm’s 2011 suggestion that gay players should stay closeted, and highlights ongoing struggles—like Marcus Urban’s 2007 revelation that Bundesliga players feared coming out. Politicians and activists, including Volker Beck, expressed hope that Hitzlsperger’s decision would break the taboo, with Zwanziger predicting sexuality would soon become a non-issue in football. The moment is seen as a potential turning point for German football’s approach to LGBTQ+ inclusion.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played 32 Championship matches this season, helping Brighton & Hove Albion secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, with the team now targeting the league title after building a four-point lead over Newcastle. With his contract expiring soon, Sidwell—who previously played in the Premier League for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke—hopes to earn a new deal to stay with Brighton, expressing confidence in their ability to survive in the top flight. Having initially joined on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year contract in June 2016, he believes his strong performances this season, exceeding expectations, warrant a renewed opportunity at the highest level.

Blackpool took an early lead in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt scored from Nathan Delfouneso’s cross, but Colchester equalized shortly after through Kurtis Guthrie following a corner after goalkeeper Sam Slocombe’s save denied Matthew Briggs. Slocombe made another crucial save before halftime, while Guthrie hit the bar, keeping the score 1-1. Blackpool missed a golden chance when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner, and Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray’s red card for a dangerous tackle on Jim McAlister in stoppage time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with both sides creating chances but failing to convert, including multiple blocked shots, missed headers, and yellow cards for fouls.

A 29-year-old footballer, previously with the Sky Blues (relegated from League One last season after 37 appearances), has joined Colchester United ("the U's") and may debut in their EFL Cup first-round match against Championship side Aston Villa on Wednesday. Reid, who has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, joins Colchester following their 3-1 opening-day loss to Accrington on Saturday.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in a March attack outside the Houses of Parliament heightened calls for a permanent **UK Police Memorial** at the **National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire**, honoring over **1,400 officers and staff** killed on duty over **250 years**. The **£4m project**, with **£1m pledged by the government** and a **£1.5m public appeal**, will feature a **brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts** bearing fallen officers’ names, given to their families as personal keepsakes. **Sir Hugh Orde** of the UK Police Memorial Trust emphasized the need for a national tribute to recognize policing’s vital role and the **sacrifice of those who died in service**, while **Home Secretary Amber Rudd** called it a "lasting tribute" to their courage. Completion is expected by **2019**.

Manchester United maintain a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League with eight games remaining after a 1-0 victory over Sunderland, marking 25 wins in their first 30 matches. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team’s focus on upcoming fixtures, particularly the derby against Manchester City, where they hold a 15-point advantage, while chasing Chelsea’s 2005 record of 95 points. United have earned 50 of 54 possible points in their last 18 league games. Ferguson noted injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea (briefly knocked out) during the Sunderland match, prompting likely changes for the FA Cup replay against Chelsea, with Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and Rio Ferdinand among potential returnees. Rooney, Welbeck, and Cleverley were rested due to fatigue from England duty. Ferguson praised his side’s strong first-half performance and resilient defending, acknowledging Sunderland’s determined challenge in the second half.

Google’s chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated that the company complied with all legal tax obligations in the UK, paying £10m in corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, and argued that any changes to tax payments should come from government reforms rather than corporate discretion. He emphasized that taxes are mandatory under current laws and that Google would adjust payments if tax rules changed, framing the issue as a political decision for the UK. Critics, including Margaret Hodge of the Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new oversight committee to scrutinize multinational firms’ tax arrangements, potentially bypassing confidentiality rules. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland to minimize UK tax liabilities, has faced criticism for such practices, while EU leaders agreed to combat tax avoidance via automatic information sharing between tax authorities. Schmidt advocated for taxing corporations where economic activity and risk-taking occur—not where products are consumed—and called for international tax reform, urging politicians to clarify and defend tax laws rather than leaving companies to interpret them.

NHS Improvement, the regulator, is pushing for faster progress in reducing the NHS’s £3.6bn annual agency staff bill, targeting a £1bn cut by the end of the financial year after falling behind schedule. A cap introduced in October—limiting agency pay to 55% above standard shift rates for all staff except senior managers—has saved £600m so far, aiming to curb both costs and reliance on temporary workers, who are more expensive due to agency fees and employer contributions. While progress is deemed "promising," NHS trusts remain 10% short of their targets, and it’s unclear if reduced agency spending has shifted to other pay areas like overtime or in-house "bank" staff. To improve transparency, NHS Improvement will publish league tables ranking trusts by agency spending and collect data on the top 20 highest-earning agency workers per trust, amid concerns over excessive pay, including cases where hospitals were quoted double the capped rates (e.g., £130/hour for a surgeon instead of £76, or £70/hour for a junior doctor instead of £35). Chief executive Jim Mackey emphasized the unsustainable cost, stating the NHS "simply doesn’t have the money" to continue such spending.

The **Longford Town Centre**, once a symbol of Ireland’s Celtic Tiger boom, now reflects the economic downturn, though local traders like **Matt O’Brien**—who runs a family clothing shop—report gradual recovery after years of decline (30% down from peak levels), aided by diversification into childrenswear and dress hire. Critics, including **Fianna Fáil’s Robert Troy**, argue the government’s **€500m water meter investment** should instead fund broadband, citing neglect by the **IDA**, which hasn’t brought foreign investment to Longford in over four years. The government counters by highlighting **Center Parcs’ planned €200m tourism development** in Ballymahon, set to create 1,000 jobs by 2019 (pending planning approval), with **Fine Gael’s James Bannon** promoting the midlands’ natural assets like the Shannon and Royal Canal. However, traders urge further support, such as **free parking** to attract customers, signaling that while **economic recovery is underway**, more action is needed to fully revitalize the region.

The tournament features eight teams competing in a round-robin format, each playing twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs, culminating in the final on **29 May** at the same venue. Key performers include **Warner (294 runs, 12 sixes)**, **Kohli (267 runs, 8 sixes)**, and **De Villiers (249 runs, 12 sixes)**, while **De Kock (108)** holds the highest individual score, and **McClenaghan (9 wickets)** leads the bowling charts. Four England-affiliated players—**Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad)**, **Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians)**, **Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils)**, and **Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)**—are participating. Matches run from **25 April to 29 May**, with most games at **15:30 BST** (some at **10:30 BST**), followed by play-offs: **Qualifier 1 (24 May)**, **Eliminator (25 May)**, **Qualifier 2 (27 May)**, and the **Final (29 May)**.

A 2013 study by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs revealed a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bag usage, exacerbating environmental issues as many are non-recyclable and discarded, often ending up in landfills or rivers. To combat this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, aiming to promote reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have already reduced bag consumption, and campaigners expect the English measure to further decrease waste and benefit the environment.

Severe winds caused significant disruption across Wales on Friday, including structural damage like part of a school roof being torn off in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, and power cuts affecting hundreds of homes. A yellow wind warning was in effect until midnight, coinciding with heavy festive travel, leading to train delays, speed restrictions on major bridges (A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge), and lane closures. The highest gusts were recorded at Mona, Anglesey, prompting Irish Ferries to cancel six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, redirecting passengers to cruise ferries, while Arriva Trains Wales issued delays for routes between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to high winds, though restrictions eased by Friday evening. However, ongoing blustery conditions forced the postponement of Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed enthusiasm for an upcoming film, hinting at a fresh take on his role without revealing details, while confirming a reunion with *Creed* director Ryan Coogler. He praised the opportunity to collaborate again with Coogler and anticipation for working with Lupita Nyong’o—an Oscar winner for *12 Years a Slave*—and Chadwick Boseman, then starring as Black Panther in *Captain America: Civil War*. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the 2015 *Fantastic Four* reboot, while Nyong’o voiced Maz Kanata in *Star Wars: The Force Awakens*. The film, *Black Panther*, was set for a February 2018 release.

The **Alexandra Palace theatre**, founded in 1875 and long unused despite retaining much of its original decor and stage machinery, is set to be restored as part of a broader **£26.6m east wing renovation project** to transform the site into a cultural hub featuring theatrical performances, cinema, comedy, and live music. The **BBC studios** within the Palace will also be repaired, while the **glazed east court** will become a public and exhibition space. Funding includes **£18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF)** and **£6.8m from Haringey Council**, with the **Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust** tasked with raising the final **£1m by summer 2017**. If successful, the theatre aims to **reopen in 2018**, reviving its original purpose of hosting opera, plays, musicals, and early cinema screenings.

James Milner, the 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned **61 senior caps for England** after debuting in **2009**, featuring in **two World Cups and two European Championships** but playing only **three minutes at Euro 2016**. He announced his international retirement citing **"common sense"** while wishing success to manager **Sam Allardyce**, the team, and fans. Milner also holds the record for **most England Under-21 caps (46)**, debuting in **2004**, and scored his **only senior international goal** in a **5-0 win over Moldova** during the **2014 World Cup qualifiers**.

A fire destroyed Marcy Smith’s home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, after she accidentally ignited rubbish in the wood stove—a routine action she had done many times before—while the fire alarm failed to activate. Her son David, who was awake during a FaceTime call with his father, spotted the flames and woke the family just in time for them to escape, though their dog and cats perished. The fire spread rapidly, engulfing the kitchen as they fled in only their pyjamas. The community has since supported the family with donations of clothing, shoes, and a bike for David, whom Marcy credits with saving their lives, praising his quick actions despite his young age.

West Ham United has reportedly attracted a potential £200 million takeover bid from an energy drinks giant, following years of ownership by David Sullivan and David Gold, who acquired a majority stake in 2010 for £105 million and now control over 85% of the club. The club has also been linked to takeover interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since relocating to the London Stadium in August. While Sullivan previously indicated a minority stake could be sold to reduce debt, he and Gold have stated their long-term intention to pass ownership to their children.

The passage describes the **2015 MTV Movie Awards**, a fan-voted ceremony in Los Angeles distinct from formal awards like the Oscars, featuring lighthearted categories such as *best kiss* (won by Zac Efron) and *best shirtless performance*. The night’s top winner was *The Fault in Our Stars*, securing *best movie*, with Shailene Woodley earning *best female performance*, the *Trailblazer Award*, and *best kiss* (with Ansel Elgort), dedicating her emotional speech to author John Green. Other winners included Bradley Cooper (*best male performance* for *American Sniper*), Channing Tatum (*best comedic performance* for *22 Jump Street*), Meryl Streep (*best villain* in *Into the Woods*), and Kevin Hart (*comedic genius award*), who highlighted his family’s influence. Robert Downey Jr. received the *Generation Award*, presented by his *Avengers* co-stars in a dramatic onstage moment. The event also served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters, showcasing clips from *Pitch Perfect 2*, *Trainwreck*, and *Avengers: Age of Ultron*.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned by Aberdeen ("the Dons") to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season, adding to his four goals in 89 appearances for Aberdeen since his 2012 debut. St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised the signing as a "brilliant acquisition," highlighting Smith’s maturity and attacking versatility, admitting surprise at securing him from Dundee United. St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, face Falkirk at home on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has announced that warmer weather now allows its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, aiming to fill about **145 potholes daily over the next four months**. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to fix **drainage systems damaged by heavy rain** and **clear debris from gutters** to address weather-related infrastructure issues.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on EnQuest’s Thistle platform, 125 miles northeast of Shetland, during pipework removal. The workers, who lacked proper protective equipment (PPE), were informed mid-task that radiation had been detected the previous night, halting operations. Though EnQuest stated the exposure was below reportable thresholds (under 1% of the HSE’s limit) and claimed existing safety measures were in place, Innes alleged a breach of duty of care, citing ongoing cancer fears, unresolved blood tests, and difficulty finding further work after raising concerns. EnQuest reported the incident to the HSE despite it not being mandatory under RIDDOR and implemented additional precautionary measures post-investigation. Wood Group emphasized employee safety, conducted medical assessments, and reinforced procedures, while the Unite union criticized the lack of transparency. The HSE confirmed no formal investigation was launched, as the incident was neither reportable nor independently flagged by staff.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) acquired a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer *Art of the Past*, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece. The sculpture is believed to have been looted from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, with allegations surfacing during a 2012 trafficking case against the firm. Following discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and India’s Archaeological Survey of India (ASI)—which formally requested its return in May—ACM decided to repatriate the artwork, citing the dealer’s confession of handling looted items despite no conclusive proof of theft. The sculpture was one of 30 objects purchased from the dealer, though the others are not suspected of being stolen; the ASI was permitted to inspect them. ACM plans to pursue legal action for compensation due to the fraudulent transaction.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck **15.5km deep**, **35km north of Lucca** in Italy’s **Garfagnana region** at **15:48 local time (14:48 GMT)**, with tremors felt as far as **Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena**. While **no injuries or major damage were immediately reported**, aftershocks occurred, **phone lines and power were disrupted in Garfagnana**, and **schools nearby were evacuated** as a precaution. The quake was described as **"medium-strong" and "fairly shallow"** by the **National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV)**, fitting the region’s seismic patterns. Italy remains earthquake-prone, with recent deadly quakes including a **magnitude-6 tremor in May 2012 (20+ deaths)** and the **2009 L’Aquila disaster (300 deaths)**, where **six scientists and an ex-official were later convicted of manslaughter** for downplaying risks before the quake, leading many to stay indoors and perish.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, initially doubted whether South Yorkshire’s climate was suitable for growing fruit but has now achieved success, expressing excitement by saying he was "literally jumping for joy." As of 8 September 2016, the fruit remains attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed *Grand Theft Auto V*’s latest release from **27 January to 24 March**, citing the need for additional testing and polish to ensure quality, emphasizing the decision was made in the best interest of the game and fans. As compensation, the long-awaited **online heists** will launch on consoles before the PC version. The PC release will feature enhanced visuals, including **1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution**, and support for **triple monitors**, with newly released screenshots showcasing greater detail. Minimum PC specifications have also been published to help players prepare. Originally launched in **September 2013**, *GTA V* became the **fastest-selling entertainment product ever**, generating **$1bn in three days**.

A 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for *Squint (19)*, a painting depicting a medieval leper squint—holes in church walls allowing "undesirables" to observe services—described by judge Ansel Krut as "quite extraordinary" despite its challenging nature. The artist, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, called the win "very nice indeed" and plans to use the prize money for art supplies. Krut praised the work’s subtle technique and emotional depth, comparing it to a "tone poem" that evokes sympathy through minimalism. The biennial prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig, while Sir Peter Blake, now its patron, won the junior title in 1961.

The offices of pro-government newspapers *Yeni Şafak* and *Yeni Akit*—both supporting President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party—were simultaneously attacked early Thursday by four masked assailants, with gunfire shattering windows at both locations, located 20km apart in Istanbul. No casualties were reported, though firefighters extinguished a blaze at *Yeni Şafak*, and police found spent bullet casings at both scenes, cordoning off the area while hunting for the perpetrators. No group has claimed responsibility, but the incident follows a similar September attack on *Hürriyet* by pro-government protesters over alleged misquoting of Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot’s team—referred to as the Mariners—on a free transfer, effective 1 January, marking Bignot’s first signing for the club. The player, a former Burton athlete, spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he made 23 appearances and scored three goals.

Arsène Wenger, whose Arsenal contract expires in the summer, has been linked to the England manager role but insists he remains focused on his current job, praising interim manager Gareth Southgate—who took over after Sam Allardyce—for his experience and competency, though acknowledging the pressure to prove himself in upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger emphasized that competency matters more than "big names" and expressed support for Southgate’s opportunity. Additionally, Wenger confirmed Arsenal will offer a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, dismissing transfer speculation linking him to Barcelona and Manchester City, and stated that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man reportedly fell from a cherry picker while working at **Fruehauf on Houghton Road** around **13:45 GMT on Thursday**, prompting a joint investigation by **Lincolnshire Police** and the **Health and Safety Executive (HSE)**. The company involved is **fully cooperating** with the ongoing inquiry.

Scottish Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter agreement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight vessels, the *Hellier* and *Hildasay*, where some crew—many non-UK residents—were allegedly paid under £4 per hour by operator Seatruck, which claimed the UK minimum wage did not apply. The change will return services to Serco Northlink next month, ending Seatruck’s contract, with Serco previously offering to cover pay gaps retroactively. Yousaf confirmed all crew will now receive at least the minimum wage, pending final financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink holds a £243m, six-year contract (awarded in 2012) to run subsidised ferry and cargo routes to Scotland’s Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on **14 May**, six days after an incident at **Rockley Park in Poole** on **7 May**, where he was involved in a confrontation with **Jamie Mitchell, 35**, his mother **Samantha Mitchell’s (57)** partner of several years. The couple had been in a "down phase" in their relationship when Jamie visited his mother at the park, later joining her and Dickie at the holiday park bar, where he consumed excessive alcohol. A fight broke out between the two men outside, requiring public intervention, and Jamie initially pleaded guilty to **common assault**. Both Jamie and Samantha later admitted **attempting to pervert the course of justice** by falsely claiming Dickie had pushed Samantha first, before Jamie revised his statement, calling the incident a **"tragic accident"** caused while trying to separate the couple. Jamie showed visible emotion after the jury’s verdict, and **sentencing for both is set for 6 February**.

Rod Temperton, the reclusive British songwriter nicknamed *The Invisible Man*, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known for penning iconic hits like *Thriller*, *Rock With You*, and *Off the Wall* for Michael Jackson, as well as *Boogie Nights* for his band Heatwave, Temperton’s work shaped disco and pop music. Born in Cleethorpes, he credited his songwriting roots to childhood radio exposure and later joined Heatwave in the 1970s after working in a frozen food factory. His collaboration with Quincy Jones led to Jackson’s breakthrough albums *Off the Wall* and *Thriller*—the latter becoming the best-selling US album ever (32 million copies). Temperton also wrote for artists like Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and Chaka Khan, earning a Grammy (1990) and two Oscar nominations (1986). Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson, praising his genius. A private funeral was held, with his family requesting privacy.

A team including Swansea University’s Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott, alongside researchers from Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities, discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs—large geometrical earthworks up to 2,000 years old—in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, revealed by modern deforestation after centuries hidden under bamboo rainforest. The purpose of these non-defensive, non-residential sites remains unclear, but they may have served as sporadic ritual gathering places, though unlike Maya pyramids or Stonehenge, they were likely obscured by tall vegetation, as Loader’s analysis of phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes suggests. The findings challenge the notion of pre-European Amazonian forests as pristine, revealing 6,000 years of human-cultivated plant diversity, where Indigenous peoples selectively fostered economically valuable trees like palms—creating a "prehistoric supermarket"—rather than clearing large forest areas. Some of Acre’s current biodiversity may still reflect these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian ranked a career-high 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Fresh off winning the Japan Open, Kyrgios admitted to feeling fatigued, attributing his subdued demeanor to exhaustion from travel—including a long commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium—and poor sleep, stating he just wanted to "get the job done." He also recalled his controversial $1,500 fine at the same tournament last year for calling it a "circus" during a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists and charities are advocating for the expansion of the HPV vaccine in Wales to include boys, citing its potential to prevent rising head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger, non-smoking men (average age 55), with 75% of cases in males. Currently, girls aged 12–13 receive the vaccine primarily to prevent cervical cancer, with 85% coverage in Wales since the 2008 school program. Organizations like Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University’s HPV team are urging the Welsh government to act proactively, arguing that HPV causes 5% of global cancers and that vaccinating boys could significantly reduce cases. However, the government states it will wait for guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes to the program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Calder High School, battled a rare blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, since his diagnosis in August. Despite his illness, he maintained a positive outlook, documenting his journey on the *Jak’s Journey* Facebook page, which gained over 28,000 followers. A passionate Rangers FC fan, he met former players like Neil Alexander and Nacho Novo, and his story inspired many. Though severely unwell, he briefly attended a prom held in his honor, where he received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. In January, doctors confirmed his cancer had spread, halting further treatment, but Jak remained determined to make the most of his time, thanking medical staff and encouraging donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Before his death, he enjoyed final experiences like visiting the Kelpies, a romantic meal with his girlfriend, and rides in a supercar and quad bike. His mother announced his passing on Facebook, expressing profound grief and pride, while a charity football match was planned to raise further funds in his memory.

Egypt secured a late 1-0 victory over Uganda in a tightly contested Africa Cup of Nations match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute after a precise assist from Mohamed Salah, breaking Uganda’s resilient defense. Uganda had a goal by Joseph Ochaya ruled out for offside in the 52nd minute and struggled to create clear chances despite a strong defensive display, including key interventions from goalkeeper Denis Onyango. The win keeps Egypt in contention for top spot in Group D ahead of their clash with Ghana, who had already advanced to the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali. Uganda, eliminated from their first tournament since 1978, will face Mali in their final group game, while Mali’s qualification hinges on a two-goal Ghana victory over Egypt. The match was marked by a deteriorating pitch, few clear opportunities, and multiple offsides, with Egypt dominating possession but failing to convert until El Said’s late strike.

Lancashire County Council has selected the former **Glenburn Sports College** (closed in August) and the unused **Skelmersdale College Westbank campus** (owned by Newcastle College) as preferred sites for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, following a **Network Rail comparative study** that also considered a location near the Concourse shopping centre. The town, designated a **new town in 1961**, has lacked a passenger station since **1956** and remains one of the largest in northwest England without one. Under the council’s plans—developed with **Merseytravel** and **West Lancashire Borough Council**—Skelmersdale could receive **two direct trains per hour to Liverpool**. Councillor **John Fillis** highlighted the chosen site’s advantages, including **future expansion potential, strong highway access, and connectivity** to the town and surrounding area, calling it an **"exciting step forward"**. The council will now begin **acquiring the necessary land** to advance the project.

A search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning uncovered an elaborate cannabis grow house, with police confirming the discovery of plants inside. Authorities arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene in connection with the operation.

A 28-year-old woman of German-Kurdish origin was discovered severely injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late Sunday after being dragged by the neck through multiple streets, requiring emergency surgery and transfer to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, also a German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in to authorities, though the motive for the attack remains unclear, according to Hannover prosecutors. Police have secured the crime scene and are appealing for witnesses to assist the investigation.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzed 4,600 Australian workers and found that women are just as likely as men to request pay raises but are 25% less likely to receive them when comparing like-for-like full-time or part-time roles. The research debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking due to fear of upsetting bosses or conforming to stereotypes, while accounting for factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. Based on 2013–14 Australian workplace data—the only systematic record of pay rise requests—the study suggested potential discrimination, though younger workers under 40 showed no gender gap in asking or receiving raises, hinting at shifting negotiation behaviors. Co-author Andrew Oswald acknowledged surprise at the findings, dismissing anecdotal claims about women’s reluctance, while Dr. Amanda Goodall noted younger women may be negotiating more effectively, offering hope for future progress.

Oxford City Council has spent funds primarily on investigating potential burial sites but has yet to find a suitable location, with two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley projected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council acknowledges ongoing efforts but cites a lack of available land, with identified sites dismissed due to issues like size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, or legal restrictions. Once the existing cemeteries are full, options will be limited to reopening family plots, using reserved spaces, or interring ashes, as the last expansion of burial space occurred in 1932. Council member Linda Smith emphasized the long-standing challenge of securing new sites, comparing it to the scarcity of land for housing.

The **Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt)**, held in **Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July**, will introduce an **augmented reality app** allowing visitors to access online content—such as **videos and band interviews**—by scanning signs and posters on-site via phones or tablets. Featured artists include **The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean**. Festival director **Caroline Maclennan** highlights that the app enhances the on-site experience while also enabling **global audiences to engage remotely**, with real-time updates on performances, ticket purchases, and festival highlights before and during the event.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse **Many Clouds** collapsed and died after winning the **Cotswold Chase** at Cheltenham, defeating **Thistlecrack** in a close finish, with the **British Horseracing Authority (BHA)** confirming the cause as a **"severe pulmonary haemorrhage"**—a rare but sudden condition that can affect otherwise healthy horses across equestrian disciplines. Though **Many Clouds** had previously exhibited **post-race ataxia** (overheating and wobbling), he showed no such symptoms during Saturday’s race and had no **significant underlying health issues**, per veterinary reports. A past winner of the **2015 Gold Cup trial** and **2014 Hennessy Gold Cup**, he was hailed as the **"horse of a lifetime"** by trainer **Oliver Sherwood**. While his history of overheating raised questions about a potential link to his death, the BHA emphasized the haemorrhage was unrelated and **unpredictable**, reaffirming the sport’s commitment to researching prevention despite its rarity.

A 15-year-old girl met **David Ayrton** (now **Davina**, 34) in a Portsmouth garage in 2004, where Ayrton later raped her while two others slept nearby; the victim recalled the attack clearly despite minimal alcohol consumption. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide in 2023, denied the charge but was remanded into custody ahead of sentencing on **4 March**, with Judge **Ian Pearson** citing risks of self-harm and non-attendance. Due to her legal gender status, she will likely be held in a **male prison in Winchester**, though protocols for her detention have been arranged. Ayrton, who changed her name in **2012**, disclosed the assault to a care home worker in **2014** and testified during trial that she had made no physical or medical transitions. The judge described the case as **"unusual and not easy"** for the jury.

Serbs Novak Djokovic and his partner lost 6-4, 6-4 in doubles to Brazil’s Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares at the Rio Olympics, a day after Djokovic’s singles exit to Argentina’s Juan Martín del Potro.
