The world No. 1, aged 29, had previously suffered a shock third-round Wimbledon loss to American Sam Querrey in July but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. Djokovic holds 12 Grand Slam titles.

The **Carrbridge Chainsaw Carving Competition**, held in the Cairngorms this Saturday, will feature over 20 competitors from **Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US**, all restricted to using **only chainsaws** to sculpt logs into animals and human figures. **Pete Bowsher**, last year’s winner from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the **Claymore Trophy**, awarded to the first-place finisher.

Rhys Webb, the 27-year-old Wales scrum-half, has been sidelined since sustaining a severe foot injury during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy in September but is now nearing a return, targeting a comeback before the Six Nations in February. Currently in a pre-season-like training phase, he aims to accelerate his recovery by a few weeks, with Wales’ opening Six Nations fixture against Ireland on **7 February** serving as a potential return date. Webb, who has 16 Wales caps, recently renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting external offers to remain with his home region, where he debuted in 2007. He emphasized his commitment to playing for Wales, stating that staying with the Ospreys positions him best to achieve that goal, and expressed satisfaction with the renewed deal.

US border agents near Sumas, Washington, intercepted two men carrying backpacks containing 58lb (26kg) of MDMA (ecstasy) being smuggled from Canada to San Francisco on Tuesday morning. One suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately detained after his accomplice—later identified as Canadian Nathan Hall—fired at agents and fled; Hall was arrested in British Columbia the following day, with a fake California driver’s licence found in his backpack. Two additional arrests followed: Kali Henifin, accused of planning to pick up the men at the border, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who allegedly admitted he was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs to San Francisco. The group had monitored police radio chatter and fled upon hearing reports of the shooting. The three US defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges, while authorities noted the area is a known smuggling corridor for drugs and firearms, with such prosecutions being common in the region.

The NSPCC’s **Childline** reported a rise in online abuse cases, counseling over **4,500 children** in the past year—nearly double the **2,400 in 2011-12**—though the actual number affected is believed to be much higher, with victims as young as **seven** describing torment, fear, and humiliation from **cyberbullying**. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline’s president, called the figures a **"wake-up call"**, emphasizing that bullying now extends beyond school via **online persecution**, worsening without intervention. She urged **adults, parents, and schools** to act, as bullying escalates if ignored, and stressed that children must **seek help**. The report coincides with **Anti-Bullying Week**, led by the **Anti-Bullying Alliance**, which collaborates with schools and parents to address the issue. A child’s testimony highlighted the emotional toll, revealing **suicidal taunts** from online peers and parental misunderstanding, while peer advice on coping was also shared.

Israel postponed a vote on approving 492 new settlement homes in East Jerusalem at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s request, likely to avoid escalating tensions with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The move follows Israel’s fury over the US abstention from a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlements as illegal under international law, which Netanyahu claimed the Obama administration helped draft—a charge the US denied. Israel, which rejects the resolution, recalled ambassadors, cut aid to Senegal, and summoned envoys from countries supporting the measure, viewing it as a threat to its claim over East Jerusalem, which Palestinians seek as their future capital. The postponed vote reflects Israel’s effort to mitigate friction with Washington, while Kerry’s speech aims to counter Israeli criticisms of US policy. Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution as a step toward ending the occupation, ahead of a planned French peace conference in January.

In a BBC interview ahead of Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday, Prince William praised her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, highlighting her duty, service, and commitment, while acknowledging criticism of his own royal duties as "work-shy William" but affirming his serious approach to responsibility in due time. The Queen marked her birthday with events including a visit to Windsor’s Royal Mail office—celebrating its 500th anniversary—where she met staff and opened a new bandstand with schoolchildren singing *Happy Birthday*, followed by political tributes from leaders like David Cameron. Ten commemorative stamps were released, featuring four generations of royals (the Queen, Prince Charles, William, and George), alongside others depicting her family and official roles. On her birthday, she and Prince Philip unveiled *The Queen’s Walkway*, a 6.3km trail honoring her record-breaking 63-year reign, and lit a beacon triggering 900+ global beacons, with US President Barack Obama attending a lunch the next day. Critics, including the republican group *Republic*, argued the BBC’s coverage lacked balance, calling it excessive celebration rather than neutral reporting.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 EFL Cup victory over League Two’s Cheltenham Town with first-half goals from Diafra Sakho—his first since November—and Andre Ayew, both finishing into the bottom corner after Sam Byram’s assist. Cheltenham, unchanged from a weekend league loss, created chances through Harry Pell’s volley and Jordon Forster’s header but failed to seriously test West Ham’s goalkeeper Adrian, while the visitors missed further opportunities, including James Collins’ and Byram’s attempts, and saw Angelo Ogbonna’s header cleared off the line. The match marked the sides’ second meeting in this competition (West Ham won 2-1 in 2013), with Cheltenham’s exit ending League Two’s representation in the tournament. West Ham, making seven changes after Premier League defeats, dominated but lacked a larger margin, while Cheltenham’s best moment—a Pell volley across goal—went unconverted by substitute Dan Holman. The game concluded with West Ham advancing comfortably despite late substitutions and minor fouls.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer and father-of-four, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to see his motorcycle while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. The victim’s family opposed jail time, acknowledging it as a momentary lapse, while Werner expressed remorse but could not explain the crash. He had been staying with his family near Bala at the time.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is a British jihadist who traveled to Syria in January 2023, adopting the name *Abu Daigham al-Britani* and joining *Rayat al Tawheed*, an Islamic State-affiliated group known for producing slick propaganda to recruit young British Muslims. Active online but always masked, Khawaja posted videos glorifying combat, including footage of wounded fighters and his own weight-lifting sessions, while also soliciting donations and offering "behind-the-scenes" glimpses of jihadist life. Some of the group’s content depicted gruesome violence, including an image of Khawaja holding a severed head claimed to be a Syrian soldier’s. After over a year in Syria, he attempted to re-enter the UK in June 2023 by faking his death in an online obituary and enlisting his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, to smuggle him back via Bulgaria. Arrested at Dover, Khawaja—deemed one of the most dangerous returning British jihadists—was charged with terrorism offenses, including soliciting murder (later dropped), and held in Belmarsh Prison’s high-risk unit. Authorities emphasize his deliberate concealment of re-entry and radicalized background, though his motives for returning remain unclear. Both Khawaja and Bhatti (who admitted aiding him) face prosecution, with Khawaja potentially receiving a life sentence.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth in their league. He has now joined Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Barnsley’s caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson’s speed and attacking style, stating he will suit the team’s approach. Jackson rejected a contract extension offer from Wrexham to make the move.

Bottles of detergent, believed to be from a lost shipping container, have been washing up at Poldhu Cove and other nearby Cornish beaches like Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion since Sunday. The National Trust and volunteers are clearing them due to risks to wildlife, though most bottles remain sealed, with some reported leaks. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency acknowledged that the *MV Blue Ocean* lost a container of *Vanish* detergent near Land’s End in May but stated there’s no definitive proof linking these bottles to that incident. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed concern over potential harm to marine life, while Cornwall Council and partners are monitoring affected areas. The public is warned to keep children and pets away from the bottles and avoid handling them.

A crash took place on the **A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00**, resulting in **multiple minor injuries** among those involved. The road was **closed**, with diversions routed via the **A897 between Helmsdale and Melvich**, while **Police Scotland confirmed investigations into the incident were still underway**.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, played a key role in Bolton Wanderers' promotion to the Championship last season, making 14 appearances to help the team finish second in League One. Since joining from Charlton in 2014, he has featured in 83 matches across all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite for his strong late-season contributions after being sidelined earlier in the campaign. His contract renewal follows those of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, as Bolton prepares for life in the Championship.

The passage describes a breakdown in cooperation between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the House of Lords over Brexit amendments, particularly regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a deal. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of "conceding everything," while Labour’s Baroness Smith countered that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope." Though the parties had previously collaborated to defeat the government on various issues—including higher education and housing—their alliance fractured when MPs rejected their Brexit amendments, with the Lib Dems pushing for stricter terms and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source dismissed the Lib Dems' stance as "grandstanding" for campaign material, criticizing them for raising expectations despite knowing MPs would back the government, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of enabling a "hard Brexit" by aligning with the Conservatives. Despite past collaborations, tensions linger, with Labour anticipating limited future cooperation, though the Lib Dems expressed openness to working with peers across parties on shared issues.

Defence is a low priority in the UK’s election, ranking outside the top voter concerns like the economy, NHS, and immigration, with politicians avoiding the topic due to public "combat fatigue" from past conflicts. Despite growing global threats—including Islamic extremism, Russian aggression, and failed states—UK defence spending has shrunk, with the Army reduced to 82,000 troops, the Royal Navy down to 19 warships, and the RAF lacking key capabilities like Maritime Patrol Aircraft, forcing reliance on NATO allies. The UK has dropped from the world’s fourth-largest defence spender to sixth, with spending projected to fall below NATO’s 2% GDP target (to 1.7% or even 1.5% by 2020), risking US disapproval and damaged credibility. Major parties offer vague manifesto pledges, with only UKIP and the DUP committing to the 2% target, while the Conservatives, Labour, and Lib Dems plan further cuts or limited increases, leaving the £34bn MoD budget vulnerable. Disputes over Trident renewal—costing £20bn—divide parties: the Conservatives and UKIP back a like-for-like replacement, Labour considers reducing submarines, the Lib Dems propose a "part-time" deterrent, and the SNP/Greens demand scrapping it entirely. New aircraft carriers, set to launch by 2020, may lack sufficient crew and F-35 jets (12 instead of 36), raising fears of a "hollow force" with advanced but underused equipment, undermining the UK’s claim to global military influence.

Barcelona vehemently denied any wrongdoing in Neymar’s 2013 transfer, despite ongoing investigations into alleged financial irregularities, including accusations that the actual cost—£106.8m when factoring in fees, wages, and taxes—far exceeded the initially declared £48.6m. The club made a voluntary tax payment of €13.55m to address potential discrepancies in interpretations of the contracts, though they maintained the original payment complied with fiscal obligations. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation allegations (which he denies), and a Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to continue probing the transfer. While Barcelona insists no tax crime occurred, it remains unclear if the case will be dropped following their payment. On the field, Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for the club this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died in a collision when a Mazda Premacy, driven the wrong way on the motorway by 70-year-old Albert Kenneth Newman (who also died), struck the van he was traveling in near Kegworth, Leicestershire, on 12 October. Luciw’s family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, called for mandatory driving tests for older drivers, arguing that aging affects reaction times and that current self-assessment forms for over-70s are insufficient. Luciw, a delivery driver and father of a baby girl, was described as kind and devoted, with his family emphasizing the tragedy of his lost future. Colleague Andy Harrington, who survived with serious injuries, supported stricter medical checks, stating the crash—where Newman’s car was on the wrong carriageway—was unavoidable and haunts him. The DVLA defended its policy, citing no evidence that older drivers pose greater risks, while Age UK stressed the importance of driving for older adults’ independence. The incident reignited debates over aging drivers’ licensing, with families urging systemic changes to prevent similar tragedies.

Women suffering severe side effects from transvaginal mesh implants—used to treat incontinence—have raised safety concerns, leading to protests over a perceived "watered-down" review report, which prompted two patient representatives to resign. Independent expert **Alison Britton**, a healthcare law professor, will now assess the review’s process and identify lessons for future oversight. The report concluded that mesh procedures **should not be routinely offered** for pelvic organ prolapse, instead recommending **informed patient choice** among treatment options and **mandatory reporting of adverse events**. Despite campaigner demands for a total ban, Health Secretary **Shona Robison** confirmed implementation of the recommendations but noted the Scottish government lacks authority to ban the procedure, as regulatory power rests with the UK’s **Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)**. The review’s chair, **Tracey Gillies**, apologized for failing to unite the panel, calling her task "almost mission impossible" amid deep divisions, while public gallery outbursts from affected women—including cries of "shame on you"—highlighted their frustration. Earlier resignations by **Olive McIlroy** and **Elaine Holmes**, who cited removed content and a lack of consensus, followed a consultant’s exit over draft concerns. Over **20,000 Scottish women** have received mesh implants in 20 years, with **400+ pursuing legal action** against health boards and manufacturers due to debilitating complications.

Laura Muir, 23, shattered Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old British 5,000m record by 14 seconds at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena, clocking **14:49.12** in a mixed 3K/5K race where she was the sole 5K finisher. McColgan initially questioned whether the race met UK Athletics’ record criteria—citing concerns over its competitive nature, lack of opponents, and potential drug-testing requirements—but British Athletics confirmed the time would likely be ratified, as doping control isn’t mandatory if none was conducted at the event. McColgan praised Muir’s performance, noting her **3:55 1,500m pedigree** suggests she could eventually dip to **14:30**, a world-class time, though she believes Muir must refine her race tactics to win global medals. Comparing it to her own solo record run in 1991—where she lapped a young Paula Radcliffe—McColgan celebrated Muir’s achievement as a fellow Scot, highlighting her world-class potential. Muir, who also holds the British 1,500m record and reached the **Rio 2016 Olympic final**, continues to demonstrate dominance in middle- and long-distance events.

Germany’s **Jung won gold** in equestrian aboard *Sam*, a last-minute replacement after *Fischertakinou* fell ill in July, while France’s **Astier Nicolas** claimed silver and American **Phillip Dutton** took bronze. Britain’s **William Fox-Pitt**, 47, competing just 10 months after a **coma-inducing fall**, finished **12th** despite a flawless final show-jumping round; his medal hopes were dashed by **time penalties in cross-country**, dropping him from first after dressage to 21st. Ireland’s **Jonty Evans** placed **ninth** on *Cooley Rorkes Drift*.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in a tense 2-hour, 39-minute match to reach the Wimbledon last 16 for the 11th time, setting up a fourth-round clash with Benoit Paire. After dominating early, Murray faced a late resurgence from Fognini—who had five set points to force a fifth set—before winning five straight games to close it out under fading light, avoiding a roof delay or potential Saturday return. Fognini, who had beaten Murray in Rome, struggled with consistency and an ankle injury, while Murray battled movement issues but relied on resilience, saving multiple set points in a dramatic fourth-set comeback. Meanwhile, Johanna Konta advanced to the second week for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. Murray acknowledged the match’s ups and downs but expressed relief at progressing, noting he’ll use the two-day break to refine his form ahead of Monday’s match.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at **Joe’s Bar in Dungiven** at **06:00 BST on 6 October 2014**, with police arriving shortly after to find patrons still present and till receipts confirming alcohol was served until **04:49 BST**, outside legal hours. The court ordered the bar’s **three-month closure**, while **Colleen O’Neill (43)**, the license holder, was charged with **two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours** and fined **£3,000**, with the judge criticizing her **"appalling record"** and lamenting the lack of power to impose custody. **James Thomas (44)**, of the same address, faced **one count of the same offense** and was fined **£1,000**. The defense admitted the premises were **poorly managed**, operating **well into the morning**, with the judge calling it **"as bad a case as I have come across."**

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionist Party’s manifesto titled *Real Partnership*, emphasized cooperation over domination, framing the election as a referendum on the mishandled Renewable Heat Incentive scandal while criticizing the DUP and Sinn Féin’s decade-long leadership as marked by "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption." He stood by his controversial remark preferring a post-election partnership with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, dismissing criticism—including from senior colleague Danny Kennedy—as reaffirming rather than disappointing, and insisted he would not retract his statements. Nesbitt claimed doorstep campaigning in unionist areas showed strong support for his stance, while acknowledging internal party differences on vote transfers. The manifesto prioritizes reducing NHS waiting lists, boosting PSNI numbers to 7,500, completing the York Street interchange, protecting LGBT rights, and mitigating Brexit’s negative impacts, alongside a *Cleaning Up Stormont* pledge to address governance failures. Despite media focus on his SDLP comments, Nesbitt redirected attention to the £85,000 daily cost of the RHI scheme and the perceived futility of expecting political reform from entrenched parties.

Northern Ireland’s Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced plans to introduce a motion in the assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, aligning with similar measures in England and Wales under "Turing’s Law." The proposal includes automatic posthumous pardons and allows living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, mirroring the UK’s recent reforms. Sugden confirmed executive approval for a legislative consent motion to expedite equal treatment for those affected, emphasizing the move as a chance to rectify past injustices more swiftly than through a full assembly bill. The motion will soon be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish runner from Kinross, set a new Scottish 1500m record with a time of **4:19.12**, finishing second behind Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon, surpassing Yvonne Murray’s 1994 record (4:22.60) and placing her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record and finished fifth in the 2015 World Championships, called the achievement meaningful and expressed excitement at nearly matching Kipyegon’s pace. She aims to qualify for the **Rio Olympics** at the British trials in Birmingham (24–26 June) after starting her season with an 800m win in France. Balancing training with her **veterinary studies** (now in her fourth year), Muir credited strong preparation for her performance and will next race in a **1500m event in Stockholm**. Yvonne Murray congratulated her via her husband’s Facebook post.
I cannot do it. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that while suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, the Russian state was likely behind the 2006 poisoning in London, citing "reasons aplenty" for targeting him. Litvinenko, a former FSB officer who defected to the UK in 2000 and accused the agency of corruption and political murders, died after ingesting polonium-210-laced tea during a meeting with the two men, with Horwell stating the radioactive substance’s use pointed to state involvement—though not necessarily direct orders from President Putin. Litvinenko had previously survived an earlier poisoning attempt and publicly criticized Putin, which Horwell suggested may have been viewed as treachery. The suspects left a "trail of polonium" across London, posing unknown long-term radiation risks to the public, and lacked credible explanations for the scientific evidence against them. Extradition efforts failed, making a trial unlikely, while Kovtun’s refusal to testify was criticized by inquiry chairman Sir Robert Owen.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia’s ongoing captain for the one-day and Twenty20 teams, replacing the injured Aaron Finch in the latter format, with David Warner, 28, named as his vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and leadership, citing his prior experience captaining in three Tests against India while Michael Clarke recovered from injuries. Clarke, 34, retired after Australia lost the Ashes 3-1 to England, prompting Smith’s promotion as his successor. Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, and will lead alongside Warner—now seen as a matured senior figure—in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting 20 August.

Tim Farron, the newly elected Liberal Democrat leader, repeatedly avoided directly answering whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners" while emphasizing his strong support for LGBT+ rights. He pledged to prioritize defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender people, citing the "spousal veto" as a barrier to their equality. Farron also explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill—intended to combat discrimination against gay people—by claiming concerns over "protection of individual liberties," though he did not specify them, while affirming his commitment to equal legal access regardless of sexuality.

The Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, closed in 2015 with 450 job losses, will be repurposed by **Accord Healthcare** for pharmaceutical production, potentially rehiring former Sanofi employees. Accord, a global pharmaceutical firm supplying over **130 products to 60 countries**, expects the investment to have an **"extremely positive"** local impact. **Newcastle City Council Leader Nick Forbes** praised the move as a boost for the **North East’s science and healthcare sector**, highlighting the **highly skilled jobs and long-term economic benefits** it brings.

Richard Ellis is departing the local council at the end of his contract this Friday, having served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive’s office) and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services) are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn criticized the departures as evidence of the council’s failure to retain senior staff, predicting more exits in the near future. Council chief executive Angela Scott acknowledged the trio’s "dedication and professionalism."

Four militants armed with guns and grenades stormed Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital after detonating explosives at the gate, killing and wounding over 50 people, including staff and patients. Afghan commandos killed all attackers after a six-hour siege, with IS claiming responsibility while the Taliban denied involvement. The assault—beginning at 09:00 local time—marked a shift in IS tactics, as it was their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital, previously targeting Shia civilians and institutions like the Supreme Court. Witnesses described attackers in white coats firing indiscriminately, and officials noted IS may be escalating high-profile attacks to compensate for failed territorial expansion in eastern Afghanistan. The government vowed retaliation, though IS retains control in some mountainous areas, while recent attacks—including a 2016 suicide bombing killing 80—highlight its growing presence since declaring its "Khorasan Province" in 2015. The Taliban, meanwhile, continues its own offensive, killing 16 in Kabul the prior week.

Guy Martin, an English rider, crashed during this year’s TT, while his Honda Fireblade faced persistent mechanical issues, leading him to announce he was quitting road racing—though he later clarified on Facebook that he was only stepping back from racing Hondas this year, not road racing entirely. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will miss the Ulster Grand Prix, admitting the TT was a "bloody disaster" where he felt reduced to a test rider. Following further testing at Cadwell, Martin concluded the bike wouldn’t be competitive at the Ulster GP, and though the team withdrew him without notification, he accepted the decision. He expressed no "unfinished business" and now aims to focus on racing classic and unconventional bikes instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a landmark victory in Nigeria’s gubernatorial elections, winning 19 of 28 governor posts, marking the Peoples Democratic Party’s (PDP) worst defeat since 1999 and reinforcing its decline after losing the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP, once dominant, retained only eight governorships—mostly in the south-east and oil-rich Niger Delta—while losing key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Boko Haram-affected Adamawa, though it held Rivers State, Nigeria’s oil hub. The APC’s gains reshaped Nigeria’s political map, controlling the north and Lagos (the commercial hub) but failing to win any of the five oil-producing states, posing a potential challenge for Buhari’s administration amid militant threats to oil revenue. Elections in Taraba remain outstanding, while Imo’s result was declared inconclusive due to spoiled ballots; violence, ethnic tensions, and power struggles marred some polls, though overall they were more peaceful than past elections. The PDP’s 16-year rule was undermined by corruption allegations, defections to the APC, and perceived failures in addressing the Boko Haram insurgency, prompting voter demand for change, while the APC’s control of Lagos—unprecedented for a ruling president’s party—signals a major shift in Nigeria’s political landscape.

The environmental lobby group Mighty accused Singapore-based agricultural trader **Olam** and its majority stakeholder, **Temasek** (Singapore’s state-owned investment fund), of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices linked to Indonesia’s annual haze crisis, caused by slash-and-burn land clearance for plantations. Olam, which sources **99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers** (constituting **<1% of the global market**), denied the allegations, citing a **"no burn-no peat-no deforestation"** policy and claiming its **14 suppliers** comply with strict sustainability standards, though verification will take years. Mighty’s report alleged Olam created a **"secretive market for rogue palm oil"** by obscuring supplier identities—only disclosed after pressure—and suggested Temasek’s investment indirectly finances environmentally harmful practices. Temasek rejected involvement, stating it does not direct Olam’s operations but supports no-burn policies. The report also criticized Olam’s **Gabon operations**, accusing it of **deforestation for monoculture plantations**; Olam defended its **public-private partnerships** as transparent and responsible. The broader palm oil industry, projected to reach **$88bn by 2022**, faces persistent criticism for **deforestation, labor abuses, and weak supplier oversight**, with NGOs and firms clashing over accountability, while governments often prioritize economic benefits over environmental enforcement.

A new law introduced on 27 August 2016 permitted dogs to dine at restaurants in outdoor areas, prompting one establishment to offer "puppy platters" specifically for canine customers. The change allowed dogs to eat alongside their owners as long as they remained outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is struggling with a knee issue and remains doubtful after appearing only as a substitute in the last two matches, while Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) may return following his absence in the recent 1-1 draw with Huddersfield. Meanwhile, midfielder Jacob Butterfield is pushing for a starting spot after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute in the same game.

Pakistan lifted its ban on YouTube after Google introduced a Pakistan-specific version, allowing the government to request the removal of "offending material" through an online process, though YouTube stated such requests would not be automatically granted and would undergo review under its community guidelines. The ban, imposed by Pakistan’s Supreme Court in 2012 following the upload of the controversial film *Innocence of Muslims*—which sparked deadly protests—was deemed no longer necessary by the telecoms regulator, the PTA, which directed ISPs to restore access. While many young Pakistanis celebrated the move, activists demanded transparency over the government’s agreement with Google, which maintains that removal requests will be documented in its Transparency Report. Blasphemy remains a punishable offense in Pakistan, though no executions have been carried out. Google also recently launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, previously stepped down during the 2015 election due to sharing nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter, though his spokesman now argues no conflict of interest exists for the upcoming vote since Blatter is no longer incumbent. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian FA, demands Scala’s withdrawal by Thursday, citing FIFA’s Electoral Regulations (Article 7.4) on conflicts of interest, and threatens legal action via the Court of Arbitration for Sport if he refuses. Bility, barred from running himself in November, has endorsed Prince Ali and urges African support for him. The election on **26 February** in Zurich will choose Blatter’s successor among five candidates: Gianni Infantino (Swiss-Italian), Prince Ali (Jordan), Jerome Champagne (France), Sheikh Salman (Bahrain), and Tokyo Sexwale (South Africa), with FIFA’s 209 members casting votes amid ongoing concerns over the process’s integrity following past controversies.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in a workplace incident at Harford Attachments, a digger bucket manufacturer in Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were recovered on Tuesday, and a forensic investigation revealed a likely **flashover explosion** caused by a buildup of toxic fumes ignited by an unknown source, creating a fireball effect. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham noted "significant progress" in forensic analysis and witness statements, while the **Health and Safety Executive** is conducting its own inquiry with inspectors and electrical safety experts to gather evidence.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for complaints over a controversial penalty awarded to Equatorial Guinea in their 2015 quarter-final loss, which they argued was mishandled by referee Rajindraparsad Seechurn—though they denied allegations of corruption. Morocco, initially banned from the 2017 qualifiers for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, had their suspension overturned by Cas, with their fine reduced from $1m to $50,000. Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa downplayed the ban’s impact, emphasizing a positive future, while Tunisia’s FTF vice-president Maher Snoussi confirmed reconciliation with Caf after mediation by president Issa Hayatou. Both nations now prepare for the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia in Group A (vs. Togo, Liberia, Djibouti) and Morocco in Group F (vs. Cape Verde, Libya, Sao Tome), as Tunisia eyes a record 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

A mass fracas erupted in the 95th minute of Chelsea’s 3-1 win over Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, leading to red cards for City’s Sergio Agüero and Fernandinho, though Chelsea’s Cesc Fàbregas faced no further action. Agüero, 28, received a four-match ban for violent conduct—his second dismissal of the season—after a high, late challenge on Chelsea’s David Luiz, while Fernandinho was given a three-match ban for his role in the subsequent scuffle with Fàbregas. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team’s involvement, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales a rhai ardaloedd eraill yn y DU sydd â chyfraddau goresgyn canser o’r gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig, ac mae cynllun peilot newydd yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn ceisio datrys y broblem drwy ganolbwyntio ar gleifion â chanser amheus ond heb arwyddion clir. Os yw’r peilot chwe mis yn llwyddiannus, bydd byrddau iechyd eraill yn ei fabwysiadu yn y dyfodol.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the four-match series after their first-Test loss, thanks to a commanding performance led by Joe Root, who scored 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, earning him the *man of the match* award. Root, promoted to number three, also contributed with four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook scored 105 and 76 not out, praising Root’s disciplined and flawless play. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, setting up their second-largest run win over Pakistan, as Pakistan collapsed for 198 and 234, struggling with poor shot selection and low confidence. Analysts like Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott highlighted England’s clinical batting, bowling discipline, and Pakistan’s broken morale, though Vaughan cautioned the series could still be tightly contested. Pakistan’s captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitted disappointment, citing missed opportunities in the first innings and vowed a stronger comeback before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August, with only Misbah and Asad Shafiq managing half-centuries in the series so far.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley joining his backroom team, while Robin McBryde takes interim head coach duties for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed pride in representing Wales abroad and enthusiasm for the role, with the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) set to appoint additional assistant coaches for the summer tour. WRU CEO Martyn Phillips noted that discussions for the full management team are nearly finalized, while WRU chairman Gareth Davies highlighted the tour as a key development opportunity for Welsh coaches, emphasizing the long-term benefits for Welsh rugby. Davies also underscored how past Lions experiences have mentally stimulated and inspired players and coaches, with the New Zealand tour expected to provide the ultimate test.

Hull City secured their first league win since August, ending a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 comeback victory over Southampton despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries. Charlie Austin’s early penalty put Southampton ahead, but Hull transformed the game in the second half with Robert Snodgrass scoring (61') and assisting Michael Dawson’s header (63') within two minutes. Southampton pushed for an equalizer, but David Marshall’s crucial saves—including a late goalline clearance by Sam Clucas—preserved Hull’s lead. Snodgrass, returning from injury, energized Hull’s attack, while manager Mike Phelan praised his team’s resilience, particularly Marshall’s performance. Southampton’s Claude Puel attributed the loss to a lack of concentration post-Europa League triumph. Hull remain in the relegation zone ahead of the international break, facing Sunderland next, while Southampton host league leaders Liverpool.

A fatal collision occurred around **14:15 BST** on the **B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa**, involving a **motorcyclist**—a local resident who died—and a **tractor driver**, who was uninjured. **Lincolnshire Police** have not released further details about the victim but are urging witnesses to contact them. The crash led to a **full road closure** in both directions between the **B1192 Tattershall Road junction (Woodhall Spa)** and the **A158 Jubilee Way junction (Horncastle)**.

Macedonia’s political crisis deepened after President Gjorge Ivanov halted an investigation into alleged government abuse of power exposed by covert recordings, claiming he sought to "end the agony" before June’s early elections and acted to "defend national interests." The 2015 recordings—released by opposition leader Zoran Zaev—appear to implicate officials in vote-rigging, corruption, and a murder cover-up, with Zaev accusing the government of illegally wiretapping 20,000 people, including politicians and journalists. Ivanov’s decision sparked backlash: Zaev called it illegal and mobilized protesters in Skopje, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn warned it undermined the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia’s EU membership bid. The government denies the allegations, accusing Zaev of destabilizing the country, a charge he rejects.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will temporarily lead Swansea’s match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s sacking, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the club’s top choice for a permanent replacement. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after recovering from near-bankruptcy and relegation threats in the early 2000s, now face relegation risks, with Curtis warning that dropping to the Championship—now stronger and harder to escape—would be difficult, especially without the financial clout of clubs like Newcastle. Curtis attributes Swansea’s decline to frequent managerial changes since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure, eroding the club’s signature "Swansea Way" of possession-based football, and questions whether player replacements have been adequate. Despite this, he believes the current squad can avoid relegation and emphasizes the club’s remarkable history—highlighted in the documentary *Jack to a King*—to motivate players, stressing the importance of survival for both the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge ("The Daggers") were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, ending their slim survival hopes in League Two despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring Orient’s winner. Dagenham, who first reached the Football League in 2007 under manager John Still, now return to non-league football after struggling defensively (worst goal difference in League Two, conceding 20 more goals than last season) and offensively, with Cureton—once a 20-goal scorer—managing just nine this term. Still, in his third spell at the club, vowed to rebuild for an immediate National League promotion. Meanwhile, Orient’s victory, secured under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler following Kevin Nolan’s recent dismissal, keeps them two points outside the play-off spots, though Hessenthaler admitted their performance was shaky after conceding two "sloppy" goals. Still criticized Dagenham’s first-half lack of organization and discipline, attributing their relegation to an inability to respond to setbacks this season.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Liverpool and England captain, will return to his old club in February as a youth coach, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised the appointment as "wonderful news," noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager in the future and his readiness to learn the necessary skills by combining his extensive playing experience—including winning the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup (three times), and League Cup (three times)—with coaching development. Gerrard, who left Liverpool in 2015 for LA Galaxy, had previously turned down the manager’s job at MK Dons, citing it as "too soon," and is currently working toward his UEFA A coaching licence, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

Morton took an early lead with a close-range goal by McManus in the 15th minute, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected strike to double their advantage. Alloa reduced the deficit before halftime through Kyle McAusland’s shot, but Morton secured a convincing victory with a second goal from McManus and a late strike by Denny Johnstone.

Ofsted uncovered squalid and unsafe conditions in three now-closed unregistered schools in Birmingham, part of an investigation into 18 such sites—primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands—where children faced risks of abuse or radicalisation. Running illegal schools can result in up to 51 weeks in jail, and ministers are proposing stricter regulations for settings teaching over 6–8 hours weekly, as any place operating over 20 hours must register as a school. While some "flexi schools" legally support home-educated children, Ofsted warns others exploit loopholes to run illegal institutions. Sir Michael Wilshaw criticised officials for delaying action and confirmed inspections will target unregistered schools across all religious groups, not just Muslim communities. The government has funded a six-inspector team to investigate these cases, with the education secretary now pushing for prosecutions, requiring her consent, and extending a consultation on tighter regulations until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is a small-scale distillery operating in a converted cowshed with one of the UK’s smallest production stills, distinguishing it from larger whisky distillery proposals currently in planning for the Scottish Borders—the region’s first since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the distillery’s focus on capturing the local "terroir" by using wild botanicals from the Teviot Valley, aiming to reflect the Borders’ unique flavors. John Henderson of Born in the Borders emphasizes the gin’s alignment with their ethos of local sourcing and its complementarity to the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery. The gin’s name honors Lilliard, a legendary female warrior from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor (Lilliard’s Edge), chosen to celebrate both the landscape and the distillery’s all-female production team.

In August 2013, **Harry Whitlam was killed** when **Gary Green, 51**, reversed a vehicle into him at **Swithens Farm, Rothwell**, while **more than twice the legal alcohol limit**—having consumed the equivalent of **13 pints of beer** before bed. Green, who was on **private land**, was **jailed for 16 months and two weeks** under **health and safety laws** (not road traffic legislation) after admitting **failing to ensure others' safety**. The **Health and Safety Executive (HSE)** found Green **recklessly** reversed the tractor into Whitlam around **09:15** while Harry walked in a closed-off area. Harry’s mother, **Pam Whitlam**, stated the **family was "changed forever"**, emphasizing the lasting trauma and urging accountability for drunk driving **anywhere**. She expressed hope to **honor Harry’s life beyond the accident**, describing him as a **beloved son, brother, and relative** whose absence grows harder with time.

Luis Suarez, the 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, has had his FIFA ban partially lifted by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), allowing him to train with Barcelona and participate in friendly matches but not competitive "organised" games. While his nine-match ban for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup remains largely upheld—with eight competitive international matches still outstanding—he can now join team activities, including Barcelona’s training sessions starting Friday, with his official presentation at Camp Nou on Monday. Suarez may play in Uruguay’s upcoming friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia but cannot feature in competitive matches until at least October 26, likely debuting for Barcelona in *El Clásico* against Real Madrid. CAS ruled FIFA’s initial ban on all football-related activity was "excessive," though it maintained the suspension’s core, rejecting calls from world players’ union FIFPro to reduce the penalty in exchange for mandatory treatment. Suarez, who joined Barcelona for £75m, has a history of disciplinary issues, including prior biting incidents and a racial abuse suspension in 2011. His legal team claimed FIFA misapplied its rules, while analysts noted the adjusted sanction balances proportionality with his repeat offenses.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre obstacle race on **18 March 2014**, defeating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, by training intensively on a local athletics track. The challenging course included hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and avoiding water pistols, with participants of all gender pairings—men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman—though marriage was not required. The victory qualifies Rich and Anna for the **World Championships in Finland in July 2014**.

In October 2014, the UK’s paper car tax disc system will be replaced by an electronic system, allowing payments via monthly direct debit, as announced by Chancellor George Osborne. Concerns arose about potential job losses among the 5,000 workers at the DVLA’s Swansea centre, prompting Swansea East AM Mike Hedges to seek clarification from Transport Minister Stephen Hammond. Hammond confirmed that while job roles would change—due to reduced refund processing and the tax disc’s removal—any staff reductions would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies, focusing on retraining for new processes and growth areas. Hedges welcomed the commitment to redeployment, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing disappointment over fewer job opportunities at the DVLA.

Hungary’s government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s Fidesz party, refuses to retreat on three controversial laws—tight asylum controls, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law—arguing they fall under "national competence" and rejecting EU interference in "domestic issues." The higher education law threatens the closure of the Central European University (CEU), founded by George Soros, while the NGO legislation risks stigmatizing civil groups as "foreign-backed." Poland has pledged to veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of its voting rights, as such sanctions require unanimous approval. Despite mass protests in Hungary and warnings from EU officials like Frans Timmermans, who threatened action without compliance, Budapest remains defiant, insisting the laws will stand. The EU objects to Hungary’s detention of asylum seekers in shipping containers and the broader crackdown on academic and civic freedoms, but Hungary’s alliance with Poland shields it from potential penalties.

A live-action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast* features an all-star cast, including an unnamed actress as Mrs. Potts (the enchanted teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film), Kevin Kline as Belle’s father Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as the villain Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon (*Dreamgirls*, *Twilight*), the film began production at Shepperton Studios in May 2016 and was set for a US theatrical release on **17 March 2017**.

Columnist Adrian Gill, known for his dazzling and often controversial writing, died suddenly after being diagnosed with multiple advanced cancers, which he humorously called the "full English." Despite his illness, he remained stoical, expressing gratitude for his life and writing a final column about his diagnosis for the *Sunday Times*, where he had been a beloved figure since 1993. Editors and colleagues, including Martin Ivens and Andrew Neil, praised his unmatched wit, fearless prose, and unique style, calling him a "giant among journalists." Gill, who overcame dyslexia by dictating his work, was celebrated for his brilliance but also courted controversy with provocative remarks—mocking regions, ethnic groups, and public figures, including a censured comment about Clare Balding. Born in 1954, he studied art before transitioning to journalism, writing for *Tatler* and the *Sunday Times*, and was married twice, first to author Cressida Connolly and later to Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children. At the time of his death, he was engaged to long-term partner Nicola Formby, mother of his twins, and had recently reflected on his excitement for their upcoming wedding.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (Amraa), lead singer of *Khar Sarnai*, was allegedly assaulted in Ulan Bator after performing in a traditional *deel* embroidered with a swastika—a symbol with deep cultural roots in Mongolia predating its Nazi association. Russian news reports claimed he was struck with a bottle and kicked in the face, leaving him in a coma for 10 days with severe brain injuries, though the Russian embassy dismissed local accounts as "distorted." His father and lawyer denied social media claims that Amraa shouted "Heil Hitler," emphasizing the swastika’s historical significance in Mongolia, while acknowledging its far-right use by some groups today. The suspected attacker, an unnamed Russian diplomatic officer, remains under investigation but was not detained; authorities cited the injury’s severity—not diplomatic immunity—as the reason, though the lawyer insisted Mongolian law should apply regardless of the suspect’s status. The case highlights tensions over cultural symbols and diplomatic accountability.

Members of the activist group **Plane Stupid** staged a protest at an airport on **Monday at 03:30 BST** on the **northern runway**, opposing its **expansion plans**. Protesters were charged with **aggravated trespass** and **entering a security-restricted aerodrome area**, with a **court appearance scheduled for 19 August**. The **Metropolitan Police** announced a **review of airport security** following the incident.

Nick Selman scored a crucial **101 off 144 balls**—his second first-class century—anchoring Glamorgan’s total after being dropped early, though the team struggled as **seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles** took regular wickets in cloudy conditions at Cardiff. **Aneurin Donald (36 off 30)** provided brief support, while late contributions from **Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten** secured a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire’s reply focused on survival in fading light, leaving the match finely poised. **Michael Hogan** captained Glamorgan in place of the injured **Jacques Rudolph**, while Selman reflected on overcoming a lean patch—including four ducks—after his earlier century in Swansea. Gloucestershire’s **Taylor**, who dismissed three batters by hitting the stumps, praised the bowler-friendly conditions and anticipated a tough challenge for his team’s batsmen against Glamorgan’s strong attack.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, admitting to planning a false crime report to ambush and shoot police officers at the Dee Estuary. He confessed to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week, with Judge Niclas Parry remanding him in custody due to his 2009 firearm conviction and ongoing bail for unrelated firearms offences (of which he was later cleared). Hughes, who made the threats while drunk on two occasions, claimed he had no intention of killing himself or carrying out the attack, though police had raised concerns given his legal history. The Hope Line provides confidential support to individuals in distress.

Surrey recovered from a shaky start at 8-2 to post 255-7, fueled by a 130-run partnership between Davies (who scored heavily after being dropped) and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire’s chase faltered despite Tim Bresnan’s 68, as Stuart Meaker’s three-wicket burst—removing key batsmen like Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance—derailed their momentum, leaving them all out for 236. Yorkshire, seeking their first Lord’s final since 2002 after a recent T20 Blast semi-final loss, had early success dismissing Sibley and Sangakkara but were hindered by dropped catches, including Davies’ reprieve at 43. Meaker’s pivotal spell (3-61) shifted the game, and despite Bresnan and Waite’s resistance, Yorkshire fell short by 19 runs. Surrey’s captain praised the team’s collective effort and the match-winning partnership, while Yorkshire’s skipper lamented their failure to capitalize in crucial moments despite strong season performances.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST after its onboard pump failed to manage incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by deploying an additional pump and towing the vessel safely to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast due to conflicting veterinary medicine exams in May, prioritizing her final year of university studies. Despite her disappointment, she remains focused on her degree and expresses confidence in Scotland’s team, while eyeing future Olympics and potentially targeting the **World Indoor Championships in Birmingham (March)**. Reflecting on her recent performance at the **World Athletics Championships**, Muir set a **personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m**, finishing sixth, and celebrated her progress despite a grueling schedule of five races in 10 days, highlighting her optimism for future potential.

Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool’s struggles to replicate last season’s title challenge, attributing it to unrealistic expectations after overachieving in 2013-14, poor transfer decisions—particularly in replacing Luis Suárez and the injured Daniel Sturridge—and a lack of intensity, pressing, and set-piece threat. The team’s defensive frailties persist despite costly signings like Dejan Lovren, while midfield runners and full-back contributions have diminished, leaving them slow and reactive. For the Chelsea match, Savage suggests a 4-2-3-1 formation with Kolo Touré over Lovren, emphasizing defensive solidity and full-back attacks, though he doubts Liverpool can win given Chelsea’s dominance. Steven Gerrard’s future is also scrutinized; while his leadership and fitness remain strong, the mental and physical toll of aging—especially after his infamous slip against Chelsea—tests his longevity, though Savage believes he still has a key role to play.

A new £45 million educational campus at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will combine primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, with East Ayrshire Council seeking permission from the McIlvanney family to name it in honour of renowned writer **William McIlvanney**, who was born and educated in the town. Council leader **Douglas Reid** highlighted McIlvanney’s passion for education, noting the campus would preserve his legacy. After graduating from Glasgow University, McIlvanney taught English before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gaining acclaim with his debut novel *Remedy Is None* and earning the title **"Godfather of Tartan Noir"** for works like the *Laidlaw* trilogy, *Docherty*, and *The Big Man*. Beyond fiction, he was a celebrated poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to Scotland’s political and sporting discourse through columns and TV programmes, and died at his Glasgow home on **5 December**.

An evacuation was ordered near a town’s swimming pool for most of the morning and early afternoon after a **1940s–1950s British sea mine** was discovered in the river on Monday, with three streets cleared and residents within 500m advised to stay indoors, open windows, and avoid outdoor areas. A **half-mile exclusion zone** remained in place on the river and at sea, halting small boats and causing **ferry disruptions** (Gourock and Rothesay routes). Authorities, including **Ch Insp Elliot Brown**, emphasized the evacuation was **precautionary**, with no immediate threat, while **Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis** of the Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit noted the mine’s **deterioration** made it impossible to assess the remaining explosives, prompting its relocation for safer disposal. **Inverclyde Council** thanked residents and businesses for their cooperation during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345m—£2m less than Rio 2016—to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, setting a medal target of 51-85 (Olympics) and 115-162 (Paralympics), down from Rio’s 67 and 147. Funding cuts include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and **badminton**—despite its men’s doubles bronze in Rio—while cycling’s budget dropped by over £4m. Judo, which also met its one-medal target, saw a slight funding increase. UK Sport defended prioritizing "medal potential," though **Badminton England** called the cut "catastrophic" and unjustified given recent success. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball—previously defunded—criticized UK Sport for neglecting development pathways despite a 2015 review. New Tokyo sports (e.g., skateboarding, karate, Para-taekwondo) await funding decisions from the remaining £9m, with UK Sport emphasizing medal potential as the key criterion. Government and National Lottery funding remains committed, but critics argue the approach risks undermining long-term success in non-priority disciplines.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth’s East Cliff conservation area—the Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View—will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, 90-room four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (one nine-storey, one seven-storey, totaling 122 units). Despite objections from English Heritage, which warned of "severe harm" to the conservation area, and 49 residents plus the Ancient Monuments Society citing the hotels’ historic character, Bournemouth councillors approved the plans (7-3) to boost tourism and improve elderly housing. Planning board chair David Kelsey acknowledged the loss of buildings and trees as "regrettable" but argued the existing structures were no longer functional, emphasizing the need for progress. The project, led by The East Cliff Project LLP, received 246 letters of support.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked while off-duty in Brecon during a night out on 8 May, after participating in training exercises. Jake Vallely, 24, punched and beat Boyd outside *The Cellar* bar, dragging his unconscious body away after the assault, which was captured on CCTV; Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking spree and earlier boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon." His friend Aaeron Evans was acquitted of manslaughter as he had left before the violence began. Vallely’s sentencing is set for 8 December. Boyd’s family described him as a loving, humorous "all-rounder" with a promising career, while condemning Vallely for causing irreversible pain. Police called the attack "despicable" and urged people to avoid violence, while the community’s support for Boyd’s family contrasted Vallely’s claims of toughness.

Andrew Travers resigned as Barnet Council’s chief executive by "mutual agreement" after a major voting error left voters’ names missing from poll lists at all 155 borough stations, forcing many to be turned away on election day—with one station reporting only 3 of 30 early voters registered. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and launched an independent investigation, due by late May, to review the EU Referendum arrangements and determine who will lead it. Travers, who served three and a half years, cited enjoyment of his role and confidence in the borough’s growth, while the council praised his contributions. Deputy CEO John Hooton will temporarily replace him amid concerns from voters about the election’s fairness.

Gateshead secured a 2-1 away win over Wrexham in a closely contested match where both teams scored from set pieces. Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a well-taken free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton’s equally impressive set-piece. The winner came in the second half when Ryan Bowman headed in Craig Baxter’s cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team’s improved second-half performance, highlighting their better passing and the quality of Bowman’s goal, while acknowledging Wrexham’s strong first-half display. Wrexham’s Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his side’s second-half defensiveness and missed chances, noting they created opportunities but failed to capitalize. The match saw multiple saves, offsides, fouls, and corners, with Gateshead ultimately clinching the victory through Bowman’s decisive header.

The **Global AgeWatch Index 2014** evaluates the **social and economic well-being of people aged 60 and over** across **96 countries**, ranking **Norway as the best-performing nation** while **Afghanistan** is the lowest, followed by **Mozambique**. The index assesses factors like income security, health, employment, and enabling environments for older populations.

The **OneWeb project**, led by Airbus and OneWeb, aims to deploy a **constellation of 600–2,000 satellites** to provide **global broadband access**, particularly targeting schools worldwide. To achieve this affordably, Airbus shifted from traditional, high-cost satellite manufacturing to **high-volume, low-cost production**—similar to car or plane assembly lines—targeting **three satellites per shift at under $1 million each**. The first assembly line in **Toulouse, France**, is operational, with two more planned in **Florida**, using **automation and scaled supplier chains** to meet demand. Launches begin in **April 2019**, with **300 satellites in orbit by late 2020**, **600+ by 2022**, and **800+ by mid-decade**, requiring **over 20 Soyuz rockets**—the largest rocket campaign in history. OneWeb has raised **$1.7 billion** and seeks further funding, positioning itself as a **first-mover** amid competitors like SpaceX. Registered in the **UK’s Channel Islands**, it highlights economic benefits for the UK, including revenue and regulatory leadership. To address **space debris concerns**, OneWeb commits to **de-orbiting satellites within two years** and adding **adapters for removal by chase vehicles** if needed. While this approach may disrupt satellite manufacturing, Airbus notes **custom, high-reliability spacecraft** (e.g., for Jupiter missions) will still require traditional methods.

John Swinney criticized the UK government’s recent spending review for placing "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland’s public finances, arguing that since 2010, discretionary funding will be **12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20**, with **4.2% of that reduction occurring between now and 2020**, equating to over **£1bn in cuts**. Despite the UK government stating Scotland would have **£390m more next year** (rising to **£750m** including underspend), Swinney accused Chancellor George Osborne of imposing unnecessary austerity, vowing to protect **schools, hospitals, and police** while maintaining priorities like **tuition-free universities** and **record health funding**. The UK government countered that Scotland’s **£30bn block grant**—bolstered by UK economic stability—was preferable to independence, urging focus on new devolved powers. Labour’s Jackie Baillie dismissed Swinney’s approach as insufficient, demanding a **long-term anti-austerity plan** and criticizing both the SNP and Tories for failing to offer real alternatives, proposing **tax-based solutions** instead.

People with severe disabilities, their families, and carers often face isolation and stress due to the lack of fully accessible toilets, as standard facilities fail to accommodate those needing hoists, benches, or assistance from multiple carers. **Changing Places toilets**—larger, enhanced facilities with these features—are recommended but not compulsory in UK building regulations, leaving over 250,000 potential users underserved despite 893 existing units. Campaigners like Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers highlight the emotional and practical toll, from changing loved ones on dirty floors to feeling excluded from society, while success stories—such as Arsenal FC’s installation and a "pop-up" Changing Places at a party—demonstrate progress. Architects and advocates argue compulsory inclusion in new large venues (e.g., shopping centres, stadiums) would clarify expectations, though cost and space barriers persist. Current guidelines (BS 8300:2009) remain non-binding, allowing businesses to prioritize mandatory requirements over recommendations, despite the clear demand for dignity and accessibility.

Italian consumers' organisations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald’s of exploiting franchisees through excessive rents, high fees, and long-term contracts that prevent them from switching competitors, while leasing premises at above-market rates. McDonald’s defended its model, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees, calling the approach successful for decades and beneficial for both franchisees and customers. The complaint is backed by the **Service Employees International Union (SEIU)** and European unions, including the UK’s **Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union**, which argue McDonald’s abuses its market dominance, harming franchisees, workers, and consumers by limiting choice and inflating prices in franchised stores compared to company-owned ones. Franchisees operate **73% of McDonald’s European locations**, and the company generated **$9.27bn (£6.40bn) in global franchised revenue in 2014**. The European Commission will review the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed credible.

A social media campaign using the hashtag **#prayforjosh** emerged to support **13-year-old Joshua Martin** from Donaghadee, County Down, after he was diagnosed with cancer on **Christmas Eve** during what was meant to be a routine appendix operation at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital, where doctors instead removed a **large primary tumor and five smaller growths**. Initiated by **Bangor Elim Church**—where Josh’s father serves as pastoral staff—the hashtag went viral, garnering **over 79,000 views and 948 shares**, with global support flooding in. A **mystery donor** later funded a **billboard** near Holywood’s A2, while Josh’s classmates and strangers worldwide amplified the movement on platforms like **Twitter and Instagram**. The church’s senior pastor, **Gary Beattie**, expressed astonishment at the outpouring, emphasizing the campaign began as a simple call for prayer but evolved into a widespread show of solidarity, with updates on Josh’s condition shared regularly to their young congregation. The movement highlights both the **power of social media** and the **global compassion** extended to Josh and his family during his recovery.

The UK government’s military restructuring includes closing **Brecon Barracks**, a historic site operational since 1805, which has housed troops involved in conflicts like Rorke’s Drift, sparking outrage from local Conservative MP **Chris Davies**, who called the decision "abhorrent" and launched a petition, citing the barracks’ cultural significance and Brecon’s high unemployment rates. While the barracks employs **85 civilians and 90 military personnel**, job losses are not expected, and nearby **Sennybridge training ground** and **Dering Lines infantry school** will remain unaffected. Defence Secretary **Sir Michael Fallon** announced plans for a new **specialist light infantry centre at St Athan**, while **Cawdor Barracks (Pembrokeshire)** and a **Sennybridge storage depot** will close in **2024 and 2025**, respectively. Labour’s **Nia Griffith** acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of economic uncertainty for affected communities.

The passage highlights the complexities and trade-offs facing the UK fishing industry post-Brexit, despite its strong support for leaving the EU due to dissatisfaction with the **Common Fisheries Policy (CFP)**. While Brexit presents an opportunity for the UK to regain control over its waters and boost exports—similar to Norway—the **House of Lords report** warns the industry (which contributes just **0.5% of GDP** and employs **12,000 fishers**) risks being **marginalised** in negotiations. Key challenges include the **shared nature of fish stocks** with EU states, the UK’s reliance on **EU markets for exports** (and EU imports for domestic consumption), and potential demands for **EU access to UK waters** in exchange for tariff-free trade. The report suggests retaining **science-based quotas** and cooperating with neighboring states, but notes Brexit could lead to **four separate fisheries regimes** across the UK’s devolved nations. Industry leaders, like the **Scottish Fishermen’s Federation**, remain optimistic, citing recent **quota increases** under the CFP as a positive sign for future independence, while the government emphasizes balancing **trade access** with **sustainable fisheries management**.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked classified documents revealing the NSA’s mass surveillance programs, including **Prism**, which granted "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies (Microsoft, Google, Facebook, etc.) to collect chat logs, social media data, emails, and more—though the companies denied involvement. The NSA also obtained **millions of Verizon phone records** (call details, locations, durations) under court orders. While U.S. officials like **Keith Alexander** and **Barack Obama** defended the programs as vital for counterterrorism, critics argued the scope was excessive, with **Peter Sommer** suggesting access might be limited to targeted individuals via court orders. Laws like the **Patriot Act** and **FISA** allowed U.S. authorities to access foreign data stored in the U.S. (e.g., via cloud computing), raising global concerns—especially in the EU, where officials demanded transparency. The **UK’s GCHQ** neither confirmed nor denied involvement. Privacy advocates, including **Privacy International**, warned that Prism enabled near-universal surveillance of internet users, with **no legal opt-out**, while Snowden justified his leaks by condemning a society where "everything I do and say is recorded." Governments insisted law-abiding citizens had nothing to fear, but the leaks exposed tensions between **security, privacy, and legal oversight**.

OpenAI is a research venture backed by high-profile figures like Elon Musk (Tesla, SpaceX), Peter Thiel (PayPal co-founder), Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, with a mission to develop AI free from financial constraints for a "positive human impact." While experts like Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that AI could pose an existential threat—potentially outpacing human evolution—others argue the risks remain distant. OpenAI’s stated goal is to advance digital intelligence for humanity’s benefit, emphasizing safe, equitable distribution aligned with human wills, and notes that only a small portion of its $1 billion funding will be used initially. The organization acknowledges AI’s dual potential: immense societal benefits if developed responsibly or severe harm if misused.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack that left him with a brain injury and speech loss, defied expectations by recovering his ability to speak and maintaining his humor and personality. Despite using crutches and undergoing 12 hours of daily gym and rehab, he remains active in charity work, supporting military causes and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. After carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June, he received overwhelming public support, with over 5,000 Facebook friend requests (exceeding the site’s limit), 19,000 hits on a single update, and numerous visit requests. His mother, Diane, described the response as "phenomenal," noting Ben’s elation at the outpouring of messages, mail, and emails. Facebook suggested he transition to a public page due to his high profile, while the torch relay involved 8,000 carriers over 8,000 miles ahead of the 27 July London Olympics opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained steady at **15%** (46.2 million people), halting three consecutive years of increases after hitting a record **15.1%** in 2010, while real median household income declined by **1.5%**. The poverty threshold for a family of four was **$23,021**, and income inequality worsened, with the **Gini index rising 1.6%**—its first annual increase since 1993. Meanwhile, the percentage of Americans without health insurance slightly improved, dropping to **15.7%** from **16.3%**.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format cricket specialist, joined Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new contract extending his stay until 2019. He holds the record for England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan in 2015. Lancashire’s cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler as one of the game’s most talented players, highlighting his pivotal role in their 2015 T20 Blast final victory and his positive influence in the dressing room, where his international experience benefits the team. Currently playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler is set to return for Lancashire’s T20 Blast match against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS *Cumberland*, *Campbeltown*, *Chatham*, and *Cornwall*—are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour after being based in Devonport, with bidders having until 23 January to express interest. No preservation proposals were submitted, and final bids are being prepared ahead of viewings in late February and March, with a decision expected by spring. The UK’s Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic recycling capacity, though Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt advocates for at least one to avoid scrapping, preferring repurposing as a diving reef to boost tourism and generate income. The Ministry of Defence emphasizes securing the best financial return for taxpayers but declines to disclose bid details due to commercial sensitivity. Originally anti-submarine specialists, the Type 22 frigates later became versatile surface combatants with advanced weapons and command systems, crewed by around 280 personnel, while the 2023 scrapping of HMS *Ark Royal* for £3m highlights prior disposal outcomes.

Since 1987, Fiji has faced persistent instability due to racial and political tensions, marked by four coups—most notably in 1987 (overthrowing an Indian-dominated government), 2000 (led by George Speight, targeting the first ethnic Indian PM), and a 2006 military takeover—all deepening ethnic divisions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. These upheavals damaged the economy, particularly tourism, and led to Fiji’s 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth for undemocratic governance, though it was reinstated in 2014 after agreeing to elections. Ethnic segregation remains entrenched, with minimal intergroup mixing, and emigration by Indo-Fijians after the coups shifted demographics, leaving indigenous Fijians as a slight majority.
