Critics argue existing respected level two apprenticeships (e.g., construction) should be retained, while the Department for Education claims reforms—like minimum one-year durations and stronger English/maths requirements—are already underway to raise standards.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey secured a dominant victory in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska, with a chance to claim her 17th world title in Saturday’s road race. The 37-year-old, Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across six Games, expressed relief at her win while targeting further success at Rio 2016. Initially a swimmer, she won six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before transitioning to cycling in 2005, amassing 21 world titles and four golds at London 2012 across both sports.

Hereford United (the Bulls) were expelled from the Football Conference after repeatedly failing to meet deadlines to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, including players, staff, and former manager Martin Foyle, despite multiple extensions granted by the league. The club’s financial crisis—stemming from debts totaling around £225,000, including a £70,000 HMRC tax bill—worsened after relegation from the Football League in 2012, with attendances dropping from 3,270 to 1,758. A fan-led bid by the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear debts was rejected in favor of a takeover by businessman Tommy Agombar, which ultimately failed to resolve the issues. Chester, initially relegated after a dramatic final-day escape by Hereford, were reinstated in the Bulls’ place, while players like Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd-Weston left due to unpaid wages. The Conference, having exhausted all options, held Hereford solely responsible for their demise, marking their expulsion as a self-inflicted collapse after years of financial mismanagement.

James Milner, the 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned **61 senior caps for England** after debuting in **2009**, featuring in **two World Cups and two European Championships** but playing only **three minutes at Euro 2016**. He announced his international retirement, citing **"common sense"** while wishing success to manager **Sam Allardyce**, teammates, staff, and fans. Milner also holds the record for the **most England Under-21 caps (46)**, debuting in **2004**, and scored his **only senior international goal** in a **5-0 win over Moldova** during the **2014 World Cup qualifiers**.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneering figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness, with a private funeral planned and a memorial service to follow later. As founder and director of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) for 30 years, he led the ensemble across six continents and produced over 200 CDs, including landmark recordings like the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 version of Handel’s *Messiah* (ranked among the top 20 recordings by *BBC Music Magazine*). Trained in keyboard at Cambridge and under notable mentors like Gustav Leonhardt, Hogwood began his career with the Academy of St Martin-in-the-Fields and co-founded the Early Music Consort of London. He held leadership roles at the King’s Lynn Festival, Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarly brilliance, and commitment to historically informed performance, noting his influence in nurturing generations of musicians and his belief in letting "the music speak for itself." Tributes highlighted his legacy as a founder of the early-music movement and a beloved mentor.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June by his parents after struggling to cope, leaving his mother to quit her job to care for him. Despite requesting a place at a special school, the family was told in September that all such schools in their area were full, with no timeline for availability. The boy’s mother expressed distress over his isolation, as he doesn’t understand why his siblings attend school while he cannot. Recently, the family was informed an additional classroom assistant had been hired at a local special school, raising hopes he may enroll in the coming weeks, though his mother fears similar delays will affect other families due to overcrowded special needs provisions. The Education Authority declined to comment on the case, citing privacy, but noted they are reviewing special school capacity in Northern Ireland to ensure local placements by 2016.

Newport County AFC holds a lease at Rodney Parade until 2023, ensuring priority for fixtures if they stay in the Football League, despite the Welsh Rugby Union’s (WRU) takeover bid for fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons and plans to convert the ground into a rugby-focused venue with an artificial pitch—something Football League rules prohibit. County’s CEO, Dave Foxall, insists their contract must be honored, while Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under existing agreements. The WRU’s takeover vote is scheduled for **9 May**, with Newport RFC shareholders deciding the outcome. On the field, County—under caretaker manager Mike Flynn—sits two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left and could secure survival this weekend if they win and rivals Hartlepool lose. Relegation to the National League would be a major setback for the club and the city, having only regained Football League status in 2013.

A former child soldier in Sierra Leone’s civil war (1991–2002) recounts being abducted at 15 by the RUF rebels, forced into combat, branded, and subjected to extreme violence, including drug-fueled atrocities and cannibalism, before escaping to Freetown, where he turned to crime. After meeting preacher Richard Cole in jail, he joined *Lifeline Nehemiah*, a rehabilitation project, which helped him rebuild his life through education and faith. During the 2014 Ebola outbreak—declared over last weekend after killing nearly 4,000 in Sierra Leone—he led community efforts: educating over 10,000 people about the virus, distributing food to 11,000, and establishing a treatment clinic with local support, despite initial skepticism and fear. Now dedicated to youth empowerment, he views his past with regret but focuses on rebuilding his nation and inspiring global change, emphasizing investment in young people as key to the future. The passage also notes Ebola’s regional death toll: 11,314, with Sierra Leone (3,955), Liberia (4,808), and Guinea (2,536) hardest hit.

A public fundraising campaign successfully saved around 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum from being auctioned to cover the pottery firm’s pension debt, reaching its target in just a month after launching in September. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the collection will stay on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, with the Art Fund gifting it to the Victoria and Albert Museum before loaning it back. The museum had faced financial trouble after inheriting Waterford Wedgwood plc’s pension debt following its 2009 collapse, leading to a 2011 court ruling allowing the collection’s sale to repay the Pension Protection Fund. Key figures, including administrator Bob Young and Alison Wedgwood (whose husband is a descendant of founder Josiah Wedgwood), highlighted the collection’s cultural significance, warning it could have been "scattered globally" without the funds. Tristram Hunt MP emphasized its role in Britain’s cultural history and national identity.

Negotiations are underway for former *I’m A Celebrity* runner-up **Mark Wright** to purchase a **20% stake** in **Billericay Town FC**, though key details remain undisclosed, while *The Sun* reports he will join as a **club director**. The team currently sits **eighth** in the **Isthmian League Premier Division**, **three points behind** a playoff spot. Wright, 30, previously played non-league football for clubs like **Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds**. Billericay was recently acquired by **multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin**, who pledged to invest **£10,000 weekly** in the club. In March, they signed **former England international Paul Konchesky**, 35.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, surprised observers by choosing a one-year extension to his term—until 2019—rather than the expected options of leaving in 2018 or staying until 2021, citing personal family reasons as the decisive factor. While speculation suggested political pressure or disillusionment with Brexit’s economic fallout might influence his decision, Carney clarified it was purely personal, tied to his daughters’ education milestones (A-levels and GCSEs in 2018) and his family’s plan to return to Canada. Though he acknowledged the professional challenge of leaving mid-Brexit negotiations, he balanced this with his commitment to the role’s demands, stating his extension would cover the critical Article 50 period before handing over to a successor. Despite Prime Minister Theresa May’s preference for a longer term and dismissals of tensions or criticism over the Bank’s pre-referendum forecasts, Carney framed the choice as a private one, emphasizing his dedication to the role while prioritizing family needs.

Blackpool took an early lead in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt scored from close range after Nathan Delfouneso’s cross, but Colchester equalized shortly after through Kurtis Guthrie following a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Blackpool’s goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made crucial saves, including denying George Elokobi and Guthrie’s header that hit the bar before halftime, while Blackpool’s Tom Aldred missed a late chance to win the game with a header. The match ended 1-1, with Colchester reduced to 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a dangerous tackle on Jim McAlister, who was later substituted due to injury. Both teams had further chances, including blocked shots and saved attempts, but neither could break the deadlock.

The **Healthy Me** programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity **Action Mental Health**, aims to help **P6 and P7 children** cope with change, particularly the stress of **transfer tests** and the transition to secondary school. After a successful **pilot in five schools**, the charity hopes to expand it across Northern Ireland. The programme includes **interactive workshops** teaching emotional wellbeing, stress management, and where to seek support, while also providing **basic training for teachers**. At **Carrick Primary School**, pastoral care co-ordinator **Helen Hamilton** noted that children and parents often feel anxiety about moving from a **close-knit primary environment** to secondary school, where teachers have less time to spot individual struggles. The workshops teach **breathing exercises and relaxation techniques** to help pupils manage stress, emphasizing that **emotional readiness is crucial for learning**. **Noelle Buick**, Northern Ireland’s chief inspector of schools, highlighted the need to **strengthen youth resilience** amid modern social challenges, advocating for **preventative education** within pastoral care. Meanwhile, **14,681 P7 pupils** sat this year’s unofficial transfer tests—a slight increase from 2015—adding to the pressure during this transitional phase.

The disused **Fawley Power Station**, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, is set to become the centerpiece of a **£1bn "merchant city" development** by Fawley Waterside, featuring a **petal-shaped glass structure**, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to **Southampton and Portsmouth**. The **198-meter chimney**—the tallest structure south of London’s Shard—will be repurposed as a key attraction, avoiding demolition due to its iconic status. Originally commissioned in **1971**, the **2,000-megawatt oil-fired station** (fueled by the nearby Esso refinery) once powered **one million homes** and included **1,100 miles of cabling**. The **300-acre site**, sold to developers in **2016**, could see construction begin in **2018** pending planning approval, with the chimney’s reuse offering a cost-effective alternative to new landmarks like Brighton’s i360 or Portsmouth’s Spinnaker Tower.

Great Britain secured two medals at the Hong Kong championships, with **Elinor Barker earning silver in the women’s scratch race** and **Oliver Latham claiming bronze in the men’s scratch** after a late sprint, finishing behind Poland’s gold medalist Adrian Teklinski and Germany’s Lucass Liss. The **men’s team pursuit squad lost the bronze to Italy**, while **Joe Truman was eliminated in the keirin semi-finals** after an early attack. In the **women’s team pursuit**, GB’s young quartet—including Barker—finished fifth in heats, missing the medal race, though Barker highlighted their potential ahead of Tokyo 2020. **Katy Marchant**, Olympic bronze medalist in sprint, was knocked out in the first round but will compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin. Analysts like **Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham’s tactical race**, noting his well-timed sprint, while **Joanna Rowsell Shand emphasized the promise of GB’s inexperienced women’s pursuit team**, despite their lack of medals. Marchant attributed her performance to post-Rio fatigue but remained focused on long-term preparation for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in *EastEnders* in 2006, will make a brief return for Dame Barbara Windsor’s final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, who is set to die from cancer in emotional spring scenes after revealing her diagnosis to son Phil (Steve McFadden). Kemp, a close friend of Windsor, agreed to reprise his role—originally played from 1990–1999 and briefly in 2005–2006—to reunite the Mitchell brothers for Peggy’s farewell. Grant, a legendary character known for family dramas like his affair with Phil’s wife Kathy and Phil’s marriage to Grant’s ex-wife Sharon, will return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the reunion as a chance to showcase Kemp and McFadden’s acting prowess amid the emotional storyline.

Sadio Mané scored two quick goals as Liverpool defeated second-placed Tottenham at Anfield, with Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino criticizing his team’s lack of intensity and desire, stating they showed no readiness to compete for the Premier League title. He warned that if Chelsea extend their lead to 12 points with a win over Burnley, it would create a significant challenge. Spurs’ poor away form was highlighted—they’ve won just twice on the road since September, with one victory in their last 17 away matches against top-six rivals. Pochettino emphasized their struggle to handle pressure, while pundit Danny Murphy criticized their defensive disorganization, noting a shift from their usual back-three system to a back four, which backfired. Murphy also pointed to Spurs’ stark contrast in performance at home versus away, citing a lack of pace and a problematic mindset in away games.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a landmark victory in Nigeria’s gubernatorial elections, winning 19 of 28 governor posts, marking the Peoples Democratic Party’s (PDP) worst defeat since 1999 and reinforcing its decline after losing the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP, once dominant, retained only eight governorships—mostly in the south-east—while losing key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Boko Haram-affected Adamawa, though it held Rivers State, Nigeria’s oil hub. The APC’s gains reshaped the political landscape, confining the PDP to regional influence, particularly in the south-east and Niger Delta, while the APC dominated the north and Lagos, the commercial capital. However, the APC failed to win any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential militant disruptions to oil revenue under Buhari’s presidency. Elections in some areas were marred by violence, ethnic tensions, and logistical issues, though overall they were more peaceful than past polls. The PDP’s losses stemmed from voter fatigue after 16 years in power, corruption allegations, failure to curb Boko Haram’s insurgency, and mass defections to the APC, forcing the party into a period of rebuilding under new leadership.

The **Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt)**, held in **Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July**, will introduce an **augmented reality app** allowing visitors to access online content—such as **videos and band interviews**—by scanning signs and posters via their phones or tablets. This year’s lineup includes **The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean**. Festival director **Caroline Maclennan** highlights that the app enhances the on-site experience while also enabling **global audiences to engage remotely**, access real-time updates, purchase tickets, and experience the festival’s atmosphere before and during the event.

Birmingham’s **Park View and Nansen Primary academies**, rated *inadequate* by Ofsted, will lose their funding agreements, potentially removing **Park View Educational Trust** from oversight, while **Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School**—also rated *inadequate*—face termination unless they address concerns by **4 July**, including ending segregation, bias against non-Muslims, and ensuring a balanced curriculum. A **Trojan Horse scandal** investigation revealed allegations of a hardline Muslim takeover, with **five schools rated inadequate** for failures like unvetted extremist speakers and Islamic-themed assemblies. **Saltley School**, the only council-run school in special measures, will get a temporary governing board. **Head teachers** described intimidation by parents, with one anonymous leader admitting near-resignation due to isolation before the scandal’s exposure. **Ofsted’s Sir Michael Wilshaw** cited a "culture of fear" and campaigns to impose a "narrow, faith-based ideology." **Parents**, like **Arshad Malik**, dismissed the reports as biased, accusing inspectors of "loaded questions," while **Saltley School** aims to recover its rating under new leadership. **Education Minister Lord Nash** emphasized failures in promoting equality and pupil welfare, demanding urgent reforms.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a 38-year-old British-Iranian woman, was sentenced to five years in prison by Iran in September on undisclosed charges of allegedly plotting to overthrow the government, a claim her family denies. Arrested in April 2016 at Tehran Airport, she has endured solitary confinement, while her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella, remains in Iran after authorities confiscated her passport, leaving her in the care of grandparents. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, has criticized the UK government for inaction and described the appeal process—held secretly in Tehran—as unpredictable, with potential outcomes ranging from acquittal to an increased sentence. He believes his wife is a pawn in a UK-Iran diplomatic dispute and revealed her deteriorating mental health, including suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike, though her condition improved after leaving solitary confinement. Their daughter, now fluent in Farsi but losing her English, communicates with her father via Skype with translation help from relatives. Amnesty International has declared Zaghari-Ratcliffe a "prisoner of conscience," urging her immediate release, while Ratcliffe struggles to obtain a visa to visit his family. The appeal’s result remains uncertain, with no clear timeline for a decision.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich, where optometrist Honey Rose, 35, allegedly failed to detect his swollen optic discs—a condition linked to a fatal build-up of fluid in his brain. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court argued that Rose’s negligence in not referring him for further investigation was criminally below professional standards, directly causing his preventable death. Rose, from Newham, east London, denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter, with the trial ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court for coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he arranged via an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014, filming the encounters, and sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day 2014. He was also found guilty of forcing the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images and behaving abusively. The victim testified she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg, who denied the charges but was placed on the sex offenders register. Due to the severity of the case, Sheriff George Way referred it to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing, citing its greater powers. Lady Wolffe later stated the sentence must reflect "society’s abhorrence" of his actions, noting he posed a "moderate risk" of reoffending despite being a first-time offender. His defense claimed his remand ahead of sentencing was a "dramatic shock."

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored **165-5**, led by Stuart Thompson’s **56**, Gary Wilson’s **41 not out**, and captain William Porterfield’s **39**, after losing early wicket Paul Stirling for a duck. Afghanistan chased down the target with **171-4** in 18 overs, powered by Samiullah Shenwari’s **56** and Mohammad Shahzad’s **47**, supported by a **51-run opening stand** between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27). Afghanistan’s Amir Hamza was the only bowler with multiple wickets (2-23). Ireland’s captain admitted they fell **15 runs short** of their **180-run target** and struggled with bowling execution, while paceman **Boyd Rankin** missed the match due to a back injury but is expected to return for the **five ODIs starting 15 March**. The teams face off again in the **second T20 at the same venue on Friday**.

Barcelona insisted they committed no offence in Neymar’s £48.6m transfer from Santos, though the total cost—including wages, fees, and a £34m payment to his parents—reached £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation allegations (which he denies) after reports suggested the actual transfer cost far exceeded the declared £48.6m. A Spanish judge found enough evidence to continue investigating the deal, prompting Barcelona to pay an additional €13.55m in taxes to address potential interpretations of their obligations, though they maintain the original payment complied with fiscal rules. The case’s status remains unresolved, while Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances this season.

The bodies of British tourists **David Miller (24)** and **Hannah Witheridge (23)** were found murdered on a beach in **Koh Tao, Thailand, on 15 September**, with post-mortems revealing Miller died from drowning and head trauma, while Witheridge succumbed to head wounds. **Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (both 21)**, were arrested and allegedly confessed to the crimes—though Thai police denied reports they later retracted their confessions. They face charges of **conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery**, with potential **death penalties** if convicted. **UK Metropolitan Police officers** traveled to Thailand to review the investigation, collaborating with Thai authorities before returning to compile a report for the victims’ families. The **UK Foreign Office raised concerns** over the investigation, including **DNA verification issues** and **allegations of suspect mistreatment**, after Thai police claimed DNA from Witheridge matched samples from the accused. The UK delegation’s visit followed an agreement between **Thai PM Prayuth Chan-ocha and UK PM David Cameron**, reversing Thailand’s initial refusal of foreign assistance.

VR is being increasingly used across fields like journalism, education, healthcare, and retail to enhance real-world understanding and engagement. The UK’s National Autistic Society created a VR film to simulate sensory overload in autism, aiming to improve public awareness, while Alzheimer’s Research UK developed a VR experience to demonstrate the challenges of dementia. Retailers like Ikea and Westfield use VR for virtual product demonstrations, with Ikea’s kitchen app unexpectedly gaining popularity for its interactive features, including virtual meatballs. In healthcare, VR aids medical training—such as Dr. Shafi Ahmed’s live virtual surgery—and treats phobias, like arachnophobia, with an 83% success rate in one study. Educationally, Google Expeditions offers virtual field trips, and startups like Evanescent Studios are testing VR for language learning, envisioning immersive historical experiences. However, cost and technical limitations remain barriers, particularly for schools, despite VR’s potential to revolutionize engagement in learning.

The "black box" of the downed Russian Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow, with investigators noting that key flight data appeared missing, though a full analysis is expected next week to clarify the jet’s location when struck. The incident—where Turkish F-16s shot down the Su-24 on **24 November**—escalated tensions between Russia and Turkey, with Moscow accusing Ankara of ignoring its airspace and acting as a "subservient" U.S. ally while Turkey claims the jet violated its borders despite warnings. Both crew ejected, but the pilot was killed by ground militants, while a Russian marine and a rescue helicopter were also lost; Russia retaliated with sanctions, including a costly ban on Turkish tourism, and demands an apology. President Putin further criticized Turkey for "creeping Islamisation" amid the diplomatic fallout.

Scotland’s women’s football team has won all five qualifiers and faces Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, where a victory would nearly secure their place in next summer’s finals in the Netherlands, avoiding another play-off heartbreak after past failures for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup. Iceland, ranked 20th—one place above Scotland—are also unbeaten, making the two upcoming matches (including the return in Reykjavik) pivotal for topping the group. Forward Claire Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, emphasizes the emotional stakes and the team’s determination, noting the boost from a strong home crowd. With 12 of Scotland’s 20-player squad playing abroad—including stars like Kim Little in the U.S. and Evans in Germany—the team benefits from exposure to top leagues, enhancing their competitiveness. Evans highlights how her experience in Germany’s elite Bundesliga, alongside world-class players, has elevated her game, while the growing number of Scots playing overseas brings diverse skills to the national team.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no simple solution to fix flaws in the current council tax, which has had inherent problems since its introduction and worsened due to lack of reforms. A review by Prof Kenneth Gibb highlighted that while property taxes—used by most OECD countries—are considered stable and effective, they create confusion among taxpayers over whether they tax wealth or fund services and are seen as unfair for not aligning with current income. Local income taxes, though perceived as fairer, pose challenges for authorities due to income volatility and limited flexibility in setting rates. Gibb emphasized that reform is complex, shaped by past experiences, and requires careful consideration despite the council tax’s deficiencies. The commission will conduct public consultations before releasing its report in autumn, while the Scottish government, which deems the current system unfair, awaits its recommendations for fairer alternatives.

Apple has enhanced iCloud security by extending its **two-step verification** system to block third-party tools like *Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker*, which was allegedly used to steal celebrity photos by bypassing backups. The system now requires users to enter a **four-digit code** sent to a trusted device or phone when logging in from new devices, preventing unauthorized access to iCloud, iTunes, or App Store purchases unless a **14-character recovery key** (which users must safeguard) is used. While Apple previously offered two-step verification, it didn’t apply to backups, leaving a vulnerability exploited by hackers using pirated forensic software. **Vladimir Katalov**, Elcomsoft’s owner, confirmed Apple’s fix is secure but warned that lost or stolen recovery keys could still risk permanent data loss or account compromise. Security expert **Prof. Alan Woodward** argued two-factor authentication should be **enabled by default**, not optional, citing password-only systems as inherently weak. Apple acknowledged the need for better user awareness and plans to **push stronger passwords and two-factor adoption**, though CEO **Tim Cook** framed it as an education issue rather than a technical one.

The passage details campaign spending by UK political parties in the May 2014 European elections, covering expenditures from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP, the winning party, spent £2,956,737 (68p per vote), while the Conservatives spent slightly more at £2,980,815 (79p per vote). Labour, which placed second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote), and the Liberal Democrats, who lost 11 of 12 MEPs, spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote). The Green Party, fourth place, spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372. Combined, the top six parties spent £9,347,087, with all except Labour increasing their spending compared to the 2009 European elections.

Defender **Anderson, 27**, has left **Barrow by mutual consent** to join another **National League** side and may face his former club on **18 February**; he previously played for **Aldershot, Exeter**, and in **Italy**. Meanwhile, **21-year-old striker Keating**—recommended to **Torquay United (the Gulls)** manager **Kevin Nicholson** by ex-**Port Vale** boss **Micky Adams**—has signed from Irish clubs **Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps**, pending **international clearance**. Nicholson praised **Anderson’s leadership** despite his limited game time for his age and called **Keating** a **hungry, raw talent**. The **Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone** but have **one win in their last six matches**.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse **Many Clouds**, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, collapsed and died after winning the **Cotswold Chase** at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day, narrowly defeating **Thistlecrack** in a close finish. The **British Horseracing Authority (BHA)** confirmed the cause of death as a **"severe pulmonary haemorrhage"**, a rare but sudden condition that can affect seemingly healthy horses across equestrian disciplines. While Many Clouds had previously exhibited **post-race ataxia**—including overheating and unsteadiness—he showed no such symptoms during Saturday’s race and had no **significant underlying health issues**, per veterinary reports. A past winner of the **2015 Gold Cup trial** and **2014 Hennessy Gold Cup**, he was hailed by trainer **Oliver Sherwood** as the "horse of a lifetime." The BHA emphasized its commitment to further research into preventing such incidents, though the haemorrhage was deemed unrelated to his prior overheating episodes.

During an emotional final session before the 5 May election, veteran MSPs **Duncan McNeil (Labour)**, **Alex Salmond (SNP)**, and **Annabel Goldie (Conservative)** delivered valedictory speeches as they stepped down from the Scottish Parliament, alongside Presiding Officer **Tricia Marwick**, who was visibly moved. **Salmond**, Scotland’s first minister from 2007–2014, reiterated his belief in Scotland’s unity despite diverse views, praising the parliament’s growing responsibilities while criticizing the **Scotland Bill** for falling short of referendum promises; he humorously acknowledged competition from the UK budget and Cheltenham races before calling service in Holyrood the "greatest honour." **McNeil**, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must improve scrutiny and accountability, urging lessons from Westminster’s committee system to avoid "consequences." **Goldie** lightheartedly reflected on her sparring with Finance Secretary **John Swinney**, while **Marwick** honored Salmond’s "distinguished" service and was earlier tearful during McNeil’s farewell. The speeches blended nostalgia, political reflection, and calls for parliamentary reform.

A live-action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast* features an all-star cast, including an unnamed actress as Mrs. Potts (originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film), Kevin Kline as Maurice (Belle’s father), Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon (*Dreamgirls*, *Twilight*), the film begins production at Shepperton Studios in May 2016 and is set for a US theatrical release on **17 March 2017**.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce at an 11:00 BST meeting with victims' relatives whether charges will be brought against 23 suspects linked to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, which resulted in the unlawful killing of 96 football fans. The cases stem from two investigations: **Operation Resolve** (examining the disaster’s causes during the Liverpool vs. Nottingham Forest FA Cup semi-final) and an **Independent Police Complaints Commission probe** into the conduct of **South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police** in the aftermath. Evidence files were referred to the CPS in January, and families, including Margaret Aspinall—whose 18-year-old son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group—await the decision after decades of struggle, seeking **accountability**. The private meeting in Warrington, led by CPS special crime head **Sue Hemming**, marks a pivotal but emotionally complex moment, though Aspinall acknowledges the fight for justice may continue regardless of the outcome.

Chelmsford Prison has faced repeated incidents of contraband—including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis—being thrown over its walls, with a local resident reporting four such instances in two weeks, prompting the prison to organize a community meeting on safety measures. A former inmate described the jail as "notorious" for smuggling, claiming drones were used to deliver items directly to windows, though the Ministry of Justice denied drone activity at the site. While staff are said to work "extremely hard" to prevent contraband, the Justice Secretary has called for further measures to address the issue, including stricter laws that now allow up to two years’ imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages into prisons. A nearby resident expressed concern but not fear, noting increased vigilance like locking doors.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years of service, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright’s VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, admitted hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and couldn’t recall the traffic light color. Mrs Blackburn, a beloved mother-of-three, was escorting a woman and child across the road when the collision occurred; she now requires residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, stating he had devastated her life and family, while the court noted the sun was near setting, potentially affecting visibility. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast due to conflicting veterinary medicine exams in May, despite the event taking place in April. After finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships—where she set a personal best of 14:52.07—she expressed disappointment but prioritized completing her final year of university. While ruling out the Commonwealths, she eyes the **World Indoor Championships in March** as a potential target and remains optimistic about future Olympics, citing "so much scope" ahead. Muir also reflected on her strong performance in London, calling the competition "tough" but celebrating her progress after five races in 10 days, hinting at untapped potential.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, Ireland, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party, last seen walking home and captured on CCTV talking to an unidentified man in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, before returning to retrieve an umbrella. Enhanced CCTV footage released in April shows the same man following Deely shortly afterward on Haddington Road, though the man remains unidentifed despite police appeals. A search involving excavations began on Saturday in a three-acre woodland area near Chapelizod, Dublin, along the R112 close to the River Liffey, expected to last weeks. This follows a recent review of the case by six detectives, with gardaí renewing calls for the man in the footage to come forward.

Juan Martín del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year injury absence due to three wrist surgeries, staged a comeback to defeat Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in a Grand Slam return, marking his first major since the 2014 Australian Open. The 27-year-old Argentine, a former world number four and 2009 US Open champion, overcame a slow start to win in four sets, calling the victory emotional after years of setbacks. He next faces either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young and shares a draw half with Andy Murray. Meanwhile, Nick Kyrgios (seed 15) rallied from two sets down to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 in a rain-disrupted match, setting up a third-round clash with Feliciano Lopez, who also came back from two sets down to defeat Fabio Fognini. The winner will face either Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Elsewhere, Tomas Berdych (seed 10) and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga (seed 12) advanced with straight-sets wins.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to Caf after disputing a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, which they claimed was mishandled by an unfit referee—though they denied allegations of corruption. Morocco, initially banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, had their suspension overturned by Cas, reducing their fine from $1m to $50,000 and allowing their return to qualifying. Equatorial Guinea had stepped in as last-minute hosts for 2015, while both Tunisia and Morocco—now reconciled with Caf—prepared for the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive finals appearance. Morocco’s FA chief, Fouzi Lekjaa, expressed optimism about the future, downplaying the impact of their brief suspension.

McLaren, once a dominant force in Formula 1 with 182 grand prix wins, a 23.18% win rate, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, now struggles to secure even fourth place in the grid, despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 due to chassis design flaws, though they retained a strong engine, but current issues stem from an underperforming Honda power unit—a stark contrast to their past glory with Honda in the late 1980s, when they won 15 of 16 races in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. After periods of resurgence (notably with Mika Hakkinen in 1998–99) and scandals (like the 2007 Ferrari data theft and 2009 "lie-gate"), McLaren’s last constructors' title was in 1998. Founded by Bruce McLaren, the team’s history cycles between triumph and decline, with Ron Dennis playing a pivotal role in its revivals, though his recent return after 2013’s slump has yet to yield results. Dennis remains optimistic, claiming McLaren will end Mercedes’ dominance, but for now, their hopes rest on Honda’s engine improvements and Alonso’s pursuit of a third title, with only belief sustaining their legacy.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at **Joe’s Bar in Dungiven** at **06:00 BST on 6 October 2014**, with police arriving shortly after to find patrons still present and till receipts confirming alcohol was served until **04:49 BST**, outside legal hours. The court ordered the bar’s **three-month closure**, while **Colleen O’Neill (43)**, the license holder, was charged with **two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours** and fined **£3,000**, with the judge criticizing her **"appalling record"** and lamenting the lack of power to impose jail time. **James Thomas (44)**, of the same address, faced **one count of the same offense** and was fined **£1,000**. A defense solicitor admitted the premises were **poorly managed**, operating **well into the morning**, with local licensing laws **"not strictly adhered to"**, and the judge called it **"as bad a case as I have come across."**

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season (272, set in 2013) by hitting eight threes and scoring 45 points, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers after trailing by 13 points. Klay Thompson added 26 points, while LaMarcus Aldridge (27 points) and Damian Lillard (20 points) led Portland, who had already clinched the Northwest Division. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol recording 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Miami’s playoff hopes suffered as they were outscored 57-27 in the second half, with Dwyane Wade shooting just 4-for-20. The Bulls’ 39-8 third-quarter run secured their return to the Eastern Conference’s No. 3 spot.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were tricked into believing YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen was a competition winner visiting Melwood for a dead-ball masterclass, only to discover his exceptional skills firsthand. Van Velzen impressed the players with precise free-kicks, including a strike into the top corner, before Balotelli matched his effort. Known for his viral free-kick videos, van Velzen later revealed he enjoyed deceiving the players by initially pretending to be unskilled, calling the experience "amazing" and highlighting the satisfaction of their shocked reactions. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the forward’s infamous *"Why Always Me?"* slogan from his Manchester City days.

Women carrying the **BRCA1** gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by undergoing an **oophorectomy** (ovary removal), with a **62% lower mortality risk** observed in BRCA1 carriers, though not in BRCA2 carriers. A Canadian study of **676 breast cancer patients** with BRCA mutations found that those who had the procedure—especially within **two years of diagnosis**—saw a **73% reduction in death** compared to those who did not, with benefits lasting up to **15 years**. The surgery also lowered **all-cause mortality by 65%** and reduced ovarian cancer deaths, as nine cases occurred in women who retained their ovaries. BRCA1/2 mutations increase lifetime breast cancer risk to **50–80%**, with BRCA1-linked cancers often being **aggressive and drug-resistant**, particularly in **estrogen-receptor-negative** cases. While oophorectomy’s protective effects were immediate and sustained, researchers called for further studies, particularly on **BRCA2 carriers** and early-stage patients. The procedure is especially relevant for **Ashkenazi Jewish women**, among whom BRCA mutations are more common (**2.3%**). Genetic testing is available for high-risk individuals, and experts suggest oophorectomy should be considered **at diagnosis** for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Jolie, who underwent the surgery in **2015** (two years after a double mastectomy), emphasized feeling **empowered** by her choice.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak’s *Carolinian* train (No. 80) shortly before 10 AM on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, while lingering on tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers, caused no injuries among them, though one passenger fell ill during the subsequent delay. The Lowes, possibly homeless and living in a nearby camp, were pronounced dead at the scene; a scrap metal collector described them as struggling, noting their difficulty crossing the tracks with a grocery cart. The train resumed its route after a nearly three-hour delay, while Durham—located 25 miles northwest of Raleigh—marks a stop on the 13.5-hour Charlotte-to-NYC journey.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín Cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and later became a DEA informant for 27 years, helping dismantle major drug operations, including those of Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Though unpaid, he was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, which included global undercover stings, but the DEA has not fulfilled this promise. After retiring due to declining health, Toro now faces deportation and lives in the U.S. illegally, fearing execution if returned to Colombia. Despite support from his former DEA handler, who called the situation "government bureaucracy at its worst," Toro remains in limbo without a green card or passport, unable to access Social Security benefits, and may go into hiding as his temporary visa expired in January. He maintains he has atoned for his past and only seeks the citizenship he was promised.

The **Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN)**, the U.S. body regulating internet addresses, is investigating **Vox Populi Registry Ltd.**, a Canadian company accused of exploiting the new **".sucks" domain** to extract high fees—**$2,499 annually**—from celebrities like **Kevin Spacey** and major brands (e.g., **YouTube, Visa, Bank of America**) seeking to protect their reputations. Spacey and others, including **Taylor Swift** (who previously paid to remove her name from ".adult" domains), have reportedly paid to take down their ".sucks" sites. While Vox Populi defends its model as legal and a platform for corporate criticism, an **ICANN advisory panel** (backed by companies like **Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay**) called it a **"predatory shakedown scheme"**, noting the **$10 public rate** (starting September) contrasts sharply with the premium charged to trademark holders. ICANN has referred the case to **U.S. and Canadian regulators** to assess legality, threatening contract breaches if violations are found, while Vox Populi’s CEO insists the business complies with rules.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby boy was found in 1988 wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in a Norfolk village pond. The case remained unsolved until police exhumed the body in 2014 during a periodic review, using DNA from the baby’s leg bone to trace a relative through the national database, leading them to the mother. She admitted concealing her pregnancy, giving birth alone, and placing the stillborn baby in the pond, with no evidence of foul play. Initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, the charge was dropped after her account, though she remains on bail pending a decision on charges for failing to register the birth or prevent a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried as an "unknown boy," was reburied in 2014 with the name *Peter*—chosen from the church where he was laid to rest—after a support group for stillborn children funded a new headstone. Police confirmed no third-party involvement, closing the decades-old mystery through advancements in DNA technology.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered by the High Court to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, now 27, who suffered severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and requires lifelong care after jumping from Young’s moving taxi in Bath in 2010. Young, then 56, mistakenly believed Hicks and his girlfriend intended to avoid paying the fare and drove him back toward the taxi rank against his will, unlawfully imprisoning him for nearly a mile. Hicks, then 23, jumped from the vehicle at over 20mph, resulting in devastating injuries. The judge ruled Young liable but reduced the damages by 50%, citing Hicks’ decision to jump as a contributing factor, while awarding an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. The compensation, expected to be in the "hundreds of thousands," will fund Hicks’ ongoing rehabilitation and care, though the final amount is pending further hearings, with both sides granted permission to appeal. Hicks’ family, represented by lawyer James Davies, emphasized his permanent disabilities, including memory loss, behavioral issues, and reliance on 24-hour care from his mother.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms spawned reported tornadoes, including one spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, which moved northeast without hitting the city but threatened other areas. CNN’s severe weather expert warned of persistent storms and emphasized the heightened danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported near Aetna in southwestern Kansas, while Missouri’s Potosi (70 miles from St. Louis) experienced possible tornado damage, including fallen trees, roof destruction, and flooding, as shown in aerial footage and social media posts. Nearby, residents in Leington and Farmington documented severe weather, including baseball-sized hail. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River Valleys, and the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth straight win since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago and eyeing a title shot. Rockhold plans to aggressively pressure Machida, calling himself "the bull" to Machida’s "matador," by cutting off the cage, exploiting Machida’s weaknesses, and forcing a ground or multi-dimensional fight where he believes he holds a significant advantage. He respects Machida’s long-standing skill and style but insists he’ll dominate by overwhelming him with speed, takedowns, and striking versatility, having trained intensely with marathon-like conditioning. Meanwhile, Machida, coming off a win against CB Dollaway, remains confident in his technique and strategy, believing he can stop Rockhold if he executes his game plan. He acknowledges the title shot implications for the winner, noting his eight-week training camp with top partners like Glover Teixeira has left him well-prepared and calm, though he prefers assessing Rockhold’s weaknesses in the moment rather than predicting them.

A light general aviation Aerostar plane performed a gear-up (belly) landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, after the pilot failed to deploy the landing gear, causing the aircraft to skid along the runway on its belly with propellers striking the ground. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis—a veteran with nearly 50 years of flying experience—realized the mistake, applied full throttle, and managed a rough but successful takeoff despite damaged propellers and a high-angle climb, avoiding a stall. He then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, landing safely with his dog, Buddy, onboard. Witnesses described the harrowing sound of the propellers and belly scraping the runway, expressing surprise that the engines remained functional. The incident, attributed to either pilot error (forgetting to lower the gear) or potential mechanical failure, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré’s underwhelming performances this season but pledged to support the midfielder until the end of the campaign, despite reports that Manchester City will consider summer offers for the 31-year-old as part of a squad overhaul. Touré, earning £220,000-a-week with two years left on his contract, has faced criticism amid City’s poor Premier League title defense, with the team taking just 18 points from their last 39 available. Pellegrini dismissed calls to rest Touré, calling him a "very important player," while captain Vincent Kompany is sidelined with a muscle injury that could rule him out for the season. Goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted the players have underperformed, letting Pellegrini down, but affirmed the manager retains the dressing room’s backing. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce warned left-back Aaron Cresswell—targeted by City—to avoid repeating the mistakes of English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who saw limited game time after joining City. Ahead of their clash with West Ham, City risk falling further behind fifth-placed Liverpool, who could close the gap to one point with a win.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his 1999 seven-year sentence for *Cosa Nostra* membership was dropped due to Italian law, which extinguishes sentences after double the penalty time has passed. Though convicted in absentia for his role as a "man of honour" (taking bribes in Palermo), his case expired in October 2014, leading Italy to withdraw its European Arrest Warrant (EAW). Despite a 2013 extradition order—overturned initially over human rights concerns due to his heart condition—prolonged legal battles and a CPS procedural error in 2014 delayed proceedings, allowing his sentence to lapse. Rancadore, who lived in the UK for over 20 years under the alias *Marc Skinner*, faced criticism over the wasted resources, with legal experts questioning why Italy didn’t withdraw the EAW sooner. While his conviction technically stands pending a Supreme Court review, his solicitor confirmed he can now live freely in England with his family. The case highlights flaws in extradition processes, with Italy’s embassy citing the CPS’s missed appeal deadline as pivotal in the outcome.

**Mr Mole**, ridden by **AP McCoy** in the **Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday**, is one of three **7-2 co-favourites** in the seven-horse field, alongside **Special Tiara** (Irish raider) and **Sprinter Sacre** (trained by Nicky Henderson, ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty’s injury). This race marks **McCoy’s final Grade One ride** before retirement, with his full schedule for his last professional day confirmed by **Friday morning**. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement in February after winning aboard **Mr Mole at Newbury**. Other contenders in the race include **Mick Channon’s Somersby**.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia Trimble—who was raped and strangled in 1975 at age 13—recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter’s body after decades of avoidance, an experience she now regrets but describes in horrifying detail, including signs of severe trauma. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after her disappearance, hidden 150 yards from her home in a garage under a shower curtain, with evidence of sexual assault, strangulation, a fractured neck bone, and missing cookie money. Initially, police charged a 15-year-old neighbor in 1979, but charges were dropped due to lack of evidence, leaving the case unsolved for 33 years. Jerome Sydney Barrett, linked via DNA from Marcia’s clothing after his 2006 arrest for another 1975 murder, was convicted in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years for second-degree murder. Ritter, who had been advised by her late husband not to see the photos, now expresses a desire for revenge, stating she wished to kill Barrett after viewing the images. Barrett, a repeat offender with a history of sex crimes, had been imprisoned between 1974 and 2002, except for a brief period around Marcia’s murder.

Rory McIlroy considers it "unthinkable" that he won’t win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam, joining only five other players—Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods—in achieving all four major titles. The 25-year-old views Augusta National as a course where he can excel and even win multiple times, though his best finish in six appearances is joint eighth (2014). He calls his 2011 final-round collapse at the Masters—where he lost a four-shot lead with an 80—the "most important day of his career," crediting it with teaching him resilience, which helped him win his first major (the 2011 U.S. Open) just months later. Despite off-course distractions in 2014, including a called-off wedding and a costly legal dispute, McIlroy used golf as a "sanctuary" to focus, and he plans to do the same amid the hype of Augusta, emphasizing that his priority is playing his best without overthinking the historic stakes.

This week’s trending stories included a rare sighting of **four rainbows** appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by fashion CEO **Amanda Curtis**. In **rural China**, authorities cracked down on the practice of hiring **exotic dancers for funerals**, forcing families to seek alternative ways to entertain mourners. Actor **Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ)** grew visibly frustrated during a **Channel 4 interview** when questioned about his private life. A dangerous new social media trend, the **#KylieJennerChallenge**, emerged, where people **suck on jars** to plump their lips like Kylie Jenner. A **102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker**, relived her past through a filmmaker’s recreated performance, while a **prom proposal referencing bombs** sparked controversy, with the student accusing school administrators of **racism**. Casting news included **Ewan McGregor as Lumiere** in *Beauty and the Beast*, and **Johnny Depp’s unrecognizable transformation** in the *Black Mass* trailer. Creative pregnancy announcements and a **military dad’s prom photobomb** also went viral.

Last year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to brain damage caused by **foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS)**, a condition resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure, according to official health data, though experts warn the true number affected may be far higher. The **World Health Organisation (WHO)** estimates that at least **1 in 100 UK babies**—around **7,500 annually**—suffer learning, behavioral, or physical disabilities, such as deformed limbs, due to maternal alcohol use. The condition is **permanent and under-diagnosed**, with affected children facing lifelong challenges, as illustrated by **15-year-old Niamh Brown**, who struggles with basic tasks, lacks danger awareness, and will never live independently after being diagnosed at age five. Beyond FAS, prenatal alcohol exposure can cause **liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy**. While the UK government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol to **no more than two units twice a week**, advocates like **Elizabeth Mitchell** of the **National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome** argue for **total abstinence** during pregnancy to prevent irreversible harm.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender nicknamed "Boomerang Boy" for repeatedly returning home after crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 by wielding an axe at assistant Andrea Brighty. Shopkeeper Sab Dhillon tackled him, while his wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him as the struggle was caught on camera. Police arrived shortly after and arrested McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years. Known as a "one-man crime wave," McKerry had a lengthy criminal history, starting with shoplifting at 12, accumulating 80 arrests by 15, and convictions for burglary, vehicle theft, and indecent letters, including a spree where he stole 22 charity boxes dressed as a woman. His nickname stemmed from his habit of returning home post-crime, with 80 arrests in 1995 and 45 in just 36 weeks of freedom in 1998.

Four British Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman in her early 20s at a Canadian naval barracks in Nova Scotia following an alcohol-fueled party on April 10 after an ice hockey tournament. Released on bail of over £2,000 each, they must surrender their passports, remain in Nova Scotia, live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, and continue working for the Royal Navy while drawing their current pay. Their bail conditions prohibit contact with the victim and six witnesses, and they cannot leave the province or apply for new passports. The men, who appeared in a Dartmouth court, face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, carrying potential 14-year prison sentences. The investigation is ongoing, with forensic tests possibly leading to additional charges, and the British High Commission is cooperating with Canadian authorities. The accused have not requested extradition to the UK and must return to court on May 27.

Valerie Jackson’s four-year-old son, RJ, is one of only 70 people worldwide with **Netherton’s syndrome**, an extremely rare congenital skin disease causing his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly, often mistaken for burns or abuse. Despite requiring constant moisturizing with creams like Vaseline multiple times daily, RJ faces public scrutiny, including false child abuse reports—once leading to armed police confronting Valerie while shopping. The family endures cruel taunts, exclusion from public spaces, and ignorance, with adults often bullying RJ or accusing Valerie of harming him. Diagnosed as a newborn after a severe rash and skin peeling, RJ’s condition—linked to a genetic mutation—causes rapid moisture loss, infection risks, and chronic discomfort, though symptoms may improve with age. Valerie, supported by her husband Reginald, manages RJ’s care through online communities like a Facebook group for Netherton’s syndrome, where she found critical guidance. Despite the challenges, she cherishes RJ’s resilience and joy, hoping for greater awareness to reduce stigma as he grows.

Campaigners against Protein World’s controversial *"Are You Beach Body Ready?"* adverts—featuring a bikini-clad model, Renée Somerfield—are celebrating their removal from the London Underground after Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters would be taken down at the end of their prepaid three-week advertising period. The campaign sparked widespread backlash, with over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition, 200+ complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) for promoting unhealthy body images, and social media outrage over perceived sexism and unrealistic beauty standards. Many posters were defaced, and a protest in Hyde Park was planned, while Protein World defended the unretouched image, engaging in heated social media exchanges, including dismissive responses like *"we are a nation of sympathisers for fatties."* TV presenter Susanna Reid criticized the advert as *"anxiety-inducing,"* and the company’s marketing head, Richard Staveley, revealed police were investigating a bomb threat against them. Despite the controversy, Protein World called the campaign a success, refusing to alter future ads, while the ASA continues to assess complaints. Meanwhile, UK protein powder sales are surging, with figures expected to hit £358m by 2017. Supporters like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick praised the advert’s message, arguing it promoted fitness over body-shaming.

Rail companies faced criticism for planning significant fare increases—up to **87%**—just days after the general election, despite major parties pledging fare freezes. **First Great Western (FGW)** was urged by **Prime Minister David Cameron** to "urgently review" its decision to nearly double off-peak return fares (from **£33.30 to £62.40**) on the **London-to-Cotswolds route**, which passes through his Witney constituency, sparking outrage among locals. FGW justified the hike as aligning with other services but offered cheaper advance single tickets (potentially **£20 return**). Other steep increases include a **24.5%** rise for **Stafford-Liverpool anytime returns** (Virgin) and a **22%** hike for **Manchester-Stoke first-class returns**, though Virgin claimed most hikes affected its discounted "Virgin-only" fares, with an overall **1.65%** average increase. Critics noted the timing clashed with political promises, as **hundreds of "anytime" and off-peak fares rose by 40% in January**, particularly on rural routes. Train firms can adjust **unregulated fares** (half their revenue) three times yearly, covering off-peak and advance tickets.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier and retired HGV driver, was left permanently blind in his left eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his Oldham home on April 18, just three weeks after marrying his wife Elaine, 54. The couple were writing thank-you cards for wedding gifts when thugs began pelting their front window with stones; when Young opened the door to confront them, a brick hit his eye, causing an open forehead wound and irreversible vision loss despite emergency surgery. Police found no clear motive, suggesting it may have been "yobs messing around," and described the attack as reckless and life-altering. The couple, who met 14 months ago, now feel unsafe and plan to relocate to Southport, while officers urge witnesses to come forward. Young, a veteran of the Irish Troubles, expressed shock at the unprovoked violence, calling it senseless.

Tom Poynton, the 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension until the end of the 2016 season after successfully returning from a leg injury that sidelined him for the entire 2014 season. His absence followed a road accident in April 2014 in which his father, Keith, died, requiring ankle surgery and extensive rehabilitation. Poynton made his comeback during Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the upcoming season. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s resilience, hard work in training, and off-field preparation, expressing confidence in his form and hoping the new deal will boost his performance, noting his strong return in training and during the Abu Dhabi tour.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with **neuroblastoma**, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones after complaining of stomach pain. To cope with treatment, he decorated his radiotherapy protective mask like a **Ninja Turtle**, which helped him feel brave during 80 days of chemotherapy, a kidney tumour removal, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. His story gained global attention, leading **Nickelodeon** to send him Ninja Turtle gifts, and he later received a **Cancer Research UK Little Star Award**. After a year of grueling treatment, doctors declared Harley **cancer-free**, though he will undergo regular check-ups. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, expressed overwhelming joy, noting his rapid recovery and hopes for his return to school. Neuroblastoma, which affects fewer than **100 UK children annually**, typically arises in adrenal glands or nerve tissues and can spread widely; symptoms vary by tumour location, and treatment may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and stem cell transplants. Harley’s case has also raised awareness as part of **Cancer Research UK’s Kids & Teens campaign**.

Tim Sherwood advises **Jack Grealish**, the 19-year-old Aston Villa midfielder, to prioritize his club career over his international future amid a tug-of-war between **England and the Republic of Ireland** for his allegiance. Sherwood, impressed by Grealish’s standout performance in Villa’s **FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool**, emphasizes that the player must focus on securing his place in Villa’s first team before making an international decision, comparing it to his past experience with **Nabil Bentaleb**, who chose Algeria over France. Grealish, who has played for Ireland’s youth teams but remains eligible for England, is described as a **confident, skillful dribbler** who thrives under pressure, with Sherwood urging him to keep improving at club level. His father, **Kevin Grealish**, echoes this sentiment, stating that consistent performances for Villa will naturally lead to international opportunities. While Grealish is expected to decide between the two nations **at the end of the season**, he is currently **split on the choice**, with the possibility of featuring in upcoming friendlies for both sides.

Private jet travel is a luxury industry dominated by the wealthy, with landing fees at airports varying significantly, often reaching thousands per flight. The market is substantial, valued at $16.7 trillion in the U.S. and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights in the U.S. (2013) and 705,000 in Europe. Peak demand occurs during major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, where round-trip costs can exceed $50,000. The most expensive landing fees—based on a 767-400 aircraft—are led by Japan’s **Haneda Airport** (£4,559), followed by **Narita** (£3,728) and **Kansai** (£3,594), while other high-fee hubs include **Toronto Pearson** (£3,461), **Darwin** (£3,059), and **Bristol** (£2,929), the only UK airport in the top 10. Popular routes like **Los Angeles to Las Vegas** (£2,890) or **Milan to Rome** ($5,880) contrast with steep fees at these airports, highlighting unexpected hubs like **Salzburg** (£2,530) and **Dublin** (£2,729) as key destinations for private flyers.

A viral video shows **Cooper the Labrador** and his smaller companion **Daisy** enjoying a McDonald’s ice cream at a drive-thru, where Daisy delicately licks her portion while Cooper devours his entire cone in one bite—a habit his owner, **Katie Gallegos** of Clackamas County, Oregon, notes is typical for him due to his fast eating. Gallegos, who runs **Dogpatch Resort**, ensures Daisy eats first to accommodate Cooper’s voracious appetite, though she defends the occasional treat, citing Cooper’s excellent health and her late 19-year-old dog’s similar weekly ice cream routine. The video, viewed over **seven million times**, sparked mixed reactions, with some calling it "cute" and others criticizing the treat choice, but Gallegos clarifies the dogs also enjoy **Starbucks "pup-uccinos"** (whipped cream in a cup), which Cooper likewise inhales whole. She emphasizes the treats are infrequent and harmless, with Daisy receiving only small amounts due to her size.

Gary Locke, the 41-year-old interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed permanently after signing a three-year deal, following a strong interim period where he lost just once in seven games. Initially joining as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer, Locke took over as interim manager in early February after Johnston’s departure. His official announcement will be addressed at a press conference on Friday morning, marking his transition from former Hearts boss to Kilmarnock’s permanent leader.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, over the use of **DoTERRA essential oils** (lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood) she applies to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers claimed the oils’ smell was distracting to other students, and Kemp received a letter from the school board calling it a "problem," though she argued no one had been removed from the classroom due to the scent. Despite the school’s initial warnings, the **Lake County School District later clarified Logan would not be suspended**, framing it as a "health issue." Kemp vowed to continue using the oils, questioning why natural scents were prohibited while chemical alternatives were acceptable, and stated the oils had benefited her son all year until a teacher’s aide complained.

A fire destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, the Hamptons, on Wednesday at 3 PM, obliterating 90 condos in the Sandpiper complex before the building collapsed. The blaze, of unknown origin, was so intense it melted paint off nearby structures and sent smoke visible from three miles away, with flames erupting from every window. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire but couldn’t enter the summer homes, instead using cranes due to the inferno’s strength. The complex, used seasonally from May to November, housed residents like Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, who lost everything. Witnesses described seeing massive flames and black smoke, while Westhampton Fire Chief Ross Donneson noted offshore winds aided visibility during firefighting efforts. Investigators are probing claims the fire may have started near a parked car.

At 88 (nearing her 89th birthday), Queen Elizabeth II was seen riding her black Fell pony, *Carltonlima Emma*, in Windsor Great Park, accompanied by a groom and wearing her signature silk scarf instead of a helmet—a lifelong habit she attributes to her hairstyle. A passionate equestrienne since age four when she received her first Shetland pony, *Peggy*, she has owned notable horses like *Betsy* (her 1950s mount) and *Surprise* (ridden at Ascot in 1961), though she has reduced riding due to a knee injury. Despite this, she remains actively involved in breeding horses, including Fell and Highland ponies at Hampton Court and Balmoral, with some now ridden by her grandchildren. Fell ponies, an ancient breed from Cumbria prized since the Neolithic era, were historically used by Romans, Vikings, and Normans for trade, labor, and transport, evolving into the sturdy 13–14hh animals known today for their gentle temperament, making them ideal for families—and a favored breed of the Queen.

A noise dispute between two Brisbane neighbors turned fatal when **Leon Yeaman, 55**, was allegedly killed by a single punch from **Phillip Pama, 28**, during a late-night confrontation outside their North Brisbane homes. Yeaman, described as a generous but schizophrenic pensioner known for loud music and drunk behavior, was in his yard making noise around 9 PM on Thursday, disturbing Pama—a married father of three working a 3 AM warehouse shift who was trying to sleep. Pama’s lawyer claimed he acted "blindly" after being pushed, delivering the fatal punch that paramedics could not revive Yeaman from, declaring him dead at the scene by 11 PM. Pama, with no prior violent history, was granted conditional bail on Friday, facing manslaughter charges, with restrictions including a curfew (6 PM–2 AM), passport surrender, and twice-weekly police check-ins. The case is set to return to court on **May 18**, with Pama reportedly overwhelmed by grief.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, was arrested for attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year-long relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) to a friend to arrange the killing, specifying that Vanya should be beaten—with broken arms and legs—tortured to cause kidney damage and slow bleeding, and left in agony before she "finished" him herself. Police conducted a sting operation, filming her instructions to an undercover officer posing as the hitman, before arresting her in her car after she handed over partial payment. Simonova, who had previously showered Vanya with gifts, now faces up to 15 years in prison for attempted murder, while Vanya expressed relief and hoped she would remain imprisoned indefinitely.

José Mourinho, then Chelsea FC manager, revealed in a 2014 interview with *The Daily Telegraph* that he maintains a strong personal faith, praying daily and speaking to God—though never about football—while separating his professional and family life. The 52-year-old father of two, known for his competitive sideline persona, emphasized his commitment to family, friends, and philanthropy, including work as an ambassador for the World Food Programme against hunger, citing his awareness of poverty. Though he admits to professional mistakes due to the emotional and competitive nature of football, he insists his personal life defines him more, describing himself as a good person who supports even strangers. Mourinho attends church irregularly, primarily when in Portugal, and avoids discussing football in prayers, despite Chelsea’s then-top league position and his prior £25,000 fine for alleging a "campaign" against the club. He also highlighted his family’s involvement in public events, like the *Hunger Games* premiere, while his son celebrated Chelsea’s Capital One Cup victory with players.

Bob Barker, the legendary host of *The Price Is Right* for 35 years before retiring in 2007, made a surprise return to the show on its April 1 edition, marking his first appearance in eight years. At 91 years old, Barker temporarily took over hosting duties from current host Drew Carey, leading the iconic "Lucky Seven" pricing game before handing the reins back to Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared energetic and effortless, demonstrating his enduring connection to the game show he once helmed. Contestants were greeted with the familiar call to "come on down!" as Barker briefly revived his signature role.

Arthur Baldwin, an off-duty U.S. Secret Service agent assigned to the **Foreign Missions Branch** (which supports U.S. diplomatic activities under the State Department), was arrested in **southeast Washington, D.C., at 12:30 AM Friday** on the **3200 block of D Street SE** after allegedly attempting to break into a home. He faces **felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property** and was arraigned Friday afternoon, though no attorney is listed in court records. The Secret Service **revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave** following the arrest. This incident follows another recent scandal within the agency: a **high-ranking supervisor was placed on leave two days prior** amid misconduct allegations under investigation by the **Homeland Security Inspector General**, while two senior officials are also being probed for a **March 4 drunk-driving incident** involving a breach of a secure White House area. The cases further damage the agency’s reputation, which is tasked with protecting the president and first family.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a hungry male lion in Lahore’s Safari Park by approaching within 10 feet of the animal while armed only with his camera. After spotting the lion from a distance, Saeed left his car—with the door open—and lay on the ground to capture close-up shots, aiming to showcase the lion’s "character and status." However, the camera’s shutter noise alerted the lion, which aggressively lunged at him, forcing Saeed to hastily retreat into his car.
