Though he initially laughed off the near-miss, he later admitted the encounter was dangerously close and doubted he would repeat such a risky stunt. The entire incident unfolded in mere seconds.

The NYPD has released an image of a distinctive heart-shaped tattoo with the name *"Monique"* on the leg of an unidentified woman found dead on a Brooklyn street nearly a month ago to aid in her identification. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on **March 22** near **Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue** in the **Gravesend** section of Brooklyn and was pronounced dead after paramedics failed to revive her. She carried no identification, but investigators believe the faded tattoo—a ribbon inside a heart topped with a rose—originally read *"Monique."* The cause of death remains undetermined pending a medical examiner’s report, and authorities urge anyone with information to contact **NYPD Crime Stoppers** at **800-577-TIPS**.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned from the UK in 2009 with limited funds and unable to afford traditional property, so they built a self-sufficient home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over a year and a half. The solar-powered, two-bedroom dwelling—constructed with wood and steel—features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and gas-powered hot water, while water is sourced from a nearby spring. Costing around $25,000, the home sits on a lot in Nelson, surrounded by nature, with their first power bill totaling just $25. The couple, who live there with their cat, prioritized natural materials for comfort and plan to replicate the project in the future, embracing a minimalist, off-grid lifestyle.

Researchers found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who don’t use them or use them individually. The study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 kindergarten students in a Midwestern suburban school district over an academic year. Shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher than peers with individual devices or no iPads at all, suggesting that **collaborative learning around technology**—not just collaboration alone—drove the improvement. Blackwell recommends schools rethink how tablets are used, particularly in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness, with findings set to be presented at the 65th International Communication Association conference. The results contrast with skepticism from some educators, like the National Association of Head Teachers' general secretary, who questioned technology’s role in non-IT classes.

A two-legged piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after a viral video showed it learning to walk upright on its front trotters, wobbling but regaining balance despite near-falls. Nicknamed "Super Pig," the resilient animal forages for food with its snout to the ground and interacts playfully with its fully legged siblings, drawing crowds of curious villagers since birth. Farmer Ms. Duan discovered the piglet’s condition when it struggled to feed, noting its missing hind legs upon inspection. The piglet’s story echoes a similar case in China, where a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also gained fame for hopping on its front paws, attracting tourists in Guangxi Province.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone’s car during a pit stop on lap 25. Dracone, who had pitted for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips’ leg, causing a cut that required stitches at the infield care center before Phillips was released. The race faced traction issues due to heavy rain before the start, contributing to challenging conditions. Dracone, a 19-year-old Italian driver, later spun out on Turn 1 and did not finish, placing 23rd.

CCTV footage captured Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdering his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), 29, in Rio de Janeiro by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times at point-blank range. Severiano confessed to the killing, citing jealousy over men looking at her, and had earlier called her a "slut" during an argument just four days into their marriage. A neighbor, Lelio Maya Puga, heard the violent dispute and gunshots, noting Sena was part of the dance group *Jaula das Gostozuedas*. After the murder, Severiano fled in a stolen car—crashing it before police arrested him—where they found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest. He now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, the 41-year-old journalist and best-selling author of *I Quit Sugar*, revealed in a candid interview with *Women’s Weekly Australia* her severe struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, which once drove her to the brink of suicide. She described feeling existentially hopeless, unable to see a way out due to a combination of stress, thyroid disease, isolation, and lack of family support, compounded by societal pressures like not having a husband or children. Wilson emphasized the intrinsic link between anxiety and depression, calling anxiety the "new depression" and highlighting that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, often leading to depressive episodes. While she now accepts her chronic anxiety and has found some peace, she recalled feeling alone in her youth, as if she lacked a "guidebook to life" while others coped effortlessly. The passage also includes helpline contacts for mental health support.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was initially charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after striking her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar upon finding her injecting heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge in 2016, citing Curtin’s justification under Oregon law, which permits physical force against an intruder refusing to leave a residence. The ex-girlfriend, described as "jealous and bitter," had allegedly harassed Curtin for years, including threats, theft, and attempts to relapse the boyfriend—who had a history of heroin use and a child with the ex. Curtin, who gave birth in January 2015, avoided a potential six-year prison sentence; she has since left the relationship, moved in with her parents, and distanced herself from the boyfriend, who is no longer involved in their child’s life. The ex-girlfriend and boyfriend later reconciled.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust when her owner sneaked a broccoli spear among her treats, immediately spitting it out after chewing. The video humorously highlights her dislike for the vegetable, raising concerns that the two children she lives with might mimic her behavior instead of eating their greens. Beyond her picky eating, Gemma is shown enjoying sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic site instead of the defunct **Young Entrepreneur Awards** page, which was scrapped in 2011. The awards’ URL, originally hosted under *hsbc.com.hk*, expired and was later taken over by the adult site, causing users clicking the link to be redirected to explicit content. The bank removed the hyperlink upon discovering the error and issued a public apology on **April 20**, clarifying it had no affiliation with the external site and emphasizing its main website remained secure. HSBC’s statement reassured customers that its internet banking services—including account management, transfers, loans, and insurance—were unaffected by the incident.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, calmly guided firefighters via a **911 call** while trapped in a second-floor bedroom with his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, after a fire broke out on the first floor of their Clinton home early Sunday. He provided clear instructions—directing rescuers to a black door in the back hallway—while reassuring his panicked sister to "stay low" and breathe. Firefighters from **Prince George’s County** broke a window to reach them; **Lt. Kenny Ward** handed Marcus to another rescuer and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah after she tugged his leg. Both siblings were hospitalized with **non-life-threatening injuries**, while their mother, older brother, and stepfather escaped separately and were treated at **MedStar Hospital**. Officials praised the **heroic efforts** of the firefighters and Marcus’s composure during the **11-minute call**, calling the rescue an extraordinary act.

Stunning images of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia’s east coast, particularly in **Jervis Bay (NSW South Coast)**, reveal a mesmerizing neon glow on popular beaches. Photographer **Andy Hutchinson** called the phenomenon a *"beautiful supernatural scene"* caused by millions of light-emitting plankton. The glow is produced by **noctiluca scintillans**, a carnivorous, single-celled phytoplankton that preys on diatoms and emits light as a defense mechanism. Oceanography expert **Iain Suthers (UNSW)** noted these blooms typically occur naturally in **spring and autumn**, with 90% of cases linked to non-harmful causes, as seen previously at **Sydney’s Manly Beach in 2014**.

New genetic tests like **EndoPredict** can identify breast cancer patients who may avoid chemotherapy by analyzing tumor genetic markers to assess aggressiveness and recurrence risk. After surgery, lab screening determines if a patient has a low (as low as 5%) or high risk of cancer returning, with some low-risk cases showing outcomes comparable to or better than chemotherapy. While chemotherapy is routinely given post-tumor removal to prevent recurrence, its severe side effects—hair loss, nausea, fatigue, and more—often make it more feared than surgery. Experts argue many women may not need it, and a low **EndoPredict** score allows patients to forgo treatment. Most tests cost around **£2,500** privately, though surgeons advocate for NHS adoption due to potential cost savings from reduced chemotherapy use. **Becca Cornford**, a 49-year-old mother, avoided chemotherapy after testing revealed a 5% recurrence risk, with monitoring deemed sufficient. Surgeons like **Professor Kefah Mokbel** emphasize these tests enable informed decisions, moving away from the previous one-size-fits-all chemotherapy approach.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from *HMS Ocean* and at least one from *HMS Illustrious* (nicknamed *HMS Lusty*), with 18 other ships also recording emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, implying pregnancies likely occurred before boarding or during leave. This follows the 2015 case of Commander Sarah West, the first female Royal Navy warship captain, who was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member, prompting an investigation. Women have served on Navy ships since 1990, with females making up 9% of personnel in 2014, and in 2015, three became the first female submariners. Additionally, nearly 100 British servicewomen were sent home from Afghanistan (2006–2013) and 102 from Iraq due to pregnancy, as military rules prohibit pregnant personnel from war zones, with most conceptions likely occurring pre-deployment.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium—likely from a nuclear reactor—was found on the roof of Japan’s prime ministerial residence in Tokyo, sparking fears of potential drone-based terrorism. The discovery coincided with a court’s approval to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear plant, a contentious move opposed by many Japanese due to safety concerns following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. The small drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing harmless but detectable cesium, was investigated by police, though its origin remains unclear. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga warned of future terrorism risks, particularly ahead of the Olympics and G7 summit, urging stricter drone regulations. Current laws ban drone flights near airports but impose no restrictions over government buildings, including the prime minister’s residence, where Shinzo Abe was absent during the incident.

A security guard in Zhejiang Province, China, named Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother—who suffers from Alzheimer’s—to work with him every day on his motorbike after she repeatedly got lost while alone, including once when collecting firewood in the mountains. Since his father’s death earlier this year and with his wife working in another city and his son still in school, Lu has no other caregiver for her. He wakes her at 5 a.m., secures her on the bike with a sash, and rides slowly over four kilometers (taking an hour) to ensure her safety and comfort, even chatting with her during the trip. At work, his employer, a bank, provides her a private room, but Lu frequently checks on her to prevent her from wandering. He views his devotion as repayment for her lifelong care, recalling how she carried him as a child while working in the fields, and expresses deep emotional attachment, stating, *“I was an apple in my mum’s eye, and now she’s my apple.”* He admits he only feels at ease when she’s in sight, fearing she might wander off otherwise.

A major study by the University of Washington’s Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by **17.2%** between 2005 and 2012, driven largely by rising rates among women due to shifting social norms. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding **one drink per day for women and two for men** on average, while binge drinking is **four or more drinks for women and five for men** in a single occasion at least once a month. Nationally, **8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers in 2012**, with women’s binge drinking rates rising **seven times faster** than men’s over the decade. County-level data showed stark variations, from **2% heavy drinkers in Hancock County, Tennessee**, to **22% in Esmeralda County, Nevada**, and binge drinking rates ranging from **6% in Madison County, Idaho**, to **36% in Menominee, Wisconsin**. Experts attribute the trends to cultural shifts (e.g., greater acceptance of women drinking like men), economic factors (cheaper alcohol, affluent professionals in high-stress jobs), weakened alcohol control policies, and increased advertising ($3.45 billion spent in 2011). Alcohol-related deaths reached **88,600 in 2010**, costing over **$220 billion annually**, while treatment centers report rising addiction cases, though many delay seeking help until facing severe consequences.

UN officials, including the World Health Organisation (WHO), warn that doctors are unnecessarily performing caesarean sections, putting women and babies at risk of infections, complications, disability, or death. The procedure should only be done when medically necessary, yet over 25% of births in England now involve caesareans—a rate more than double that of the early 1990s—far exceeding the WHO’s recommended 10–15%. Factors driving the increase include women opting for planned caesareans due to severe childbirth anxiety (tokophobia), age over 40, prior complicated births, or conditions like asthma or diabetes. The WHO criticizes current NHS guidelines, which permit caesareans without medical justification, noting the procedure costs the NHS £2,369 (vs. £1,665 for natural birth) and diverts resources from other patients. Research shows up to 10% of caesareans lead to infections, yet doctors often underestimate the risks.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into an $800,000 summer home in Edgartown on Martha’s Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners’ belongings in a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after homeowner Mark Conklin found her in his living room, where she falsely claimed ownership before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup. Police later discovered a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested Filkins hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home. A construction worker reported seeing her selling or giving away items, including furniture, lamps, a Weber grill, and a painting by the owner. Police urged anyone who purchased stolen items to return them, assuring assistance in seeking restitution, and provided a contact number (508-627-4343) for tips. Filkins’ next court date is May 14.

Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend’s birthday party on Saturday night, and it was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border the next morning. Officers, realizing the phone was unlocked, posted humorous selfies, puns, and updates on Bella’s Facebook page—including photos of the phone in a "holding cell"—to track her down, joking about charging it in a "cell" and offering early "release for good behaviour." Bella, unaware of the posts, arrived at 1 PM after a security guard directed her there, and officers recognized her from her Facebook profile without needing her name. The playful posts went viral among her friends, who praised the police’s creative approach, while officers even replied to her friends’ texts in the same humorous tone. Bella laughed at the antics, thanked the police for their humor, and later secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed after being caught in a violent fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. The calf strayed into the conflict and was grabbed by one of the brawling males, flung into the air, and dragged through the water while its mother watched helplessly. Despite her attempts to intervene—including attacking the aggressor—the sub-adult hippo bit down harder and tossed the calf, which later died from its injuries. The mother had earlier kept her distance from the fight, possibly to avoid harm, but her decision proved fatal for the calf, as the males had been battling for some time. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the horrific incident, noting the mother’s prior efforts to protect her baby from younger hippos before the tragic outcome.

A three-bedroom, 1,990 sq/ft maisonette in London’s exclusive Knightsbridge—one of Britain’s priciest areas—is on sale for just £575,000, but with only three years remaining on its lease, making the annual cost £191,000 (or £15,000/month, comparable to local rents). The "unmodernised" property, requiring renovations, includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, parking, and a communal garden, but its value could surge to £6 million if the lease is extended. A second, larger maisonette (2,500 sq/ft) in the same building is listed for £595,000, also with three years left. Extending the lease—likely costing £3.35–£4.5 million for 90 years—would align with Knightsbridge’s typical prices (£2,750–£3,000 per sq/ft), but the current short lease reflects a rare opportunity, attracting developers and locals. Built in 1893 with high-quality architecture, Egerton Place historically housed elite figures like Sir Evan MacGregor, though experts warn buyers of steep lease-extension costs and advise against letting leases expire. The freeholder, believed to be the Welcome Trust, would negotiate any extension.

Starbucks experienced a widespread computer outage on Friday evening, disrupting point-of-sale registers at **8,000 stores** (7,000 in the U.S. and 1,000 in Canada), forcing many locations to close early or give away free drinks and baked goods since they couldn’t process credit card payments—though some still accepted cash. The outage, caused by a **failure during a daily system refresh**, began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast, prompting social media buzz as customers shared photos of free beverages. While some stores remained open, others shut down to avoid free giveaways, leading to mixed reactions among customers. Starbucks resolved the issue by Saturday, resuming normal operations, and apologized for the inconvenience, noting the glitch also affected **Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores**. The incident occurred just a day after the company reported **record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion**, with shares rising 4.4% to $51.50.

Terrorist training and radicalization activities have been identified in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Extremists engage in seemingly ordinary community activities while harboring hidden agendas, with incidents dating back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, a rugged terrain also used by British military forces like the SAS. Notable cases include the 7/7 bombers white-water rafting in North Wales (2005) and a 2010 plot by Cardiff-based extremists inspired by Al-Qaeda. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Llanybydder, linked to Iraqi clerics. Secret meetings among extremists have also been documented in Welsh country parks, with DC Jones emphasizing the importance of community intelligence in countering these threats.

A rare Omura’s whale, previously feared extinct, was discovered washed ashore on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn—marking the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. Initially misidentified, the 5.68-meter juvenile female was confirmed via DNA testing by the Department of Parks and Wildlife. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the find "highly significant" due to the species' obscurity; Omura’s whales were first scientifically described in 2003 and are typically found in tropical and subtropical waters, such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale’s unique traits include a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass was buried for later skeletal recovery, aiming to enhance field identification guides, study regional distribution, and potentially display the remains in museums.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, argued that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to hormonal concerns, claiming women’s biology makes them unfit for leadership, despite supporting equal rights. Critics countered that male hormones—like testosterone—have historically impaired male leaders’ judgment, with studies showing women take fewer unnecessary risks. The debate highlights deeper gender bias in leadership, where women face systemic barriers despite qualifications, as evidenced by workplace disparities (e.g., more male CEOs named John than total female CEOs) and stereotypes (e.g., women labeled "nice" while men are called "geniuses"). Experts like Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg emphasize that gender equality benefits economies, families, and businesses, yet biases persist, making Clinton’s presidential bid harder. Rios’ claim—echoing outdated views—ignores Canada’s female prime minister (Kim Campbell) and the broader evidence that gender bias, not biology, limits women’s potential.

Veteran actor **Robert Hardy, 89**, is auctioning over **200 antiques**—worth up to **£100,000**—as he downsizes his home, including rare items like a **hand-painted 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt** (estimated £4,000–£6,000), a **yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle**, a **portrait of himself holding a longbow**, **Victorian furniture**, **swords**, **flintlock rifles**, **17th-century books**, and **crystal chandeliers**. A **military history enthusiast** who studied under **J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis** at Oxford, Hardy is an expert on the **medieval longbow** and consulted on the **Mary Rose shipwreck** recovery. Known for roles like **Siegfried Farnon in *All Creatures Great and Small***, **Winston Churchill in multiple dramas**, and **Cornelius Fudge in *Harry Potter***, he retired from stage acting after a fall but continues TV work. The auction, handled by **Dominic Winter in Gloucestershire**, reflects his lifelong passion for **literature and history**, though he expressed sadness at parting with his "treasured library."

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man with a history of bipolar disorder, prior battery on law enforcement, and a past involuntary psychiatric commitment, is a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found in their Winter Garden home on Saturday after a well-being check revealed foul play. Shemansky, already on parole, disappeared the same day he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son, which neighbors suggest his mother may have blocked to prevent further legal trouble amid his contentious divorce. His estranged wife, who filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago, is now preparing for potential confrontation, while authorities confirm they have the murder weapon but have not disclosed the cause of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication after allegedly asking for water at a trailer park office shortly after the killing; police urge the public to report any sightings to 407-656-3636.

The city of **Eugene, USA**, was awarded the **2021 IAAF World Championships** after the **IAAF Council** bypassed the standard bidding process, citing a **"unique strategic opportunity"** to host the event in the U.S. for the first time. Eugene had previously lost its bid for the **2019 championships** to **Doha, Qatar**, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of its capability. IAAF President **Lamine Diack** emphasized the decision’s strategic value, highlighting unprecedented collaboration between **public authorities, the private sector, the U.S. Olympic Committee, NBC, and local public support** to access a key market and advance global athletics. The **2007 championships in Osaka, Japan**, were also awarded without a bid, while **Mo Farah** won gold in the **men’s 10,000m at the 2013 Moscow championships**.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, after luring him into a "pitiless and wicked" fatal robbery. Granger targeted Hassan—known for flashing cash at London casinos—by befriending him under the alias "Rachel," exploiting his generosity (gifts, cash, and luxury outings) before orchestrating his murder. On the night of the attack, she left his Islington flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend **Kyrron Jackson (28)** and accomplice **Nicholas Chandler (29)** to enter, tie up Hassan, and kick him to death while ransacking his home for hidden winnings (they stole £3,000, a TV, and his phone). Jackson and Chandler—both from southeast London—were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a 36-year minimum for the "brutal" attack, part of a broader crime spree including armed casino robberies. Granger, who claimed she acted out of love for Jackson, was found guilty by a 10-2 majority and condemned by the judge for her deceit and lack of compassion. Hassan, a divorced father of three who kept large sums in his flat (including in his microwave), was discovered dead with multiple broken bones, bound and face-down in his blood. His family called his death a "ruthless greed"-fueled tragedy that would "haunt them forever." All three defendants were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan.

Cesc Fàbregas, Chelsea’s Spanish midfielder, has faced criticism for his declining form in the second half of the season, continuing a trend noted during his time at Barcelona, where his performances traditionally dipped post-Christmas. After a strong start to the 2014-15 campaign—where he looked set to break Thierry Henry’s Premier League assist record (20 in a season)—his contributions have waned, with just one assist in his last five league games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. Despite his struggles, including a poor showing in Spain’s 2-0 defeat to Holland, Chelsea remain on track for the Premier League title, with Fàbregas still a key player in their run-in. Manager José Mourinho will hope his recent assist for Diego Costa signals a resurgence, as Chelsea face six of the nine remaining teams Fàbregas has already set up goals against this season. While fatigue and a grueling schedule appear to have affected his durability, his late-season form could be pivotal in securing the title.

West Ham are in advanced discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward **Deshane Beckford**, a highly rated prospect from Montego Bay United who impressed during a two-week trial with the club’s academy. The skilful forward, considered one of the Caribbean’s top emerging talents, has also attracted interest from Belgian clubs and other European sides. Meanwhile, West Ham announced that **season tickets at their new Olympic Stadium** for the **2016-17 Premier League season** will start at **£289**, the lowest pricing in the league, as part of a strategy to fill the **54,000-capacity venue**.

Police dropped an investigation into the violent assault on **Mike Lane, 40**, joint master of the **Tedworth Hunt**, just three months after the attack, despite substantial evidence, including a **video**, **suspect names**, and **car registrations** provided to **Wiltshire Police**. On **January 24**, balaclava-clad protesters armed with **iron bars on ropes** and **citronella spray** ambushed Lane and 30 hunters—who were tracking an **artificial scent**, not a fox—near **Everleigh, Amesbury**. Lane was **kicked in the head**, suffering **concussion, broken teeth, memory loss**, and facial swelling, with his attacker’s face captured on film. Police **shelved the case due to "insufficient evidence,"** sparking outrage from Lane, witnesses like **Karen Fieldsend**, and hunt supporters, who accused authorities of **failing to act** compared to urban assaults. The **Countryside Alliance** is pushing to **ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings**, while Wiltshire Police stated the case remains **undetected but could reopen** if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, known as the "American mouthpiece" of al Qaeda, was a prominent English-language propagandist for the terrorist group before being killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January 2015 at age 36, though he was not specifically targeted. Born in 1978 as Adam Pearlman to a Jewish family in California, he converted to Islam in 1995, left for Pakistan in 1998, and joined al Qaeda, adopting the name Abu Suhayb. He rose to prominence post-9/11, appearing in videos threatening attacks on Western targets, urging lone-wolf violence in the U.S., and praising acts like the Fort Hood shootings and Benghazi attack. Indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda, he was among the FBI’s most-wanted terrorists. His final video (2014) called for overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. Gadahn’s death was announced alongside that of another U.S. al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, while a separate strike accidentally killed U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto. Documents from Osama bin Laden’s compound later revealed Gadahn’s role in shaping al Qaeda’s media strategy.

Chinese parents are known for their enthusiasm in nurturing child prodigies, and a new basketball sensation has emerged in the form of five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, whose viral video showcases his extraordinary skills—dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, scoring effortlessly, and maintaining flawless rhythm. Mai has been playing since age two and a half, earning widespread admiration across basketball-obsessed China, where he’s compared to the country’s most famous NBA star, Yao Ming. Netizens have flooded the video with reactions, from disbelief ("special effects!") to awe ("who is his father?") and even self-deprecating humor, with some lamenting their own skills in contrast to the child’s talent. His performance has cemented his status as a rising star, captivating fans nationwide.

Tom O’Carrol, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE)—a notorious 1970s-80s group that campaigned to legalize child sex and lower the age of consent to 10—has become a supporter of the media pressure group *Hacked Off*, which advocates for state-backed press regulation following the Leveson Inquiry. O’Carrol, jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and once part of the National Council for Civil Liberties’ (NCCL) gay rights sub-committee (which also pushed to legalize incest), attended a *Hacked Off* rally in Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs, chaired by comedian John Cleese. His involvement risks embarrassing *Hacked Off*, which opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation as "biased" and seeks statutory media oversight, while defending the public nature of its events.

On Thursday, Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained to host **Ten Pieces’** Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia show, displacing regular lap swimmers. The empty pool served as a striking catwalk, with models parading through it and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop under clear skies and 28°C heat. **Ten Pieces**, a unisex lifestyle brand co-founded by Icebergs restaurateur **Maurice Terzini** and **Lucy Hinckfuss**, showcased a **monochrome capsule collection** of **10 versatile pieces** designed to be styled **20 ways** for day-to-night wear, emphasizing **minimalist, androgynous** designs. Guests enjoyed food from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria, while beachgoers and passersby stopped to watch the unconventional fashion spectacle.

Bolton-born boxer **Amir Khan** spent a family day at **Six Flags Discovery Kingdom**, a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with and fed a rare **white tiger**, as well as interacted with **giraffes and sea lions**, accompanied by his wife **Faryal Makhdoom Khan** and daughter **Lamysa**. The **28-year-old** also recently announced his next fight, confirming he will face former **light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri** on **May 30** at welterweight, ending speculation about potential bouts against rivals like **Kell Brook**, **Adrien Broner**, or **Keith Thurman**. Khan had faced pressure to fight Brook but stated he was already in advanced negotiations for a different opponent.

The name of **Mohammed Abu Khdeir**, a 16-year-old Palestinian beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was briefly added to Israel’s **Mount Herzl memorial wall**—which honors fallen soldiers and terrorism victims—ahead of Memorial Day, accompanied by an Israeli flag and symbolic flowers. His family, led by his father **Hussein Abu Khdeir**, objected, stating no permission was given and rejecting his son’s inclusion among "soldiers of the occupation." The **Almagor terror victims’ organization** also opposed the addition, arguing Abu Khdeir’s killing was an isolated "rogue attack" and not terrorism, demanding his name’s removal in a letter to Israel’s **National Insurance Institute**, which oversees the memorial. After complaints, the institute confirmed the name would be removed, and it was already deleted from the memorial’s website. Meanwhile, a **judicial panel** began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir’s killing.

A California-based YouTuber named Lionel Hutz captured his young son playfully chasing the family cat around the garden, attempting to use the cat’s belly as a pillow for rest. In the footage, the cat is seen grooming itself before the boy plops down on top, only for the feline to quickly move away after a brief pause. The child persistently follows, repeating the action twice more until the cat, seemingly annoyed, retreats indoors. Later, the two reconcile, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats, showing their bond despite the earlier playful struggle.

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer, including allegations that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest—charges later expunged after probation. Though he passed a background check when hired in 2010, school officials were unaware of his criminal history, which also includes a 2011 arrest (resulting in four years’ probation) and a 2008 DUI guilty plea. Kushner claims he never intended to deceive the school and considers his past a "bad phase" he has moved beyond, while still coaching in a summer league where he’s praised for his work with kids. The trial involves six former narcotics officers charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing, with defense lawyers dismissing the prosecution’s case as reliant on 19 "lying" ex-dealers and a corrupt ex-cop.

An explosion at a controversial **paraxylene (PX) chemical plant** in **Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China**, triggered a massive fire on **Monday night**, injuring **six people**—five from broken glass—with all hospitalized. The blast, caused by an **oil leak at a storage facility**, prompted over **600 firefighters** to contain the flames by **Tuesday morning**, with no reported toxic chemical spill. Nearby residents described hearing a **loud explosion and tremors**, sharing images on **Weibo**, while authorities confirmed no casualties in a **2013 explosion** at the same plant. The facility, originally planned for **Xiamen**, was relocated to its current **remote location in 2007** after **public protests** over pollution risks, reflecting broader opposition in China to **PX plants**, which produce a **carcinogenic chemical** used in polyester manufacturing.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland U21 international, defiantly refuses to pull his socks up despite referees' warnings, citing a lifelong superstition. Known for wearing his socks low—just above his children-sized shinpads—he insists he won’t change, even after making his first Premier League start in Villa’s 3-3 draw against QPR. Grealish acknowledges referees’ attempts to correct him but remains firm, joking he’s never been kicked on the shin. While pleased with his debut start in a high-stakes relegation match, he expressed disappointment with the result but gratitude for his manager’s confidence, hoping to earn more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source close to the family. While her father, Bobby Brown, claimed she was "awake" and watching him during a public appearance, medical reports and family statements confirm she shows no response to visitors, familiar voices, or visual stimuli, with her long-term condition described as a tracheostomy-dependent state requiring extensive rehabilitation. Doctors indicate she may live for years, but the quality of her life remains uncertain, with her family expressing hope for a miracle while acknowledging the severity of her neurological state, which has persisted for nearly three months. Conflicting statements from Bobby Brown—later clarified by his wife and attorney as emotionally driven—highlight her transfer out of the ICU and the beginning of a difficult rehabilitation process.

Russia is on the verge of reaching the Fed Cup final after taking a 2-0 lead over Germany, with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saving a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova’s straight-sets win over Julia Görges in the opening match. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki’s aggressive play early on but recovered, despite 13 double faults, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved costly. Lisicki admitted missing a key match point and poor tiebreaker performance, while Pavlyuchenkova noted difficulties adjusting to Lisicki’s power. Russia now needs just one more victory from Sunday’s three matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week’s severe wild weather, are being warned to prepare for another storm expected to hit from **Thursday to Saturday**, bringing heavy rain and potential flooding. The same **east coast low** system that battered the state’s east coast for three days last week may return, though meteorologists suggest it could be **less severe and shorter** (two days) but still risky due to **saturated ground and uprooted trees**. The **Hunter region**, already devastated by flooding and high winds, is a major concern, with the **State Emergency Service (SES)** struggling to complete over **4,400 of 24,196 outstanding jobs** before the next system arrives. The **northern rivers and mid-north coast** are expected to bear the brunt of intense rainfall and strong winds, while **southeast Queensland** may also see heavy falls. The SES, with **1,000+ personnel** (including 200 from other states), is urging residents to **secure homes and prepare for possible evacuations**, warning that further rain could **raise flood levels** and hinder recovery efforts. The **Bureau of Meteorology** notes uncertainty in the storm’s severity but expects rain to peak **Thursday to Saturday**.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s *La Vida Loca* video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide after collapsing at her Milan apartment due to low blood pressure, which caused a fall and heavy bruising. She shared photos of her injuries on Instagram (with over 40,000 followers) and clarified she was recovering at home after hospital treatment, calling the suicide claims "shocking" and "not entirely correct." Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially suggested to media that she had tried to take her own life, blaming external pressures, but Moric stated he was in Naples during the incident. Italian outlets also referenced a alleged 2009 overdose attempt, which she did not address. Moric, a Croatian-born former wife of jailed paparazzo Fabrizio Corona—known as Italy’s "king of paparazzi" for blackmailing celebrities—shares a son, Carlos Maria (born 2002), with him; Corona was imprisoned after phone taps revealed him admitting to "ruining lives" without remorse.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov poll for *The Sunday Times* reveals the British public’s strong preference for traditional names, particularly **Diana**—honoring William’s late mother, Princess Diana—if the baby is a girl, with **12%** supporting it, followed by **Alice** (the late Queen’s aunt) and **Charlotte** (a nod to Prince Charles), each at **9%**. For a boy, **James** (13%) and **Alexander** are top choices, though **25%** of the 2,200 polled hope for a girl, compared to just **3%** wanting a brother for Prince George. Social media echoes the sentiment, with users expressing emotional attachment to the name Diana. Additionally, **68%** of Brits approve of William taking **six weeks’ paternity leave** from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in **Khost, eastern Afghanistan**, on Thursday, killing **17 people** and injuring **64 others**, including an **Afghan lawmaker**, according to provincial police chief **Faizullah Ghairat**. The protesters, led by **MP Humayoon Humayoon**, were marching toward a larger rally against the **provincial governor** when the attack occurred around **10 a.m. local time**. The **Taliban denied responsibility**, and no other group has claimed the attack. Eyewitness **Zahir Jan** confirmed the protesters' intentions, while **CNN reporters** contributed to the coverage from Kabul and Hong Kong.

Dani Alves is poised to depart Barcelona in the summer after his agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed he rejected the club’s final contract offer—a three-year extension contingent on playing 60% of matches. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back spent seven trophy-laden years at Barcelona, securing four Spanish league titles and two Champions League trophies, but failed to reach an agreement on a new deal. Santana criticized the timing of the negotiations, calling the process nonsensical, as the club only presented the offer in April, leaving Alves set to leave the Nou Camp.

Pablo Osvaldo, the 29-year-old striker on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club, believing they would thrive there. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games since his move, praised their South American-style abilities and claimed Boca’s fans at La Bombonera would adore them. He specifically named Pirlo—widely regarded as one of the world’s best midfielders—and Totti, a Roma icon, as his top choices among former teammates, emphasizing their perfect fit for Boca’s style and the passionate reception they’d receive.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a dramatic double somersault fall from the favorite horse *Merrion Square* during the 4:20 PM race at Wincanton, which went viral online with hundreds of thousands of views. Despite the spectacular crash—described by others as one of the most impressive falls they’d seen—Ferguson escaped with just a minor nose cut and returned to his routine duties, including mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls’ yard the next morning. He recalled the incident as a blur, only realizing what happened after watching the replay, and emphasized there was nothing he could do to avoid it, calling himself "very lucky." While he faced lighthearted teasing from fellow jockeys and gained social media followers, Ferguson remained undeterred, joking about a potential gymnastics career post-racing and resuming riding immediately.

The passage discusses England flanker and London Wasps captain **James Haskell** celebrating the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron* by posting an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man, mimicking Robert Downey Jr.’s character. The film premiered in London with a star-studded cast, including Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell’s rugby career is also detailed: he began at Wasps in 2002, earned his first England cap in 2007, then played for **Stade Français (2009–2011)**, **Ricoh Black Rams in Japan (2011)**, and **Highlanders in New Zealand (2012)** before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has made over **100 appearances for Wasps** and earned **57 England caps**, re-establishing himself as a key player for both club and country.

The wide-leg trouser is a key SS15 fashion trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans after their long dominance, with styles ranging from denim and cropped to printed or striped variations. While the look—revived from the 1970s—can feel intimidating, especially for shorter frames, styling tips include pairing it with high heels (preferably with an exposed top of foot) to elongate the leg, opting for high-waisted and extra-long lengths, and balancing the voluminous silhouette with a simple knit, shirt, or tee to maintain proportion. Denim flared jeans, like those seen in Gucci’s SS15 collection or Topshop’s *Miller* style, are the easiest entry point, while brands like Celine and Stella McCartney offered dressier, evening-appropriate versions. High-street options, such as Finery London, provide affordable alternatives, and the trend’s versatility makes it weather-proof for spring. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Poppy Delevingne have embraced the look, reinforcing its status as a wardrobe update.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of *American Sniper*—part of its UMix student social event series—after over 200 students petitioned against it, arguing the film’s portrayal of the Iraq War was discriminatory toward Middle Eastern people, a concern heightened by the Detroit area’s large Arab-American population. The 2014 film stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, the deadliest sniper in U.S. military history, who was killed in 2013. Following backlash and a counter-petition, Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper reversed the decision, acknowledging the cancellation contradicted the university’s commitment to free expression and student choice. The screening will proceed, with *Paddington* offered as an alternative, and the move was supported by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24 and residing in Cockburn Central, allegedly attempted to set a quokka—a small Australian animal about the size of a domestic cat—on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3 by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter, singeing the animal but leaving it alive. Detectives investigated the incident on the island, questioned the men, and seized video evidence of the act, leading to their eviction from Rottnest Island. Both tourists were charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are native to small islands off Western Australia, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

At 102 years old, Alice Barker—a former chorus-line dancer in 1930s and 1940s New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar, where she performed alongside legends such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra—was reunited with her past through newly discovered footage. Though films of her performances existed, Barker had never seen them, and her personal memorabilia had been lost over time, leaving her without visual records of her dancing career. With the help of jazz historian Mark Cantor and volunteers, a compilation of "soundies" (early music videos) featuring Barker was assembled and shown to her at her nursing home, where she joyfully reacted, calling the experience "fabulous."

The tradition of washing one’s own car in Britain is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting they never do it, instead opting for professional car washes. A survey of 1,100 adults by OSV found only 12% of men who wash their cars do so regularly, while just 5% have ever asked their children to clean the car for pocket money. Reasons for the decline include Sunday shop openings, live football on TV, the convenience of hand car washes, and the difficulty of cleaning larger vehicles like 4x4s. Though 15 million cars were owner-washed during the Easter break, a quarter did it just to escape the house. Owners in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield wash cars most frequently, while those in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh do so least. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be owner-washed, whereas Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least likely. OSV’s Andrew Kirkley attributes the shift to time constraints, bigger cars, disinterest from children, and the affordability of professional services.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard’s immense influence since his 2008 arrival at Liverpool, calling him one of the world’s best players and a defining figure for the club, though he acknowledges the team will never be the same without him. Gerrard, set to leave for LA Galaxy after the season, aims to cap his Liverpool career by leading the team to the FA Cup final—potentially facing Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, if they beat Aston Villa in the semi-final. Skrtel credits Gerrard for helping him settle at the club upon his own arrival from Zenit St Petersburg, highlighting his daily support and leadership. While admitting Gerrard’s departure will be challenging, Skrtel believes Liverpool’s younger players can fill the void with teamwork and guidance. Both players return from three-match bans for the Villa clash after their red cards in the March defeat to Manchester United.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one during the Par-3 Contest at Augusta National, dazzling the crowd on the 130-yard fourth hole with a shot that spun back into the cup—his first ace on Augusta’s hallowed turf. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus joked afterward about predicting the feat in an earlier interview, though his achievement was later overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who recorded two aces (on the fourth and eighth holes) but lost in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. The day tied the 2002 record with five total hole-in-ones. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion (first winning in 1963 at age 23 and last in 1986), is one of five golfers to complete the Career Grand Slam, a milestone Rory McIlroy could match by winning his third consecutive major.

Tornado sirens activated in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms spawned reported twisters, including one spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, which moved northeast and missed the city but threatened other areas. CNN’s severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of persistent storms and emphasized the heightened danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna, about 125 miles southwest of Wichita. Beyond Kansas, the National Weather Service noted a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri (70 miles from St. Louis), where wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees were reported, alongside large hail in nearby Farmington. The storms also produced unusual dark clouds in Leaddington, and the National Weather Service forecasted more severe weather for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River Valleys, and the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff’s deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April 2 arrest, claiming he mistakenly used a gun instead of a Taser while attempting to subdue Harris, who had fled during a weapons sting. Bates, who apologized and called the shooting accidental, was granted permission to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, a decision that drew criticism from Harris’s family, who viewed it as insensitive amid their mourning. Harris’s family alleges Bates was unqualified, received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, and that supervisors were pressured to forge his training records—claims denied by the sheriff’s office, though Bates’s lawyers released training documents they say prove his proper certification. Two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest were reassigned due to threats, and Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2, with his legal team emphasizing their preference to address the case in court rather than the media.

Conor McGregor, the 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against José Aldo on **July 11 in Las Vegas**, marking Aldo’s eighth title defense. McGregor, known as *"The Notorious,"* recently unveiled a new **tiger-face tattoo on his stomach**, symbolizing aggression with the caption, *"If you see the tiger, it’s too late. You’re food."* He claims Aldo lacks his motivation, stating the champion *"doesn’t want the belt in his presence"* and avoids confrontation, unlike McGregor, who **publicly grabbed Aldo’s belt during a Dublin promotional tour** in March, rallying 5,000 fans. Their rivalry intensifies ahead of the fight, with McGregor asserting his hunger for the title surpasses Aldo’s drive to retain it.

Tony Abbott, then-Australian Prime Minister, faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after publicly "skolling" (rapidly drinking) a schooner of beer at an Australian rules football event, where he was cheered by a crowd of about 50. Critics, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argued his actions glorified binge drinking and reinforced harmful stereotypes linking masculinity to heavy alcohol consumption, framing drinking as a competitive performance rather than social activity. While supporters like Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, citing his overall fitness, opponents, including Opposition Leader Bill Shorten, mocked his past preference for light beer, calling it "un-Australian." Abbott’s speech and enthusiastic downing of the beer—completed in about six seconds—were seen as perpetuating the idea that heavy drinking defines Australian identity, despite shifting public attitudes against binge drinking. Witnesses described Abbott as "proud as punch," but critics urged him to set a more responsible example.

Indiana’s Scott County, located 30 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky, has experienced a **significant HIV outbreak**, with **120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives**—up from 106 the prior week—primarily among **intravenous drug users** abusing the painkiller **Opana**. The surge follows Governor **Mike Pence’s** approval of a **30-day needle exchange program** (March 26–April 25), which has distributed **5,322 clean syringes** to 86 participants while collecting **1,400 used ones**. Health officials, who declared an epidemic, expect cases to rise with increased testing, pressuring Pence to extend the program; he plans a decision by early next week. A **mobile unit** has boosted participation by building trust with drug users, but the program’s long-term fate and broader legislation allowing exchanges in **23 high-hepatitis C counties** (a key HIV risk indicator) remain uncertain. While the **House passed a bill** (April 7) to expand exchanges, Senate leaders like **David Long** express skepticism, citing concerns about enabling drug use, though some acknowledge the need for adaptation. **Federal funding bans** since 1989 and lack of state funds for Scott County’s program raise sustainability questions, with critics like **Dr. Beth Meyerson** arguing the response lacks long-term planning. Proponents, including **Rep. Ed Clere**, frame exchanges as **harm-reduction policy**, not drug endorsement, warning that HIV risks persist beyond Scott County.

An obsessive Arsenal fan tested his girlfriend, Saskia, with a detailed 50-question exam about the club, formatted like a school test with multiple-choice questions, tables, and essay-style responses. She scored 43.5/50 (87%), earning an "A" grade and avoiding a breakup, though her boyfriend noted minor errors like misidentifying player positions (e.g., Özil as defense) and struggling to name the full starting XI (missing Koscielny). Creative answers—such as calling Eden Hazard a "p***k" and praising Thierry Henry—earned bonus points, while wrong answers triggered red-pen corrections and angry faces. The test included trivia like the 2014 FA Cup final score (Arsenal 3-2 Hull) and winner (Aaron Ramsey), as well as subjective questions like "Why is Arsenal the best team?" Saskia’s results, shared on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla), sparked mixed reactions: some called her "proper GF material" and the boyfriend a "legend," while others criticized the test as excessive. Despite the humor, the boyfriend’s playful ultimatum ("I will not be dumping you!") and Saskia’s near-perfect score turned the stunt into a viral moment, inspiring other fans to replicate the test.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín Cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and later became a DEA informant in the U.S. for 27 years, aiding in high-profile operations like the takedowns of drug lord Carlos Lehder Rivas and Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Though unpaid, he was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his undercover work, which included global stings, but the DEA has not fulfilled this promise. After retiring due to declining health, Toro now faces deportation and lives in the U.S. illegally, fearing assassination if returned to Colombia. Despite support from former handlers like DEA agent Mike McManus—who called the situation "government bureaucracy at its worst" and personally aided Toro financially—the DEA has refused to intervene. Toro’s temporary visa expired in January, leaving him in limbo without a green card, passport, or access to Social Security, and he may go into hiding if deported. He maintains he has "atoned" for his past and only seeks the citizenship he was promised.

A 14-year-old girl in India’s Uttar Pradesh allegedly set herself on fire with kerosene after being gang-raped by five men from her village when she stepped outside her home in Mathura district’s Kosi Kalan. Currently fighting for her life with 70% burns in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital, her family reportedly pressured her to stay silent about the attack. The accused have been arrested. The incident occurs amid heightened tensions over sexual violence in India, following the ban on *India’s Daughter*, a documentary about the 2012 gang rape and murder of 23-year-old Jyoti Singh, whose case sparked global outrage and protests. Recent vigilante attacks, including the beating deaths of two accused rapists in Nagaland—one later declared innocent—highlight public fury over gender-based violence, with calls for stronger protections for women. Jyoti’s killers were sentenced to death, while a juvenile received three years in reform school.

Louis van Gaal dreams of winning Manchester United’s derby against rivals Manchester City at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, whom he deems unfit despite their claims of readiness. A victory could lift United to second or third in the table, securing Champions League qualification without a playoff, a target Van Gaal admits exceeded pre-season expectations. He emphasizes controlling aggression, having lost the reverse fixture 1-0, and dismisses revenge as motivation, stating losses to City can happen. Key players like Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Ángel Di María, Radamel Falcao, and Ander Herrera trained ahead of the match, with Herrera in strong form. Van Gaal also praises United’s fans for their unwavering support, anticipating the electric derby atmosphere at Old Trafford.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a joint protest against soaring ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, following the league’s £5.14 billion TV rights deal announcement. With tickets starting at £64—among the highest in the league—supporters displayed banners inside and outside the ground, including one reading *"£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket,"* criticizing the financial burden on fans. Organized by Arsenal’s *Black Scarf Movement* and Liverpool’s *Spirit of Shankly* and *Spion Kop 1906* groups, protesters condemned "extortionate" prices, late fixture changes, and unreasonable kick-off times, arguing football has prioritized profit over fans. Kelvin Meadows called the costs a betrayal of match-going supporters, while Roy Bentham warned of losing a generation of working-class fans without tangible price reductions. The protest, which united rival fanbases, also featured slogans like *"Football without fans is nothing,"* with further demonstrations planned post-match.

Baby Star Reader was diagnosed with **biliary atresia**, a rare, life-threatening liver condition affecting 1 in 16,000 newborns, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, when persistent jaundice and pale stools prompted medical tests. Doctors confirmed her bile ducts were blocked, requiring an urgent liver transplant after an unsuccessful **Kasai procedure** (surgery to drain bile). Neither parent, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, was a suitable donor, but Jade’s twin sister, **Shanell Reader**, proved a perfect match and **donated part of her liver** without hesitation. The transplant, performed in November, succeeded, allowing Star to recover after six weeks in hospital, though she now requires lifelong **anti-rejection medication** and regular monitoring. Shanell, who also recovered well, emphasized her immediate willingness to save her niece, while Jade expressed overwhelming gratitude, calling the transplant a chance for Star to live a **normal life**. The condition, whose cause remains unclear, can lead to liver failure if untreated, with jaundice being a key early symptom.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Aké, Loïc Remy, and Willian participated in Audi’s football challenge, competing in a series of skill-based games. In the first round, Hazard and Aké won 5-3 by firing balls into a car’s boot from close range, while the second challenge involved long-range shots into convertible Audis, with Hazard and Aké extending their lead to 6-0 after a makeshift tennis match over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus. The final round—a long-range shooting challenge—saw Remy and Willian stage a comeback to win, though Willian accidentally smashed a car’s wing mirror during the attempt. Despite the mishap, the players humorously reacted, with Willian later rewarded by driving one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a fatal 2013 highway crash that killed Vermont couple Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and her fiancé Jason Timmons (29) when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph, shearing off the top of their SUV. Though prosecutors claimed Dellinger admitted to attempting suicide at the time, he denied being suicidal during his 2015 sentencing, where he pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus’s death, facing 12–24 years in prison. His defense attributed the crash to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug effects, and advanced multiple sclerosis, while his wife described him as ethical and expressed devastation to the victims’ families. Dellinger, who held high-level roles at companies like PPG Industries and GE, also faces a wrongful death lawsuit; prosecutors alleged he argued with his wife over medications before deliberately steering into the median, though his lawyer dismissed the state’s claims as exaggerated. Records show Dellinger left PPG in 2011 with a $1M+ severance and owns $3M in property.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to **20 years to life** in prison (avoiding the maximum 25 years) for the **second-degree murder** of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she poisoned with a lethal dose of salt via his feeding tube while hospitalized. Prosecutors argued she sought attention through her son’s illnesses, subjecting him to **unnecessary hospitalizations and procedures**, while her lawyer claimed she was a loving mother and blamed hospital negligence, planning to appeal. The boy’s father, **Chris Hill**, reacted angrily on Facebook, calling for her to be placed in **general population** and expressing hope she would die in prison, citing her **lack of emotion** during sentencing. The judge noted Spears’ **mental illness** but condemned the crime’s cruelty, while prosecutors highlighted her **social media posts**—including photos of Garnett’s final hours—as evidence of her **Munchausen by proxy** behavior. Spears, who lived in Chestnut Ridge, NY, maintained her innocence, claiming Garnett suffered from multiple medical conditions.

Concise concerns over two new influenza strains—**H3N2** and **B/Phuket**—which caused a surge in flu-related deaths in Europe and the U.S. due to a mismatched vaccine, have led to an **improved vaccine** arriving in Australia a month late. The updated shot, also covering **H1N1**, will be **free for high-risk groups** (young, elderly, and most Indigenous Australians) from **April 20**. Experts, including **Dr. Alan Hampson** of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasize its effectiveness and urge **all Australians**—even those not in high-risk categories—to get vaccinated to protect vulnerable contacts. The modified vaccine aligns with global strains and mirrors the one planned for the next northern hemisphere winter, aiming to reduce deaths compared to overseas outbreaks. Delays mean **early bookings** are advised.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois, face criticism and financial uncertainty as the state marks the 150th anniversary of his assassination. A *National Geographic* article dismissed the tomb’s interior as lacking historical character, comparing it to an "office lobby," while historian Adam Goodheart called its Art Deco-style reconstruction disappointing. Meanwhile, Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner’s proposed budget cuts threaten to eliminate the state’s historic preservation agency, which oversees the tomb, merging it into another department amid a broader financial crisis. Reduced funding has already led to shorter operating hours, fewer staff, and locked doors, frustrating visitors. Despite recent renovations totaling over $2.5 million—including upgrades to plaster, marble, lighting, and waterproofing—supporters like Pam VanAlstine of the Lincoln Monument Association fear further cuts could harm the site’s upkeep. Originally designed by sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, the tomb has undergone multiple reconstructions, now featuring a marble-and-bronze interior with Lincoln’s burial chamber marked by the inscription *"Now he belongs to the ages."* While critics pan its design, visitors like William Sparks praise its grandeur, highlighting divided opinions on its historical presentation.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, highlighting both their renewed popularity and the controversies surrounding some of the more extreme styles. While chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo tees are embraced by a new generation, the return of **JNCO’s ultra-wide "rave" jeans** (with 50-inch leg openings) has sparked backlash from those who wore them originally. The article critiques other questionable trends making comebacks, including **bucket hats** (worn by Christina Aguilera in the 2000s and recently by Rihanna), **camouflage print** (popularized by Destiny’s Child and now seen on Jordyn Dunn), **double denim and maximalist prints** (championed by 90s stars like Britney Spears and now by Kylie Jenner), **UGG boots** (a noughties staple of Paris Hilton and still worn by Kristen Bell), **Daisy Dukes** (revived by Jessica Simpson in 2005 and now sported by Miley Cyrus), **Juicy Couture velour tracksuits** (favored by Britney Spears and Nicki Minaj), **colored sunglasses** (worn by *NSYNC and now by Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner), **corsets as outerwear** (pioneered by Victoria Beckham and now seen on Selena Gomez), and **harem trousers** (once loved by Kim Kardashian and still worn by Elle Macpherson). The piece ultimately questions whether these impractical or over-the-top trends should remain in the past.

The passage highlights several trending stories from a busy week, including a rare sighting of **four rainbows** in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by fashion CEO **Amanda Curtis**. In **rural China**, authorities cracked down on the practice of hiring **exotic dancers for wakes**, forcing families to find alternative ways to entertain mourners. Actor **Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ)** became visibly agitated during a **Channel 4 interview** when questioned about his private life. The **Kardashian-inspired "#KylieJennerChallenge"** went viral, with people attempting to plump their lips by sucking on jars to mimic **Kylie Jenner’s** look. A **102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker**, relived her past with the help of filmmakers, while a **prom proposal referencing bombs** sparked controversy, with the student accusing school administrators of **racism**. Casting news included **Ewan McGregor** as Lumiere in *Beauty and the Beast*, and **Johnny Depp’s** dramatic transformation in the *Black Mass* trailer. Creative pregnancy announcements, like a *Fresh Prince of Bel-Air* reference, and a **military dad photobombing** his son’s picture also stood out for their originality.

The **Miami Open** saw Serena Williams achieve her **700th career victory**, celebrated with a giant cake, after defeating Germany’s Sabine Lisicki **7-6, 1-6, 6-3** to reach the semi-finals, avenging her 2013 Wimbledon loss to the same opponent. This followed Andy Murray’s **500th win**, also marked with a cake. Williams’ potential clash with sister Venus was thwarted by Venus’ loss to Spain’s Carla Suárez Navarro. The world No. 1 advanced to face **Simona Halep**, who beat Sloane Stephens **6-1, 7-5**, for a spot in the final, with Williams treating the tournament as a near-hometown event. The matches highlighted tight competition, celebratory milestones, and Williams’ resilience in overcoming a mid-match dip.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani activist and founder of *The Second Floor (T2F)*, a vibrant Karachi café and cultural hub, was fatally shot by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on Balochistan’s enforced disappearances—a taboo topic in Pakistan. Known for her fearless advocacy of free speech, human rights, women’s entrepreneurship, and progressive values, Mahmud defied threats to amplify marginalized voices, even after authorities canceled the event at Lahore University. Her café, a sanctuary for secular thought and artistic expression, became a symbol of resistance, blending psychedelic art, graffiti, and open dialogue in a country where dissent is often met with violence. Mahmud’s killing, which also injured her mother, sparked nationwide mourning, with tributes pouring in for her courage and vision of a just, tolerant Pakistan. Though no group claimed responsibility, her assassination underscored the dangers of challenging state narratives, particularly regarding Balochistan’s long-standing insurgency and alleged human rights abuses. Friends and admirers, like BBC journalist Ziad Zafar, hailed her as a "brave heart" who inspired countless Pakistanis to demand liberty and justice, leaving a void in the nation’s struggle for free expression.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, is one of roughly 100,000 **West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs)** who fled to Indian-administered Kashmir during the 1947 Partition but remain stateless after 70 years, denied property ownership, voting rights in state elections, and government jobs due to their refugee status. Living in slums in Jammu, Kashmir’s Hindu-dominated winter capital, three generations of WPRs—most of whom have never visited Pakistan—face systemic poverty, barred by pre-independence laws granting citizenship only to those with roots in the former Kingdom of Kashmir. While other refugees were absorbed post-Partition, the WPRs’ fate became entangled in Kashmir’s disputed status and fears of altering the Muslim-majority state’s demographics. Despite Kashmir’s relative prosperity, WPR families like Ram’s survive on meager incomes, with children excluded from state-run colleges and jobs. Hope has emerged with **Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist BJP** gaining power in Kashmir’s coalition government, pledging to normalize WPR status, though activists like Labha Ram Gandhi warn of protests—or even violence—if reforms fail. The community’s plight underscores broader tensions in Kashmir, where militant attacks and demands for independence or merger with Pakistan persist amid decades of conflict.

Yoshinori Muto, a 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward and Japan international, is weighing a potential £4 million summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who reportedly plan to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem. However, Muto prioritizes joining a team where he can play regularly and develop his career, stating he needs time to decide. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed Chelsea’s offer, while Muto’s former manager Ranko Popovic praised his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence, calling him an exceptional talent with innate qualities. Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledged Muto’s potential but avoided detailed comments, citing professionalism, though he noted commercial factors—like the club’s £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber—influence transfers, emphasizing they only sign players who can contribute on the pitch.

Australia has abandoned its policy of excluding overseas-based players from national selection, a move praised as progressive, while England’s refusal to do the same is criticized as outdated. The argument highlights top performers like **Matt Giteau** and **Drew Mitchell** (Toulon) excelling abroad and potentially strengthening Australia’s World Cup squad, contrasting with England’s exclusion of stars like **Steffon Armitage**—whose form has surged in France—despite his turnovers and ball-carrying prowess. Examples like **Jonny Wilkinson** and **Nick Abendanon** further prove players can thrive overseas, yet England’s **Stuart Lancaster** maintains a rigid stance, risking weaker squads and post-tournament "what ifs." The passage stresses that global tournaments demand the best players regardless of club location, noting that **South Africa** and **Wales** successfully integrate overseas talents like **Bryan Habana** and **Leigh Halfpenny**, while England’s policy undermines competitiveness and player morale. The call is for England to prioritize merit over club loyalty to maximize World Cup success.

Open Garden’s **FireChat** app enables off-grid messaging without internet or mobile signals by using **wireless mesh networks**, where phones act as nodes to relay messages via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct (up to ~30 feet/9 meters). The app, downloaded over **5 million times**, leverages Apple’s **Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF)** (iOS 7+) and Android’s similar feature, allowing secure, anonymous communication—useful in areas like planes, subways, or during protests. However, messages typically travel only **~200 feet (61 meters)**. To extend range, Open Garden developed **Greenstone**, an egg-shaped beacon that stores and forwards messages (up to **1,000 recent ones**) when other FireChat users come within **~20 feet (6 meters)**, with a **one-year battery life**. Greenstone aims to strengthen mesh networks in high-density areas (e.g., festivals, hospitals) where traditional networks fail, though it’s still in development and depends on manufacturer partnerships for wider release.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, advocates for reclaiming the word **"fat"** as a neutral, body-positive descriptor, comparing it to terms like *"short"* (at 5'3") or *"wife"* (as she is married), arguing it shouldn’t equate to *"ugly."* In her 2014 TED Talk (posted online recently with 38,000 views), she critiques societal conditioning that frames fatness as inherently negative, citing a **66% rise in workplace size discrimination** over 30 years and studies showing young girls’ top wish is to be thinner. However, she highlights research that **exposure to body diversity increases acceptance and preference** for varied body types, which inspires her burlesque performances—using glamour to challenge narrow beauty standards. Initially nervous about her 240lb frame, she found empowerment in performing, urging others to recall moments of bravery (*"courage references"*) during insecurity.
