Despite some online trolling, her talk sparked overwhelmingly positive feedback, including messages from teens rethinking body image, reinforcing her belief that **body-positivity is gaining ground.**

Theo Walcott has frequently been left on Arsenal’s bench this season, appearing as a substitute in 17 of their 33 Premier League games and playing just six minutes in their 0-0 draw with Chelsea. The 26-year-old winger, alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Özil, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin—Paris’s oldest fashion house and Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013—alongside model Olga Sherer, with the team set to wear Lanvin attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott, who last started for Arsenal in their 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14, hopes to return to the starting lineup in their upcoming match against Hull.

A collection of over 400 props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist **Rick Baker**—spanning his 30-year career across films like *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, *Planet of the Apes*, and Michael Jackson’s *Moonwalker*—will be auctioned **May 29** at the **Hilton Universal City (Los Angeles)** and on **PropStore.com**, with no reserve. The **$746,100-estimated collection** includes high-value items like the **Edgar Bug alien from *Men in Black* ($40,000)**, the **Grinch costume ($8,000)**, the **Mikey costume from *Men in Black* ($30,000)**, the **Two-Face mask from *Batman Forever* ($1,500)**, and the **Harry suit from *Harry and the Hendersons* ($6,000)**. Other notable lots feature **gremlins puppets ($6,000–$8,000)**, a **Michael Jackson robotic face ($3,000)**, and pieces from *An American Werewolf in London*, *Hellboy*, and *Mighty Joe Young*. PropStore’s Brandon Alinger called the auction a rare chance for fans to own iconic creations from Baker’s influential work in Hollywood.

The family of seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, a "daring, outgoing, and determined" British boy from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, expressed profound grief after his fatal fall in the French Alps, calling his death a "vast void in their hearts." While skiing with his mother, Ceri (44), sister Antonia (9), and brother Gerwyn (19) in Flaine, Carwyn became separated after Antonia lost a ski, leading him to venture into dense woodland off-piste. Footprints and sliding marks in the snow revealed he had removed his skis, likely trying to reach the resort he spotted through the trees, before falling 164ft to his death. His mother frantically searched for him, but police located his body using his tracks. Described as a "competent skier" since age three and an adventurous fan of Bear Grylls, Carwyn was remembered for his "handsome smile," love of laughter, and kindness. His family had enjoyed a happy holiday before the tragedy, while back in Wales, his school and community—including Brecon Cathedral and Ysgol y Bannau—mourned the "lively, likeable" boy. The family, known for their award-winning farm shop, awaits repatriation of his body amid an outpouring of support.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after feeling pressured to achieve a "size zero" body, fueled by bullying and societal expectations. At her worst, she survived on just 100 calories a day—often a single piece of fruit—while hiding food to deceive her family, leading to severe malnutrition. Her extreme weight loss caused her heart rate to dangerously slow, resulting in a collapse and a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. Laura’s struggle began at age 13 when she weighed nearly 13 stone and faced weight-related bullying, pushing her into an obsessive diet that spiraled into anorexia. After hospitalization, she received support from eating disorder organizations (EDICT and CAMHS) and has since recovered, now advocating against size-zero pressures. Her mother, Sue, highlighted the terrifying extent of Laura’s condition, including her indifference to health as long as she remained thin. Today, Laura’s improved body image and confidence have led her to the semi-finals of *Miss Teen GB*, a competition promoting positive self-image over harmful stereotypes. The passage also notes that anorexia, a serious mental health condition, affects around 725,000 people in the UK, with 10% suffering from anorexia specifically, often driven by anxiety over body shape and societal pressures.

Liverpool fans pressured Raheem Sterling to stay at the club during the unveiling of their 2015/16 home kit—a gingham design by New Balance, marking the brand’s first under a record £300 million four-year deal. Sterling, alongside teammates like Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, presented the kit at Anfield, though his future had been uncertain after rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract and expressing interest in a move to Arsenal. Despite this, Liverpool insisted Sterling, who has two years left on his contract, would not leave this summer, with fans vocally urging his retention. The players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, emphasizing the importance of winning the trophy for the club’s success. The new kit includes a tribute to the Hillsborough victims and features an all-white branding design, while departing captain Steven Gerrard’s hope of an FA Cup final farewell remains alive.

Researchers from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, covering 0.4% of the sky (150 times the area of the full moon) using data from the Dark Energy Camera (DECam) on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. The map, released at the American Physical Society meeting, reveals dark matter clumps (red) and sparse regions (blue) by analyzing gravitational lensing distortions in 130 million galaxies, requiring supercomputers for precision measurements. Part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), the project aims to map 12.5% (one-eighth) of the sky in 3D by 2018 to study dark matter’s role in galaxy formation and its interplay with dark energy, which accelerates the universe’s expansion. The map supports theories that galaxies form in high-dark-matter regions, showing filaments of matter where galaxies cluster and voids where few exist, while follow-up studies will further explore this relationship. Dark matter, though invisible, comprises ~85% of the universe’s matter and is detected via its gravitational effects on light.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who previously coached him during Holland’s 2014 World Cup campaign—eager to secure him as a key summer signing. Depay, PSV’s star player and the Eredivisie’s top scorer with 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped the club win their first Dutch title in seven years after a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen, showcasing his skill with a stunning free kick. PSV confirmed interest from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, with Depay’s value now exceeding Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid from the previous summer. Known for his pace, dribbling, and explosive right foot, Depay—who joined PSV at 12 and made over 100 appearances—has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo, with scouts and teammates praising his athleticism, flair, and potential. Though still raw and occasionally inconsistent, his World Cup performances (including goals against Australia and Chile) and rapid development have cemented his reputation as one of Europe’s most promising talents.

Chelsea secured a dominant 3-1 away win against Manchester City’s youth side in the FA Youth Cup final first leg, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice (his 35th and 36th goals of the season) and Dominic Solanke adding a late third to extend their lead. Abraham’s first-half brace put Chelsea ahead, though Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly leveled for City. Chelsea’s attack overwhelmed City’s defense, with Ola Aina and Jake Clarke-Salter standing out defensively, while City’s Brandon Barker and Tosin Adarabioyo showed promise despite the loss. Key players like Kean Bryan (injured) and Bersant Celina struggled to impact the game, while Chelsea’s midfield, led by Charlie Colkett, controlled play. The result leaves Chelsea firmly in control ahead of the second leg at Stamford Bridge.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, argued that sexual preference is innate but maintained that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right, instead leaving the decision to state legislators. While he personally believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, he stated he would attend a same-sex wedding of a loved one or staffer despite disagreeing with it, emphasizing respect and love over personal beliefs. Rubio also compared this stance to his Catholic opposition to divorce, clarifying he wouldn’t reject someone for being divorced. He opposed judicial intervention on marriage laws, insisting the matter should be resolved through state political processes. Additionally, Rubio recently launched his presidential campaign, with donors pledging over $51 million to support his primary bid against a competitive field of well-funded Republican rivals.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple cycling around the world with no fixed plans, agenda, or timeline, driven purely by their dream to explore the planet by bike. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they embarked on an open-ended journey, covering nearly **7,000 miles (11,131 km) across 16 countries in 356 days**, living on **less than €3 per day each** (€0.10 per km) by relying on free accommodation—primarily camping (161 nights), Couchsurfing (66 nights), and Warm Showers (44 nights)—and minimal food costs (€2.74/day). Their route began in London, winding through **Western and Southern Europe (France, Spain, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece)** before crossing into **Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia**, with plans to continue into **Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas**. They sustain themselves on simple foods like pasta, rice, and seasonal produce, often supplemented by wild foraging, dumpster diving in Western countries, or meals from generous strangers. Carrying **130 kg of gear**, they embrace spontaneity, stunning landscapes, and the kindness of others, viewing their journey as a long-term, low-budget odyssey into the unknown.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 discovered months after their wedding that their hired photo booth from **Premiere Photos**, owned by **James Evans**, allegedly printed the racial slur *"poor n***** party"* on some of their photos. The bride’s sister withheld the information to avoid ruining the wedding day, but the couple later sued under the **Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act**, citing **negligence and breach of contract**. Evans denied the allegations, claimed no evidence tied his company to the slur, and reportedly told the groom to *"sue me"* instead of apologizing. The couple, represented by attorney **Cathy Hale**, seeks an apology rather than financial compensation, with **mediation scheduled** before a potential **July trial**. The wedding took place at **Beautiful Bell Tower in Houston**, and Evans’ attorney argued the couple showed no signs of distress.

England full-back **Mike Brown** is taking a **cautious approach** to recovering from his latest concussion, admitting uncertainty over his return date after withdrawing from Harlequins’ match against Saracens due to post-game headaches following England’s clash with France. He emphasizes the importance of **not rushing back** to avoid long-term risks, citing examples like **Johnny Sexton** (12-week break) and **Geoff Parling**, while **George North**—who suffered **four concussions in quick succession**, including a knockout against Wasps—has been **advised by medics to sit out the rest of the season** and will consult a neurosurgeon. Brown, who was **knocked out cold** during England’s February win over Italy, credits **World Rugby’s online concussion education** for helping him recognize symptoms, leading him to **pull out of the Ireland game** despite its significance. He now **advocates for honesty and caution**, urging teammates to prioritize health over playing through symptoms, stressing that **short- and long-term dangers** outweigh the temptation to push through. The passage also notes Brown’s involvement in **Land Rover’s "We Deal in Real" campaign**, promoting grassroots rugby ahead of the **2032 Rugby World Cup**.

A leading expert suggests smartphone and internet use may contribute to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, with heterosexual pairs now averaging three times a month—down from four in 2000 and five in 1990, according to Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book *Sex by Numbers*. The blur between work and private life, constant digital connectivity, and competing time demands are cited as key factors, as people prioritize tasks like late-night emails over intimacy. Spiegelhalter also notes rising single-person households but emphasizes that technological integration and busier lifestyles have eroded quiet, personal time previously spent with partners, pushing sex lower on priority lists.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols in China and sold for up to £1.2 million per dog, have seen their value collapse due to the government’s anti-corruption crackdown, which discouraged their use as bribes, and urban bans on large dogs (over 50 kg) in cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Once bred for herding and known for loyalty, these 80 kg dogs are now being abandoned, stolen, or sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skins for leather. A recent rescue revealed 20 mastiffs in cramped cages—many dead or injured—highlighting widespread cruelty, with hundreds feared to face similar fates. Overbreeding for profit has also degraded the breed’s quality, flooding the market with "imperfect" dogs. Urbanization and the dogs’ unsuitability for city life have further reduced demand, marking a stark decline from their 2005–2022 boom, when they were flaunted as luxury items.

A survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that **every respondent** had experienced sexual harassment or assault on public transport, with **half first harassed before age 18**, ranging from verbal insults and intimidation (whistling, comments on appearance) to physical attacks or rape. The issue forces **six in ten women to fear public transport** (vs. three in ten men), leading many to alter routes, schedules, clothing, or avoid transit entirely, effectively **excluding them from public spaces**. The report, submitted to France’s Women’s Rights Ministry, highlights that such abuse often goes **unreported and normalized**, with victims unaware it constitutes assault—such as unwanted touching, which carries a **five-year prison term and €75,005 fine**. Experts, including Pascale Boisard of the High Council for Gender Equality, called for **public campaigns to combat impunity**, educate victims that harassment is unlawful, and hold aggressors and bystanders accountable, emphasizing that **freedom of movement is a fundamental right**. Attackers exploit crowds to evade consequences, reinforcing a culture of unchecked abuse.

Direct Line’s *#everydayfix* competition, run with London-based design firm Makerversity, crowdsourced solutions for common daily stresses identified in a survey of 2,000 people, where the top issues included sleeplessness (46%), lost keys (37%), and phone battery drain (31%). Three prototypes were shortlisted for public voting via Twitter retweets: **Snooze** (an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for undisturbed sleep), **Forget Me Lock** (a key attachment turning green/red to confirm door lock status remotely), and **Nipper** (a tiny charger powered by household batteries for emergency phone boosts). The winning design, determined by retweets with the *#everydayfix* hashtag by April 46, will proceed to a Kickstarter campaign for production. Other rejected prototypes included a **parking pin** (alerting when a space becomes free), the **Relay app** (forwarding messages when a phone dies), and **Hat Nav** (a cycling helmet with bone-conduction directions). The initiative highlights innovative, simple fixes for everyday frustrations, blending public input with design expertise.

Vera Baird, Northumbria’s Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC), is under Ministry of Justice investigation for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to *Victims First Northumbria*, a charity she co-directs alongside Chief Constable Sue Sim, raising conflict-of-interest concerns. The funding followed a Home Office rule allowing PCCs to commission victim services, but critics, including Labour MP Keith Vaz, called the arrangement "inappropriate" and likened the force’s internal disputes to a "soap opera." Baird defended the decision, claiming compliance with protocols, while Sim—previously accused of bullying and facing misconduct probes—announced her retirement amid scrutiny. The charity was created after a decline in contacts to its predecessor, *Victim Support*, but sources suggest potential distrust due to Sim’s involvement. The Ministry of Justice will determine if rules were breached, with powers to withdraw funding if conflicts are confirmed.

Three people—**Corry "Corey" Campbell (21)**, the ringleader, **Carl Halin (18)**, and **Sandra Ng (19)**, Campbell’s girlfriend—were sentenced for their roles in a **42-hour torture** of **Greg Valecce (53)**, an unemployed drug addict, in **March 2014** at Campbell’s mother’s Philadelphia basement. Campbell, believing Valecce had injured his cat and stolen from him, led the assault, which included **beating, restraining, and tattooing offensive symbols** (e.g., swastikas, racial slurs, and a penis ejaculating on a rainbow) onto Valecce’s body while filming the abuse. Valecce escaped with **broken ribs, wrists, and facial bones**, later removing the tattoos but suffering lasting trauma. Campbell and Halin received **20-year sentences**, Ng got **23 months**, while **David Thomas (28)** awaits sentencing and **Jennifer Pratt (40)** awaits trial. Police found **tattoo equipment, drugs, and Valecce’s stolen debit card** at the scene.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who previously coached him during Holland’s 2014 World Cup campaign—eager to secure him as a key summer signing. Depay, PSV’s star player and the Eredivisie’s top scorer with 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped the club win their first Dutch title in seven years after a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen, where he scored a stunning free kick. PSV confirmed United’s interest alongside Paris Saint-Germain and another top European club, with technical director Marcel Brands noting the transfer would involve a significantly higher fee than Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid last summer. Depay, known for his pace, dribbling, and explosive right-foot shots, has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo, with scouts and managers praising his potential. After rising through PSV’s youth system since age 12, he made his debut in 2011 and has over 100 appearances, though his decision-making remains a work in progress. Internationally, Depay scored crucial goals at the 2014 World Cup, including the winner against Australia, and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea secured a dominant 3-1 away win against Manchester City’s youth side in the FA Youth Cup final first leg, taking a commanding lead back to West London. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half with powerful volleys (his 35th and 36th goals of the season) before being substituted due to injury, while Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the victory after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly equalized for City. Chelsea’s attack overwhelmed City’s defense, with Ola Aina and Jake Clarke-Salter standing out defensively, while City’s Brandon Barker and Tosin Adarabioyo showed promise despite the loss. Key players like Kean Bryan (injured) and Bersant Celina struggled to impact the game, while Chelsea’s midfield, led by Charlie Colkett, controlled proceedings. The result left City facing an uphill battle in the second leg.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, argues that sexual preference is innate but maintains that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right, asserting instead that states should decide through legislative debate rather than court rulings. While he personally believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, he stated he would attend a same-sex wedding of a loved one or staffer despite disagreeing with it, emphasizing respect and love over personal beliefs. Rubio also compared this stance to his Catholic opposition to divorce, clarifying that disagreement does not equate to rejecting individuals. Additionally, he recently launched his presidential campaign, with donors reportedly pledging over $47 million to support his primary bid against a competitive field of Republican candidates.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple cycling around the world with no fixed plans, agenda, or timeline, driven purely by their dream to explore the planet by bike. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they embarked on an open-ended journey in 2015, covering nearly **7,000 miles (11,131 km) across 16 countries** in their first year, including France, Spain, Italy, Slovenia, Bosnia, Turkey, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas. Living on **less than €3 per day each** (€0.10 per km), they minimize costs by camping (161 nights), using hosting platforms like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and relying on free food from locals, wild foraging, or dumpster diving in Western countries. Their diet consists mainly of **pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, and seasonal produce**, with food as their only major expense (€2.74/day). Carrying **130 kg of gear**, they embrace slow travel, stopping to admire landscapes—from the French Alps to Turkey’s northern coast—while documenting their adventure on their blog, *The Crazy Travel*, and living off the kindness of strangers along the way.

England full-back **Mike Brown** is taking a **cautious approach** to recovering from his latest concussion, admitting uncertainty over his return date after withdrawing from Harlequins’ match against Saracens due to post-game headaches following England’s clash with France. He emphasizes the importance of **not rushing back** to avoid long-term absences like those of **Johnny Sexton** (12-week break) or **Geoff Parling**, citing increased **concussion awareness** from World Rugby’s online modules, which helped him recognize symptoms and pull out of England’s Ireland game in March. Meanwhile, **George North**, after suffering his **fourth concussion in quick succession** (most recently against Wasps), has been **advised by medics to sit out the rest of the season** and will consult a neurosurgeon. Brown, who was **knocked out cold** during England’s February win over Italy, stresses the **dangers of playing through symptoms**, urging teammates to prioritize health over matches, even high-stakes games like England vs. Ireland. He credits education on **short- and long-term risks** for his cautious stance, reinforcing that **"it’s just not worth pushing through."**

A leading expert suggests smartphone and internet use may contribute to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, with heterosexual pairs now averaging three times a month—down from four in 2000 and five in 1990, according to Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book *Sex by Numbers*. He attributes the drop to blurred boundaries between work and private life, constant digital connectivity eroding "quiet empty time," and competing demands that push sex lower on priority lists. Spiegelhalter also cites factors like more people living alone but emphasizes that technological busyness—such as checking work emails late—reduces intimate time with partners, leaving people "too connected" to focus on relationships by bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols in China and sold for up to £1.2 million per dog, have seen their value collapse due to the government’s anti-corruption crackdown, which deterred their use as bribes, and urban bans on large dogs (over 50 kg) in cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Traditionally used in Tibet for herding, these loyal dogs now face mass slaughter, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and skins for leather. Animal rescuers recently saved 20 emaciated, injured mastiffs en route to a slaughterhouse, with many already dead from neglect, while thefts and dumping of "imperfect" dogs by breeders have surged. Overbreeding for profit has degraded the breed’s quality, flooding the market with unsellable dogs. Urbanization has also revealed their unsuitability for city life, reversing a decade-long boom where they were flaunted as luxury items—including a record £1.2 million sale in 2023. Hundreds are feared to be meeting similar cruel fates across China.

Direct Line’s *#everydayfix* competition, run by Leeds-based insurance company Direct Line in collaboration with London design firm Makerversity, invited groups to create prototypes addressing common daily stresses identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top "everyday emergencies" included sleep disruption (46%), lost keys (37%), traffic delays (35%), and phone battery drain (31%). Three finalists emerged: **Snooze**, an alarm clock by *Instruments* that silences phone notifications for undisturbed sleep; **Forget Me Lock**, a key-attached device by *Onn Studio* that turns red/green to confirm door lock status remotely; and **Nipper**, a tiny charger by *Impulse* powered by household batteries for on-the-go phone boosts. The public can vote via Twitter retweets (with *#everydayfix*) by April 40 to determine which prototype advances to a Kickstarter campaign for production. Other rejected prototypes included a **parking pin** (alerts when spaces free), the **Relay app** (forwards messages when a phone dies), and **Hat Nav** (a cycling helmet with bone-conduction directions). The initiative highlights creative solutions to mundane but widespread frustrations.
